questions.title: Prove a relation between velocity and acceleration
questions.questionText: Two particles \(P\) and \(Q\) move in a straight line \(AB\) towards each other. \(P\) starts from \(A\) with a velocity \(u_1\) and an acceleration \(a_1\). \(Q\) starts from \(B\) with velocity \(u_2\) and an acceleration \(a_2\). They pass from each other at midpoint of \(AB\) and arrive at other ends of \(AB\) with equal velocities. Prove that \((u_1+u_2)(a_1-a_2)=8(a_1u_2-a_2u_1)\).
questions.solution:
Let the particle \(P\) reach \(C\) (midpoint of AB) in time \(t\), then the particle \(Q\) must reach \(C\) also in time \(t\).

 DIAGRAM[1,200]
For P:
\(\dfrac{l}{2} = u_1t + \dfrac{1}{2}a_1t^2\)  ...(1)

For Q:
\(\dfrac{l}{2} = -u_2t + \dfrac{1}{2}(-a_2)t^2\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{l}{2} = u_2t + \dfrac{1}{2}a_2t^2\)  ...(2)

From (1) and (2), we get (by subtracting)
\((u_2 - u_1)t + \dfrac{1}{2}(a_2 - a_1)t^2 = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow t = 2(\dfrac{u_2-u_1}{a_1-a_2})\)  ...(3)

Now, substitute this value of \(t\) from (3) in any of equations (1) or (2), we get
\(\dfrac{l}{2} = u_1[2(\dfrac{u_2-u_1}{a_1-a_2})] + \dfrac{1}{2}a_1[2(\dfrac{u_2-u_1}{a_1-a_2})]^2\)
\(\dfrac{l}{2} = 2(\dfrac{u_2-u_1}{a_1-a_2})[u_1 + a_1(\dfrac{u_2-u_1}{a_1-a_2})]\)
\(\Rightarrow l = \dfrac{4(u_2-u_1)}{(a_1-a_2)^2}[u_1a_1 - u_1a_2 + a_1u_2 - a_1u_1]\)
\(\Rightarrow l = \dfrac{4(u_2-u_1)(a_1u_2 - a_2u_1)}{(a_1-a_2)^2}\)  ...(4)

Again, after reading the question carefully, we observe that P reaches B and Q reaches A with equal velocities, say v.
Then, for P, we have
\(v^2 - u_1^2 = 2a_1l\)   ...(5)

For Q, we have
\(v^2 - u_2^2 = 2a_2l\)  ...(6)
\(\Rightarrow v^2 - u_1^2 = 2a_1l\)
\(\Rightarrow v^2 - u_2^2 = 2a_2l\)
\(\Rightarrow u_2^2 - u_1^2 = 2(a_1 - a_2)l\)
\(\Rightarrow l = \dfrac{u_2^2-u_1^2}{2(a_1-a_2)}\)  ...(7)
From equation (4) and (7), we get,
\(\dfrac{u_2^2-u_1^2}{2(a_1-a_2)} = \dfrac{4(u_2-u_1)(a_1u_2 - a_2u_1)}{(a_1-a_2)^2}\)
\((u_2+u_1) = \dfrac{8(a_1u_2 - a_2u_1)}{(a_1-a_2)}\)
\((u_1+u_2)(a_1-a_2) = 8(a_1u_2-a_2u_1)\) (Hence proved)
questions.hint: Use equations of motions to find the time when they meet and their relations. Use the equal final velocities to relate the initial velocities and accelerations.
methodOfSolving: Find time t when they meet each other.
Find the relation between distance l and the given parameters.
Use the relation that the final velocities are equal at the other end.
Equate the two relations for distance l to get the final relation

questions.title: Time of Flight for Two Stones Dropped from a Cliff
questions.questionText: A stone is dropped from the top of a cliff of height \(h\). \(n\) second later, a second stone is projected downwards from the same cliff with a vertically downward velocity \(u\). Show that the two stones will reach the bottom of the cliff together, if \(8h(u-gn)^2 = gn^2(2u-gn)^2\). What can you say about the limiting value of \(n\)?
questions.solution:
The time taken by the first stone to reach the bottom of the cliff is \(\sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}}\).

According to the given problem, the second stone is projected \(n\) second later. The two stones will reach the bottom together, if the second covers the same distance in time \(t = \sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}}-n\).

Since, \(h = ut + \dfrac{1}{2}gt^2\)
Hence, \(h = u\left[\sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}}-night] + \dfrac{1}{2}g\left[\sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}}-night]^2\)
\(\Rightarrow h = u\sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}} - un + \dfrac{g}{2}\left[\dfrac{2h}{g}-2n\sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}}+n^2ight]\)
\(\Rightarrow h = u\sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}} - un + \left[h - gn\sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}} + \dfrac{n^2g}{2}ight]\)
\(\Rightarrow 2h = u\sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}} - un + 2h - 2gn\sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}}+n^2g \)
\(\Rightarrow 2h = (u-gn)\sqrt{\dfrac{8h}{g}} + \dfrac{n^2g}{2}-un\)
\(\Rightarrow 2h = u\sqrt{\dfrac{8h}{g}} + \dfrac{n^2g}{2} - un\)
Solving it, we get
\(h - \dfrac{gn^2}{8} = \left(\dfrac{2u-gn}{u-gn}ight)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 8h(u-gn)^2 = gn^2(2u-gn)^2\)
Hence, the two stones will reach the bottom together, if the above condition is satisfied. Also, since \(t=\sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}}-n\), so we must have \(t \ge 0\)
\(\Rightarrow \sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}}-n \ge 0\)
\(\Rightarrow n \le \sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}}\)
So the limiting value of \(n\) is \(n_{MAX}=\sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}}\).
questions.hint: Consider the time taken by the first stone to reach the bottom.  The second stone is projected 'n' seconds later.  For them to reach together, the second stone must cover the same distance 'h' in a time less than that of the first stone by 'n' seconds.  Use the equations of motion to relate the quantities.
methodOfSolving: Calculate the time taken for the first stone to fall.
Determine the time taken for the second stone to fall, considering the delay.
Apply the equations of motion to relate h, u, g, and n.
Consider the condition for the time for the second stone to be valid (t>=0) to find the limiting value of n

questions.title: Velocity Ratio of Two Particles Meeting Mid-Air
questions.questionText: A particle is dropped from the top of a tower \(h\) m high and at the same moment another particle is projected upwards from the bottom. They meet when the upper one has descended a distance \(\dfrac{h}{n}\). Show that the velocities of the two when they meet are in the ratio \(2:(n-2)\) and that the initial velocity of the particle projected up is \(\sqrt{\dfrac{ngh}{2}}\).
questions.solution:
The situation is shown in figure.
 DIAGRAM[1,160]
Let the two particles meet at A after a time \(t\).
For first particle,
\(\dfrac{h}{n} = \dfrac{1}{2}gt^2\) ...(1)
For second particle,
\(\left(h - \dfrac{h}{n}ight) = ut - \dfrac{1}{2}gt^2\) ...(2)
Adding equations (1) and (2), we get
\(h = ut\)
\(\Rightarrow t = \dfrac{h}{u}\) ...(3)
Substituting the value of \(t\) from equation (3) in equation (1), we get
\(\dfrac{h}{n} = \dfrac{1}{2}g\left(\dfrac{h}{u}ight)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow u^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}ngh\)
\(\Rightarrow u = \sqrt{\dfrac{ngh}{2}}\) ...(4)
Velocity \(v_1\) of first particle at A is given by
\(v_1^2 = u_1^2 + 2g\left(\dfrac{h}{n}ight) = 0 + 2g\left(\dfrac{h}{n}ight)\) ...(5)
Velocity \(v_2\) of second particle at A is given by
\(v_2^2 = u^2 - 2g\left(h - \dfrac{h}{n}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow v_2^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}ngh - 2gh\left(1 - \dfrac{1}{n}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow v_2^2 = gh\left[\dfrac{n}{2} - 2\left(1 - \dfrac{1}{n}ight)ight]\)
\(\Rightarrow v_2^2 = gh\left[\dfrac{n}{2}-2+\dfrac{2}{n}ight] = gh\left[\dfrac{n^2-4n+4}{2n}ight]\)
\(\Rightarrow v_2^2 = gh\dfrac{(n-2)^2}{2n}\) ...(6)
Dividing equation (5) by equation (6), we get
\(\dfrac{v_1^2}{v_2^2} = \dfrac{\dfrac{2gh}{n}}{gh\dfrac{(n-2)^2}{2n}} = \dfrac{4gh}{gh(n-2)^2}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{v_1}{v_2} = \dfrac{2}{n-2}\)
questions.hint: Use the equations of motion for both particles, considering the distance traveled by each when they meet.  The sum of the distances traveled by both particles is equal to the total height 'h'.
methodOfSolving: Write the equations of motion for both particles.
Relate the distances traveled by each particle to the total height h.
Solve for the time 't' when they meet.
Calculate the velocities of each particle at time 't'.
Find the ratio of the velocities.

questions.title: Maximum Height of Vertically Projected Particle
questions.questionText: A particle is projected vertically upwards from the ground at time \(t=0\) and reaches a height \(h\) at \(t=T\). Show that the greatest height of the particle is \(\dfrac{(gT^2+2h)^2}{8gT^2}\).
questions.solution:
Let \(u\) be the velocity of projection of the particle. Then
\(h = uT - \dfrac{1}{2}gT^2\)
\(\Rightarrow uT = h + \dfrac{1}{2}gT^2\)
\(\Rightarrow u = \dfrac{h}{T} + \dfrac{1}{2}gT = \dfrac{2h+gT^2}{2T}\)
If \(H\) be the greatest height reached, then
\(0 = u^2 - 2gH\)
\(\Rightarrow 0 = \left(\dfrac{2h+gT^2}{2T}ight)^2 - 2gH\)
\(\Rightarrow H = \dfrac{(2h+gT^2)^2}{8gT^2}\)
questions.hint: Use the equation of motion to relate the initial velocity 'u', height 'h', time 'T', and acceleration due to gravity 'g'. Then use the relation between maximum height reached, initial velocity, and acceleration due to gravity to find 'H'.
methodOfSolving: Relate the given parameters using equation of motion.
Find initial velocity u using the above relation.
Relate maximum height H, u and g.
Substitute u to find H.

questions.title: Mean Relative Velocity of Particles
questions.questionText: Consider a collection of a large number of particles each with speed \(v\). The direction of velocity is randomly distributed in the collection. What is the magnitude of the relative velocity between a pair of particles averaged over all the pairs in the collection?
questions.solution:
As shown in figure, let \(\vec{v}_1\) and \(\vec{v}_2\) be the velocities of any two particles and \(	heta\) be the angle between them. As each particle has speed \(v\), so
\( |\vec{v}_1| = |\vec{v}_2| = v\)
The magnitude of relative velocity \(\vec{v}_{21}\) of particle 2 with respect to 1 is given by
\(v_{21} = \sqrt{v^2+v^2 - 2(v)(v)\cos	heta} = \sqrt{2v^2(1-\cos	heta)} = \sqrt{2}v\sqrt{(1-\cos	heta)}\)
Since \(1 - \cos	heta = 2\sin^2\left(\dfrac{	heta}{2}ight)\)
\(v_{21} = \sqrt{2}v 	imes \sqrt{2\sin^2\left(\dfrac{	heta}{2}ight) } = 2v\sin\left(\dfrac{	heta}{2}ight)\)
 DIAGRAM[1,200]
As the velocities of the particles are randomly distributed, so \(	heta\) can vary from 0 to \(2\pi\). If \(\langle v_{21} angle\) is the magnitude of the average velocity when averaged over all pairs, then
\(\langle v_{21} angle = \dfrac{\displaystyle\int_0^{2\pi} 2v\sin(\dfrac{	heta}{2}) d	heta}{\displaystyle\int_0^{2\pi} d	heta} = \dfrac{[-4v\cos(\dfrac{	heta}{2})]_0^{2\pi}}{2\pi-0} = \dfrac{2v}{\pi} (\cos\pi - \cos 0)\)
\(\Rightarrow \langle v_{21} angle = \dfrac{2v}{\pi}(-1-1) = \dfrac{4v}{\pi}\)
questions.hint: Consider the relative velocity between two particles with velocities v1 and v2 at an angle θ.  Since the speeds are the same, the magnitude of the velocities is 'v'. Calculate the magnitude of the relative velocity and then average it over all possible angles (0 to 2π).
methodOfSolving: Find the relative velocity between two particles at an angle \(\theta\).
Average the magnitude of the relative velocity over all angles from 0 to \(2\pi\).

questions.title: Closest Distance and Time for Two Moving Particles
questions.questionText: The distance between two moving particles \(P\) and \(Q\) at any time is \(a\). If \(v_r\) be their relative velocity and if \(u\) and \(v\) be the components of \(v_r\) along and perpendicular to \(PQ\), then find \n(i) their closest distance and \n(ii) the time that elapses before they arrive at their nearest distance.
questions.solution:
METHOD I
Assuming \(P\) to be at rest, particle \(Q\) is moving with velocity \(v_r\) in the direction shown in figure. 
 DIAGRAM[1,200]
 Components of \(v_r\) along and perpendicular to PQ are \(u\) and \(v\) respectively. In the figure \(\sin\alpha = \dfrac{u}{v_r} \), \(\cos\alpha = \dfrac{v}{v_r} \).
(i) The closest distance between the particles is PR.
So, \(s_{min} = PR = PQ\cos\alpha = (a)\left(\dfrac{v}{v_r}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow s_{min} = \dfrac{av}{v_r}\)
(ii) Time after which they arrive at their nearest distance is
\(t = \dfrac{QR}{v_r} = (PQ)\dfrac{\sin\alpha}{v_r} = (a)\left(\dfrac{\dfrac{u}{v_r}}{v_r}ight) = \dfrac{au}{v_r^2}\)
METHOD II
In time \(t\), particle P will travel a distance \(PR = ut\) relative to Q along \(PQ\) and a distance \(RS = vt\) perpendicular to \(PQ\). \(S\) is the position of \(P\) after time \(t\) relative to \(Q\). The distance \(x\) between them after time \(t\) is given by 
\(x^2 = QR^2 + RS^2 = (a-ut)^2 + v^2t^2\)
\(x^2 = (u^2+v^2)t^2 - 2aut + a^2\)
\(x^2 = v_r^2t^2 - 2aut + a^2 \qquad \{  ecause u^2+v^2 = v_r^2 \}\)
DIAGRAM[2,150]
This can also be written as 
\(x^2 = v_r^2\left[t-\dfrac{au}{v_r^2}ight]^2 + \dfrac{a^2v^2}{v_r^2}\) ...(1)
From equation (1) it is clear that x is minimum at \(t=\dfrac{au}{v_r^2}\) and the minimum value of \(x\) is \(x_{min} = \dfrac{av}{v_r}\)
questions.hint: Resolve the relative velocity into components along and perpendicular to the line joining the particles. The closest distance will be when the component of relative velocity along the line joining them becomes zero.
methodOfSolving: Resolve the relative velocity into components.
For closest distance, consider the component of relative velocity along PQ and equate it to zero.
Find time by dividing displacement by velocity
Alternatively write x as a function of t using QR and RS. Then find the minimum distance.

questions.title: Projectile Motion with Thin Nets
questions.questionText: A particle is projected vertically with a speed of 32.9 \(ms^{-1}\) from a point \(O\). It passes successively through two horizontal thin nets at height 8 m and 16 m respectively, above \(O\). Find (i) the greatest height above \(O\) that the particle attains and (ii) its speed on reaching back to \(O\). Assume that each thin net has a mesh which is broad enough to allow the ball to cross the net but with half the velocity with which the ball enters.
questions.solution:
Take upward direction as positive. In the upward journey, let \(v_1\) be the velocity of the particle just before it enters the net \(A\). Then
\(v_1^2 = u^2 - 2gh = (39.2)^2 - 2 	imes 9.8 	imes 8\)
DIAGRAM[1,200]
Solving it, we get \(v_1 = 37.15\,ms^{-1}\)
Velocity of the particle after crossing the net is \(\dfrac{v_1}{2}\)
So \(v_1 = 18.575\,ms^{-1}\)
Let \(v_2\) be the velocity of the particle just before it enters the net \(B\). Then
\(v_2^2 = (18.575)^2 - 2 	imes 9.8 	imes 8\)
Solving it, we get \(v_2 = 13.72\, ms^{-1}\)
Velocity of the particle after it crosses the net \(B\) is \(\dfrac{v_2}{2} = \dfrac{13.72}{2} = 6.86\,ms^{-1}\)
Let \(h\) be the height reached above the net \(B\) where velocity of particle becomes zero. Then
\((0)^2 = (6.86)^2 - 2 	imes 9.8 	imes h\)
\(\Rightarrow h = 2.4 \,	ext{m}\)
Total height above \(O\) is \(16+2.4 = 18.4 \,	ext{m}\)
In the return journey, the velocity of the particle at the time of reaching net \(B\) is given by
\(v_3^2 = (0)^2 + 2gh\)
\(\Rightarrow v_3 = \sqrt{2gh} = \sqrt{2 	imes 9.8 	imes 2.4}\)
Velocity after crossing net B is \(\dfrac{1}{2}\sqrt{2 	imes 9.8 	imes 2.4}\)
Velocity at net \(A\) is \(\sqrt{\dfrac{2 	imes 9.8 	imes 2.4}{4}+2 	imes 9.8 	imes 8} = \sqrt{9.8 	imes 17.2}\)
\((v_A)_{down} = \sqrt{9.8 	imes 17.2}\)
Velocity after crossing the net A is \(\dfrac{1}{2}\sqrt{9.8 	imes 17.2}\)
Let the velocity at \(O\) be \(v_4\). Then
\(v_4^2 = \dfrac{9.8 	imes 17.2}{4} + 2 	imes 9.8 	imes 8\)
\(\Rightarrow v_4 = 14.1 \,	ext{ms}^{-1}\)
questions.hint: Use the equations of motion and consider the effect of the nets on the velocity of the particle. Remember to analyze both the upward and downward journeys.
methodOfSolving: Analyze the upward motion to the first net.
Account for the velocity change at the first net.
Analyze the motion to the second net.
Account for the velocity change at the second net.
Determine the maximum height.
Analyze the downward motion, accounting for the velocity changes at each net.
Calculate the final velocity at O.

questions.title: Motion of Three Points on a Line
questions.questionText: At the initial moment three points \(A\), \(B\), and \(C\) are on a horizontal straight line at equal distance from one another. Point \(A\) begins to move vertically upwards with a constant velocity \(v\) and point \(C\) vertically downward without any initial velocity at a constant acceleration \(a\). How should the point \(B\) move vertically for all the three points to be constantly on one straight line? The points begin to move simultaneously.
questions.solution:
Initially, at \(t=0\), all the particles are equidistant from each other.

DIAGRAM[1,200]

Let at time \(t\) the particle \(A\) goes to \(A'\), \(B\) goes to \(B'\) and \(C\) goes to \(C'\).
\(AA' = vt\)
\(BB' = u_Bt + \dfrac{1}{2}a_Bt^2\)
\(CC' = \dfrac{1}{2}at^2\)
In similar triangles \(AOA'\), \(BOB'\) and \(COC'\) we have
\(\dfrac{vt}{l-x} = \dfrac{u_Bt+\dfrac{1}{2}a_Bt^2}{x} = \dfrac{\dfrac{1}{2}at^2}{l+x}\) ...(1)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{2v}{at} = \dfrac{l+x}{l-x}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{l-x}{x} = \dfrac{at}{2v}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \left(\dfrac{1}{1+\dfrac{at}{2v}}ight)l\) ...(2)
Put (2) in (1) we get
\(u_Bt + \dfrac{1}{2}a_Bt^2 = \left(\dfrac{v}{2}ight)t + \dfrac{1}{2}\left(\dfrac{a}{2}ight)t^2\)
i.e., \(u_B = \dfrac{v}{2}\) and \(a_B = \dfrac{a}{2}\)
Hence, for all the particles to be on one straight line, the particle at B must move with an initial velocity \(\dfrac{v}{2}\) in the upward direction and an acceleration \(\dfrac{a}{2}\) in the downward direction.
questions.hint: Consider the positions of A, B, and C at any time t. Since A, B, and C always lie on a straight line, the slopes of the lines joining them must be equal. Use similar triangles and the equations of motion.
methodOfSolving: Write the displacement equations for A, B, and C.
Use similar triangles AOA', BOB', and COC'.
Equate the ratios of the vertical and horizontal displacements.
Solve the resulting equations for the velocity and acceleration of B.

questions.title: Height of a Building from Ball Drop
questions.questionText: A steel ball is dropped from a roof of a building. An observer standing in front of a window 1m high notes that the ball takes 0.1 sec to fall from the top to the bottom of the window. The ball continues to fall and makes a complete elastic collision with the ground, so that it rebounds with the same velocity with which it strikes the ground. The ball reappears at the bottom of the window 2 second after passing the bottom of the window on the way down, find the height of the building (Take \(g = 10\,ms^{-2}\)).
questions.solution:
Let \(v_1\) and \(v_2\) be the velocities of a ball at the top and bottom of the windows respectively. Let \(h_1\) be the height of the building above the top of the window and \(h_2\) that below the bottom of window, then
Height of Building = \(h_1\) + Height of Window + \(h_2\)
\(=\) Height of Building = \((h_1+1+h_2)\) m
For the path between the top and bottom of window,
We have \(h=1\) m , \(t=0.1\) s \(a = g = 10 \,	ext{ms}^{-2}\)
\(h = v_1t + \dfrac{1}{2}gt^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 1 = v_1 	imes 0.1 + \dfrac{1}{2} 	imes (10) 	imes (0.1)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow v_1 = 9.5 \,	ext{ms}^{-1}\)
Also from equation \(v = u + at\)
\(\Rightarrow v_2 = v_1 + 10 	imes 0.1 = 9.5+1 = 10.5 \,	ext{ms}^{-1}\)
Also, from equation of motion \(v^2-u^2 = 2as\),
\(\Rightarrow v_1^2 = 0 + 2 	imes 10 	imes h_1\)
\(\Rightarrow h_1 = \dfrac{v_1^2}{2 	imes 10} = \dfrac{(9.5)^2}{2 	imes 10} = 4.51 \,	ext{m}\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Path above top of Window \(= 4.51 \,	ext{m}\)
For the path below the bottom of window, the ball reappears at the bottom of window to second after passing the bottom on its way down. Hence, it takes a time of 1 s to fall from the bottom of window to the ground and rebounds to the same height in a further time of 1 s.
\(h_2 = v_2t + \dfrac{1}{2}gt^2\)
\(\Rightarrow h_2 = 10.5 	imes 1 + \dfrac{1}{2} 	imes 10 	imes 1^2\)
\(\Rightarrow h_2 = 10.5+5 = 15.5 \,	ext{m}\)
\(\Rightarrow\) Path below the bottom of window \(= 15.5 \,	ext{m}\)
Hence, Height of the Building is \(H = 4.51+1+15.5\)
\(H = 21.01 \,	ext{m}\)
questions.hint: Use the equations of motion to determine the velocities at the top and bottom of the window. Analyze the motion of the ball before it reaches the window, between the top and bottom of the window, and after it rebounds from the ground.
methodOfSolving: Calculate v1 and v2, the velocities at the top and bottom of the window respectively.
Calculate h1, the height above the top of the window.
Calculate h2, the height below the bottom of the window.
Add h1, h2, and the window height to find the total height of the building.

questions.title: Average Velocities and Uniform Acceleration
questions.questionText: A particle moves with uniform acceleration \(a\). If \(v_1\), \(v_2\) and \(v_3\) be the average velocities in three successive intervals of time \(t_1\), \(t_2\) and \(t_3\) respectively, then find the value of \(\dfrac{(v_1-v_2)(t_3+t_2)}{(v_2-v_3)(t_2+t_1)}\).
questions.solution:
For OB
\(a = \dfrac{v_2-v_1}{(t_2+t_1)-0} = \dfrac{v_2-v_1}{t_2+t_1}\) ...(1)

DIAGRAM[1,300]

For AC
\(a = \dfrac{v_3-v_2}{(t_3+t_2+t_1)-t_1} = \dfrac{v_3-v_2}{t_3+t_2}\) ...(2)
From (1) and (2), equating the values of \(a\), we get
\(\left(\dfrac{v_1-v_2}{v_2-v_3}ight)\left(\dfrac{t_3+t_2}{t_2+t_1}ight) = 1\)
questions.hint: Use the definition of average velocity and the equations of motion for uniformly accelerated motion. Consider two intervals for average velocities and equate the acceleration in both cases.
methodOfSolving: Express acceleration in terms of average velocities for two separate intervals, say OB and AC.
Equate the expressions for acceleration and solve for the required ratio.

questions.title: Maximum Angular Velocity of Two Moving Points
questions.questionText: Two points are moving with uniform velocities \(u\) and \(v\) along the perpendicular axes, \(OX\) and \(OY\). The motion is directed toward \(O\), the origin. When \(t=0\), they are at a distance \(a\) and \(b\) respectively from \(O\). At what time \(t\) is the angular velocity of the line joining them greatest?
questions.solution:
At \(t=0\), the particles are at A and B respectively.
Let at time \(t\), the particles are at P and Q respectively.

DIAGRAM[1,200]

From figure, \(OP = a - ut\) and \(OQ = b - vt\) ...(1)
Let \(	heta\) be the angle which the line \(PQ\) makes with the direction \(OX\) at time \(t\). From \(	riangle OQP\),
\(	an(\pi - 	heta) = \dfrac{OQ}{OP} = \dfrac{b-vt}{a-ut}\)
\(\Rightarrow -	an	heta = \dfrac{b-vt}{a-ut}\)
\(\Rightarrow 	an	heta = \dfrac{vt-b}{ut-a}\)
\(\Rightarrow 	heta = 	an^{-1}\left(\dfrac{vt-b}{ut-a}ight)\) ...(3)
Differentiating equation (3), we get
\(\dfrac{d	heta}{dt} = \dfrac{1}{1+\left(\dfrac{vt-b}{ut-a}ight)^2} 	imes \dfrac{(ut-a)(v)-(vt-b)(u)}{(ut-a)^2}\)
\(\Rightarrow \omega = \dfrac{d	heta}{dt} = \dfrac{av-bu}{(a-ut)^2+(b-vt)^2}\)
Here, \(\omega\) will be maximum when denominator is minimum, because numerator is constant.
Let, \((Den)^2 = S = (a-ut)^2 + (b-vt)^2\). For it to be MINIMUM, we have
\(\dfrac{dS}{dt} = 2(a-ut)(-u) + 2(b-vt)(-v) = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow t = \dfrac{au+bv}{u^2+v^2}\)
It can be seen that \(\dfrac{d^2S}{dt^2}>0\). Hence, \(S\) is minimum, or \(\omega\) is maximum, at \(t=\dfrac{au+bv}{u^2+v^2}\)
questions.hint: Find the angle \(\theta\) that the line joining the points makes with the x-axis at any time \(t\). Differentiate \(\theta\) with respect to \(t\) to find the angular velocity \(\omega\). Find the condition for \(\omega\) to be maximum.
methodOfSolving: Express the positions of the points at time \(t\).
Find \(\tan(\theta)\) using the positions of the points.
Differentiate \(\theta\) with respect to time to find \(\omega\).
Find the time at which \(\omega\) is maximum by minimizing the denominator of the expression for \(\omega\).

questions.title: Distance Between Particles with Perpendicular Velocities
questions.questionText: Two particles move in a uniform gravitational field with an acceleration \(g\). At the initial moment the particles were located at one point and moved with velocities \(u_1 = 3 \,\text{ms}^{-1}\) and \(u_2 = 4 \,\text{ms}^{-1}\) horizontally in opposite directions. Find the distance between the particles when their velocity vectors become mutually perpendicular.
questions.solution:
Let the velocities of the particles be at right angles to each other at time \(t\). Then
\(\vec{v}_1 = u_1\hat{i} + gt\hat{j}\)
\(\vec{v}_2 = u_2\hat{i} + gt\hat{j}\)
\(\vec{v}_2 = -4\hat{i} + gt\hat{j}\)

DIAGRAM[1,250]

For velocities to be mutually perpendicular, we have
\(\vec{v}_1 . \vec{v}_2 = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow -12 + g^2t^2 = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow t = \sqrt{\dfrac{12}{g^2}} = \dfrac{2\sqrt{3}}{g} \,	ext{s} = \dfrac{2\sqrt{3}}{8} \,	ext{s}\)
Separation between the particles is
\(x = (u_1+u_2)t = 7 	imes \dfrac{2\sqrt{3}}{8}\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \dfrac{14\sqrt{3}}{8} \,	ext{m}\)
questions.hint: Consider the horizontal and vertical components of the velocities of the particles.  The dot product of two perpendicular vectors is zero.
methodOfSolving: Write the velocity vectors of the particles at any time \(t\).
Apply the condition for perpendicularity using the dot product of the velocity vectors.
Solve for the time \(t\).
Calculate the distance between the particles at time \(t\).

questions.title: Horizontal Distance Between Two Projectiles
questions.questionText: From a point at a height \(h\) above the horizontal ground a particle \(A\) is projected with a velocity \(u\) in an upward direction making an angle \(\alpha\) with the horizon. Another particle \(B\) is projected with the same velocity \(u\) but in a downward direction exactly opposite to \(A\). The two particles will strike the ground at a distance \(x\) apart. Find \(x\).\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
Taking upward direction as positive. Then
For particle A
Vertical displacement = \(-h\) (downwards)
Vertical component of velocity = \(u\sin\alpha\) (upwards)
and Acceleration = \(-g\) (downwards)
\(\Rightarrow -h = (u\sin\alpha)t_1 - \dfrac{1}{2}gt_1^2\)
\(\Rightarrow gt_1^2 - 2(u\sin\alpha)t_1 - 2h = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow gt_1^2 - 2u\sin\alpha t_1 - 2h = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow t_1 = \dfrac{2u\sin\alpha \pm \sqrt{4u^2\sin^2\alpha + 8gh}}{g} = \dfrac{u\sin\alpha \pm \sqrt{u^2\sin^2\alpha+2gh}}{g}\)
If we use negative sign, then time \(t_1\) will be negative. So, dropping the negative sign, we get
\(t_1 = \dfrac{u\sin\alpha + \sqrt{u^2\sin^2\alpha + 2gh}}{g}\)
For particle B
We have Vertical Displacement = \(-h\) (downwards)
Vertical Component of Velocity = \(-u\sin\alpha\) (downwards) and Acceleration = \(-g\) (downwards)
\(\Rightarrow -h = -(u\sin\alpha)t_2 - \dfrac{1}{2}gt_2^2\)
\(\Rightarrow h = (u\sin\alpha)t_2 + \dfrac{1}{2}gt_2^2\)
\(\Rightarrow gt_2^2 + 2(u\sin\alpha)t_2 - 2h = 0\)
Solving, we get
\(\Rightarrow t_2 = \dfrac{-u\sin\alpha + \sqrt{u^2\sin^2\alpha + 2gh}}{g}\)
\(t_2\) is the time taken by the particle to reach the ground
Now, distance travelled \(x = x_1 - (-x_2) = x_1 + x_2\)
\(\Rightarrow x = (u\cos\alpha)t_1 + (u\cos\alpha)t_2\)
\(\Rightarrow x = u\cos\alpha(t_1+t_2)\)
\(\Rightarrow x = u\cos\alpha\left(\dfrac{2\sqrt{u^2\sin^2\alpha+2gh}}{g}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow x = \dfrac{2u\cos\alpha}{g}\sqrt{u^2\sin^2\alpha+2gh}\)
questions.hint: Analyze the motion of particles \(A\) and \(B\) separately. Calculate the time taken by each particle to reach the ground. The horizontal distance traveled by each particle is the product of its horizontal velocity component and the time of flight. The difference in these distances is \(x\).
methodOfSolving: Write the equations of motion for vertical displacement of particle \(A\).
Solve for the time of flight \(t_1\) of particle \(A\).
Write the equations of motion for vertical displacement of particle \(B\).
Solve for the time of flight \(t_2\) of particle \(B\).
Calculate the horizontal distance traveled by each particle.
Find the difference between the horizontal distances to get \(x\).

questions.title: Angle of Projection from Velocity at Greatest and Half Height
questions.questionText: The velocity of a projectile when it is at the greatest height is \(\dfrac{2}{\sqrt{5}}\) times its velocity when it is at half of its greatest height. Determine its angle of projection.
questions.solution:
Let the particle be projected with velocity \(u\) at an angle \(	heta\) with the horizontal. Horizontal component of its velocity at all heights will be \(u\cos	heta\). At the greatest height, the vertical component of velocity is zero, so the resultant velocity is \(v_1 = u\cos	heta\). At half the greatest height during upward motion, we have \(v_y = \sqrt{u_y^2 - 2ay}\)
\(\Rightarrow v_y = \sqrt{u^2\sin^2	heta - 2(g)\left(\dfrac{u^2\sin^2	heta}{4g}ight)} = \dfrac{u\sin	heta}{\sqrt{2}}\)
Hence, resultant velocity at half of the greatest height is \(v_2 = \sqrt{v_x^2+v_y^2} = \sqrt{u^2\cos^2	heta + \dfrac{u^2\sin^2	heta}{2}}\)
Since, it is given that \(\dfrac{v_1}{v_2} = \dfrac{2}{\sqrt{5}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{v_1^2}{v_2^2} = \dfrac{u^2\cos^2	heta}{u^2\cos^2	heta+\dfrac{u^2\sin^2	heta}{2}} = \dfrac{2}{5}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{1}{1+\dfrac{1}{2}	an^2	heta} = \dfrac{2}{5}\)
\(\Rightarrow 1+\dfrac{1}{2}	an^2	heta = \dfrac{5}{2}\)
\(\Rightarrow 2+	an^2	heta=5\)
\(\Rightarrow 	an^2	heta = 3\)
\(\Rightarrow 	heta=60^\circ\)
questions.hint: The velocity at the greatest height is the horizontal component of the initial velocity. Find the vertical component of the velocity at half the maximum height using the equations of motion. Calculate the resultant velocity at half the maximum height. Use the given ratio to determine the angle of projection.
methodOfSolving: Write the velocity at the greatest height \(v_1\).
Calculate the vertical and horizontal components of velocity at half the maximum height.
Calculate the resultant velocity \(v_2\) at half the maximum height.
Use the given ratio \(\dfrac{v_1}{v_2}\) to find the angle of projection \(\theta\).

questions.title: Minimum Speed for Projectile to Pass Through a Point
questions.questionText: With what minimum speed must a particle be projected from origin so that it is able to pass through a given point \(P(x, y)\)? Assume \(x\) and \(y\) axes along the horizontal and vertically upward directions respectively, with origin at the point of projection.
questions.solution:
Let \(u\) and \(	heta\) be the velocity and angle of projection respectively.
For the projectile to pass through \(P(x,y)\)
\(y = x	an	heta - \dfrac{gx^2}{2u^2}(1+	an^2	heta)\)
\(\Rightarrow gx^2	an^2	heta - 2xu^2	an	heta + (gx^2+2yu^2) = 0\)
The projectile will pass through \(P(x,y)\) if this equation (quadratic in \(	an	heta\)) gives some real value of \(	heta\), i.e., its discriminant \(\ge 0\).
\(4x^2u^4 - 4gx^2(gx^2+2yu^2) \ge 0\)
\(u^4 - 2gyu^2 - g^2x^2 \ge 0\)
\(u^4 - 2gyu^2 + g^2y^2 \ge g^2x^2 + g^2y^2\)
\((u^2-gy)^2 \ge (x^2+y^2)g^2\)
\(\Rightarrow u \ge \sqrt{gy+g\sqrt{x^2+y^2}}\)
So, the minimum value of \(u\) is \(u_{MIN} = \sqrt{gy+g\sqrt{x^2+y^2}}\).
questions.hint: Use the equation of trajectory of a projectile.  For the particle to pass through \(P(x,y)\), the equation of the trajectory must be satisfied. This leads to a quadratic equation in \(\tan(\theta)\). For the equation to have real solutions, its discriminant must be greater than or equal to zero.
methodOfSolving: Substitute the coordinates \((x,y)\) into the equation of trajectory.
Form a quadratic equation in \(\tan(\theta)\).
Apply the condition that the discriminant of the quadratic must be greater than or equal to zero to find the minimum speed \(u\).

questions.title: Height of a Hill from Projectile Motion
questions.questionText: Two shots are projected from a gun at the top of a hill with the same velocity \(u\) at angles of projection \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) respectively. If the shots strike the horizontal ground through the foot of the hill at the same point, find the height \(h\) of the hill above the plane.
questions.solution:
Let \(R\) be the horizontal range for both. Taking the point of projection as origin, the point struck is \((R, h)\). This point satisfies the equations of both the trajectories.
\(-h = R	an\alpha - \dfrac{1}{2}g\dfrac{R^2}{u^2\cos^2\alpha}\) ...(1)
and \(-h = R	an eta - \dfrac{1}{2}g\dfrac{R^2}{u^2\cos^2 eta}\) ...(2)
From these equations, we have
\(R	an\alpha - \dfrac{1}{2}g\dfrac{R^2}{u^2\cos^2\alpha} = R	an eta - \dfrac{1}{2}g\dfrac{R^2}{u^2\cos^2 eta}\)
\(\Rightarrow R(	an\alpha - 	an eta) = \dfrac{1}{2}g\dfrac{R^2}{u^2}\left(\dfrac{1}{\cos^2\alpha} - \dfrac{1}{\cos^2 eta}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{2u^2}{g}(	an\alpha - 	an eta) = R(\sec^2\alpha - \sec^2 eta)\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{2u^2}{g}(	an\alpha-	an eta) = R[(1+	an^2\alpha)-(1+	an^2 eta)]\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{2u^2}{gR}(	an\alpha - 	an eta) = 	an^2\alpha - 	an^2 eta\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{2u^2}{gR} = (	an\alpha + 	an eta)\) ...(3)
\(\Rightarrow R = \dfrac{2u^2}{g(	an\alpha + 	an eta)}\)
Substituting the value of R in equation (1), we get
\(h = \dfrac{2u^2}{g(	an\alpha + 	an eta)}\left(\dfrac{1}{2} \dfrac{g}{u^2\cos^2\alpha} \dfrac{2u^2}{g(	an\alpha+	an eta)} - 	an\alphaight)\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \dfrac{1}{(	an\alpha + 	an eta)}\left(\dfrac{\sec^2\alpha}{(	an\alpha+	an eta)}-	an\alphaight)\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \dfrac{2u^2}{g(	an\alpha+	an eta)^2}(1-	an\alpha	an eta)\)
questions.hint: Write the equation of trajectory for both shots. Since both shots land at the same point on the ground, their ranges are equal. Substitute the range \(R\) and height \(-h\) (taking the top of the hill as the origin) into both trajectory equations.
methodOfSolving: Write the equation of the trajectory for each angle of projection.
Set the ranges equal to \(R\) and the vertical displacement equal to \(-h\).
Eliminate \(R\) from the two equations to find an expression for \(h\).

questions.title: Velocity of Particle at Origin
questions.questionText: A particle moves in the plane \(x-y\) with constant acceleration \(a\) directed along negative \(y\)-axis. The equation of motion of particle has the form \(y = Ax - Bx^2\). \(A\) and \(B\) are positive constants. Find the velocity of the particle at the origin of the co-ordinates.
questions.solution:
Comparing the above given equation with the equation of the oblique projectile moving under the influence of the acceleration field \(\vec{a}\).
\(\Rightarrow y = x	an	heta - \dfrac{ax^2}{2u^2\cos^2	heta}\) {Equation for Oblique Projectile}
\(\Rightarrow A = 	an	heta\) and \(B = \dfrac{a}{2u^2\cos^2	heta}\)
\(\Rightarrow A = 	an	heta\) and \(\sec^2	heta = \dfrac{2u^2B}{a}\) ...(1)
We know that \(\sec^2	heta - 	an^2	heta = 1\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{2u^2B}{a} - A^2 = 1\) \(\qquad\) {using (1)}
\(\Rightarrow u = \sqrt{(1+A^2)\dfrac{a}{2B}}\)
questions.hint: Compare the given equation of motion with the equation of trajectory of a projectile. Relate the constants \(A\) and \(B\) to the angle of projection and initial velocity.
methodOfSolving: Compare the given equation with the equation of trajectory of a projectile: \(y = x\tan\theta - \dfrac{gx^2}{2u^2\cos^2\theta}\).
Relate \(A\) and \(B\) with \(\tan\theta\) and initial velocity \(u\).
Use trigonometric identity \(\sec^2\theta - \tan^2\theta = 1\) to solve for \(u\).

questions.title: Muzzle Speed of a Bullet
questions.questionText: A horizontal projectile is fired from a tower \(B\). The shooter fires his gun from point \(A\) at an angle of \(30^\circ\). Determine the muzzle speed of the bullet if it hits the projectile at \(C\). \nDIAGRAM[1,200]\n
questions.solution:
Let us take the \(x-y\) coordinate system so that its origin coincides with point \(A\).

\(x\)-Motion: Here, \(x = 20-0 = 20 \,	ext{m}\)
Since \(x = u_xt + \dfrac{1}{2}a_xt^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 20 = (v_A\cos 30^\circ)t\) ...(1)
\(y\)-Motion: Here, \(y = 10-1.8 = 8.2 \,	ext{m}\) \((v_A)_y = v_A\sin 30^\circ\) and \(a_y = -g = -9.8 \,	ext{ms}^{-2}\)
Since \(y = u_yt + \dfrac{1}{2}a_yt^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 8.2 = (v_A\sin 30^\circ)t + \dfrac{1}{2}(-9.8)(t)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 8.2 = \left(\dfrac{20\sin 30^\circ}{\cos 30^\circ}ight) - 4.9t^2\) \(\left\{  ecause t = \dfrac{20}{v_A\cos(30^\circ)} ight\}\)
Thus, \(8.2 = \dfrac{20\sin30^\circ}{\cos30^\circ}-4.9t^2\)
\(\Rightarrow t = 0.83 \,	ext{s}\)
So that \(v_A = \dfrac{20}{\cos 30^\circ (0.83)} = 28 \,	ext{ms}^{-1}\)
questions.hint: Use the equations of motion in both horizontal and vertical directions.  The time taken for the bullet to travel horizontally to point C must be the same as the time taken for it to travel vertically to point C.
methodOfSolving: Set up a coordinate system with origin at A.
Write the equations of motion in x and y directions.
Solve for time t and muzzle speed v_A

questions.title: Angle of Projection from Elevations
questions.questionText: A particle is projected at an angle of elevation \(\alpha\) and after \(t\) second it appears to have an elevation of \(\beta\) as seen from the point of projection. Find the initial velocity of projection.
questions.solution:
\(	an eta = \dfrac{y}{x} = \dfrac{(u\sin\alpha)t - \dfrac{1}{2}gt^2}{(u\cos\alpha)t}\)
\(\Rightarrow x(u\sin\alpha - \cos\alpha 	an eta) = \dfrac{gt}{2}\)
\(\Rightarrow u = \dfrac{gt}{2(\sin\alpha - \cos\alpha	an eta)} = \dfrac{gt\cos eta}{2\sin(\alpha- eta)}\)

DIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.hint: Use the equation of trajectory and express the horizontal and vertical coordinates of the projectile in terms of initial velocity, angle of projection, and time.  Relate the angle of elevation \(\beta\) to the coordinates \(x\) and \(y\) at time \(t\).
methodOfSolving: Write \(\tan\beta\) in terms of \(x\) and \(y\) coordinates at time \(t\).
Express \(x\) and \(y\) in terms of initial velocity, angle of projection, and time.
Solve for the initial velocity \(u\).

questions.title: Angle between Velocity Vectors
questions.questionText: A particle is projected with a velocity u at an angle \(\alpha\) to the horizontal, in a vertical plane. At time \(t\), it is moving in a direction making an angle \(\beta\) with the horizontal. Prove that \(\tan\beta = \dfrac{u\sin\alpha-gt}{u\cos\alpha}\).
questions.solution:
Since \(	an eta = \dfrac{u\sin\alpha-gt}{u\cos\alpha}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{\sin eta}{\cos eta} = \dfrac{u\sin\alpha - gt}{u\cos\alpha}\)
\(\Rightarrow u\sin eta\cos\alpha = u\sin\alpha\cos eta - gt\cos eta\)
\(\Rightarrow u(\sin\alpha\cos eta - \sin eta\cos\alpha) = gt\cos eta\)
\(\Rightarrow u\sin(\alpha -  eta) = gt\cos eta\)
questions.hint: Consider the horizontal and vertical components of the velocity at time \(t\). The tangent of the angle \(\beta\) is the ratio of the vertical component to the horizontal component.
methodOfSolving: Find the horizontal and vertical components of velocity at any time \(t\).
Write \(\tan\beta\) as the ratio of vertical to horizontal velocity components.

questions.title: Projectile Motion and Wall Clearance
questions.questionText: A ball is projected so as to just clear two walls, the first of height \(b\) at a distance \(a\) from the point of projection and the second of height \(b\) and at a distance \(a\) from point of projection.  Find the range on the horizontal plane \(R\). Also show that the angle of projection is given by \(\tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{a^2+ab+b^2}{ab}\right)\).
questions.solution:
Since \(y = x	an	heta - \dfrac{gx^2}{2u^2\cos^2	heta} = x	an	heta\left(1-\dfrac{x}{R}ight)\)
For the particle clearing the wall of height \(b\) at distance \(a\), we have \(x=a\), \(y=b\). So
\(b = a	an	heta\left(1-\dfrac{a}{R}ight)\) ...(1)

DIAGRAM[1,200]

For the particle clearing the wall of height \(a\) at a distance \(b\), we have \(x=b\), \(y=a\). So
\(a = b	an	heta\left(1 - \dfrac{b}{R}ight)\) ...(2)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{b}{a} = \dfrac{a}{b}\left(\dfrac{R-a}{R-b}ight)\) {Divide (1) by (2)}
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{b^2}{a^2} = \dfrac{R-a}{R-b}\)
\(\Rightarrow Rb^2 - b^3 = Ra^2 - a^3\)
\(\Rightarrow R(b^2-a^2) = b^3 - a^3\)
\(\Rightarrow R = \dfrac{b^3 - a^3}{b^2-a^2} = \dfrac{(a^2+ab+b^2)(b-a)}{(a+b)(b-a)}\)
\(\Rightarrow R = \dfrac{a^2+ab+b^2}{a+b}\) ...(3)
Substituting (3) in (1) or (2), we get
\(b = a	an	heta\left(1-\dfrac{a}{\dfrac{a^2+ab+b^2}{a+b}}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow b = a	an	heta\left(\dfrac{b^2+ab+a^2-a^2-ab}{a^2+ab+b^2}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow 	an	heta = \dfrac{a^2+ab+b^2}{ab}\)
\(\Rightarrow 	heta = 	an^{-1}\left(\dfrac{a^2+ab+b^2}{ab}ight)\)
questions.hint: Use the equation of trajectory for a projectile. Since the ball just clears both walls, the coordinates of the top of each wall must satisfy the equation of trajectory.
methodOfSolving: Write the equation of trajectory: \(y = x\tan\theta - \dfrac{gx^2}{2u^2\cos^2\theta}\).
Substitute the coordinates of the top of each wall into the trajectory equation.
Solve the resulting equations to find the range R and the angle of projection \(\theta\).

questions.title: Minimum Initial Velocity for Projectile
questions.questionText: The angular elevation of an enemy's position on a hill \(h\) m high is \(\beta\). Show that, in order to shell it, the minimum initial velocity of the projectile must be \(\sqrt{gh(1+\csc\beta)}\).
questions.solution:
Coordinates of the point P are \((h\cot eta, h)\).
Substituting in \(y = x	an	heta - \dfrac{gx^2}{2u^2}(1+	an^2	heta)\)

DIAGRAM[1,200]

\(\Rightarrow h = (h\cot eta)	an	heta - \dfrac{gh^2\cot^2 eta}{2u^2}(1+	an^2	heta)\)
This is quadratic in \(	an	heta\). For \(	heta\) to be real discriminant of this equation ≥0, which gives
\(u \ge \sqrt{gh(1+\csc eta)}\)
\(\Rightarrow u_{MIN} = \sqrt{gh(1+\csc eta)}\)
questions.hint: Use the trajectory equation for a projectile. The enemy's position \((x, y)\) must satisfy this equation.  For the projectile to reach the enemy's position, the trajectory equation must have a real solution for the angle of projection.
methodOfSolving: Determine the coordinates of the enemy's position.
Substitute the coordinates into the trajectory equation.
Obtain a quadratic equation in \(\tan\theta\).
Apply the condition that the discriminant of the quadratic must be greater than or equal to zero to find the minimum velocity \(u\).

questions.title: Projectile from a Moving Platform
questions.questionText: A gun is fired from a moving platform, and ranges of the shot are observed to be \(R_1\) and \(R_2\) when the platform is moving forward and backward respectively with velocity \(v\). Find the elevation of the gun in terms of the given quantities.
questions.solution:
Let \(u\) be the velocity of projection in both the cases. In the first case, we have
\(T_1 = \dfrac{2u\sin\alpha}{g}\) and \(T_1 = \dfrac{R_1}{u\cos\alpha + v}\) ...(1)
\(\Rightarrow R_1 = \dfrac{2u^2\sin\alpha\cos\alpha + 2uv\sin\alpha}{g}\) ...(2)
In the second case, we have
\(T_2 = \dfrac{2u\sin\alpha}{g} = T_1\) ...(3)
\(R_2 = \dfrac{2u^2\sin\alpha\cos\alpha - 2uv\sin\alpha}{g}\) ...(4)
From (2) and (4), we get
\(\dfrac{R_1 - R_2}{R_1} = \dfrac{4uv\sin\alpha}{g}\) ...(5)
and \(\dfrac{R_1}{R_2} = \dfrac{u\cos\alpha + v}{u\cos\alpha - v}\)
\(\Rightarrow u = \dfrac{v(R_1+R_2)}{\cos\alpha(R_1-R_2)}\) ...(6)
From equations (5) and (6), we have
\(	an\alpha = \dfrac{g}{4v^2} (R_1-R_2)(R_1+R_2)\)
questions.hint: Consider the horizontal velocity of the projectile relative to the ground in both cases (platform moving forward and backward). The time of flight remains the same in both cases.
methodOfSolving: Write the expressions for the range and time of flight in both cases.
The time of flight is the same in both cases, use this to relate R1 and R2.
Solve for the angle of elevation \(\alpha\).

questions.title: Ratio of Times of Flight for Two Projectiles
questions.questionText: Two bodies are projected from the same point with equal speeds in such directions that they both strike the same point on a plane whose inclination is \(\beta\). If \(\alpha\) be the angle of projection of the first body with the horizontal show that the ratio of their times of flight is \(\dfrac{\sin(\alpha-\beta)}{\cos\alpha}\).
questions.solution:
For the first body, we have
\(R = \dfrac{u^2}{g\cos^2 eta}[\sin(2\alpha- eta)-\sin eta]\)
Let \(\alpha'\) be the angle of projection of the second body. Since, range of both the bodies is same. Therefore,
\(\sin(2\alpha- eta) = \sin(2\alpha' -  eta)\)
\(\Rightarrow 2\alpha' -  eta = \pi - (2\alpha -  eta)\)

DIAGRAM[1,200]

\(\Rightarrow \alpha' = \dfrac{\pi}{2} - (\alpha- eta)\)
Now, \(T = \dfrac{2u\sin(\alpha- eta)}{g\cos eta}\) and \(T' = \dfrac{2u\sin(\alpha'- eta)}{g\cos eta}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{T}{T'} = \dfrac{\sin(\alpha- eta)}{\sin(\alpha' -  eta)} = \dfrac{\sin(\alpha- eta)}{\sin(\dfrac{\pi}{2}-(\alpha- eta)- eta)}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{T}{T'} = \dfrac{\sin(\alpha- eta)}{\sin(\dfrac{\pi}{2}-\alpha)} = \dfrac{\sin(\alpha- eta)}{\cos\alpha}\)
questions.hint: Use the range equation for a projectile on an inclined plane. Since the ranges are equal, relate the two angles of projection. Then, use the time of flight formula for a projectile on an inclined plane to find the ratio of the times of flight.
methodOfSolving: Write the range equation \(R\) on an inclined plane.
Equate the ranges for both projectiles to find a relation between the angles \(\alpha\) and \(\alpha'\).
Write the time of flight formula \(T\) on an inclined plane.
Find the ratio \(T/T'\) using the relation between \(\alpha\) and \(\alpha'\).

questions.title: Velocity of a Carriage from Dust Particle Motion
questions.questionText: The radii of the front and rear wheels of a carriage are \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\) is the distance between the axle centres. A particle of dust driven from the highest point of the rear wheel is observed to alight on the highest point of the front wheel. Find the velocity of the carriage.\nDIAGRAM[1,300]\n
questions.solution:
Velocity of projection of the dust particle from the top of the wheel is \(2v\) horizontally.

DIAGRAM[1,300]

For horizontal projectile \(y = \dfrac{gx^2}{2v^2}\)
\(2b-2a = g\left[\dfrac{c^2 - (b-a)^2}{2v^2}ight]\)
\(\Rightarrow v = \sqrt{\dfrac{g(c+b-a)(c-b+a)}{4(b-a)}}\)
questions.hint: The dust particle acts as a horizontal projectile with an initial velocity equal to twice the velocity of the carriage. Use the equation of trajectory for a horizontal projectile. The vertical displacement of the dust particle is the difference in the radii of the wheels, and the horizontal displacement is the distance between the axle centers.
methodOfSolving: Note that the initial velocity of dust is \(2v\) horizontally.
Write the equation for projectile motion: \(y = \dfrac{gx^2}{2u^2}\)
Substitute \(y = 2b-2a\) and \(x=c\) and \(u=2v\).
Solve for \(v\).

questions.title: Time Interval for Collision of Two Shells
questions.questionText: A canon fires successively two shells with velocity \(u\), the first at an angle \(\theta_1\) and second at an angle \(\theta_2\) with horizontal. Neglecting air drag, find the time interval between firings leading to collision of shells.
questions.solution:
Let the time of flight before collision be \(t\), i.e., let first shell reach \(P(x,y)\) in time \(t\).
Let second shell be fired with a delay say \(\Delta t\). So it falls short of time by \(\Delta t\) and has net time \((t-\Delta t)\) to be at \(P\).
For First shell \(x=(u\cos	heta_1)t\) ...(1)
For Second shell \(x=(u\cos	heta_2)(t-\Delta t)\) ...(2)
\(\Rightarrow t - \Delta t = \dfrac{x}{u\cos	heta_2} = \dfrac{u\cos	heta_1}{u\cos	heta_2}t\)
\(\Rightarrow \Delta t = t\left(\dfrac{\cos	heta_2 - \cos	heta_1}{\cos	heta_2}ight)\) ...(3)
From (1), \(t=\dfrac{x}{u\cos	heta_1}\)
\(\Rightarrow \Delta t \left(\dfrac{x}{u\cos	heta_1}ight) = \dfrac{\cos	heta_2 - \cos	heta_1}{\cos	heta_2}\)
\(\Rightarrow u\Delta t = \dfrac{x(\cos	heta_2 - \cos	heta_1)}{\cos	heta_1 	imes \cos	heta_2}\) ...(4)
Also, \(y = x	an	heta_1 - \dfrac{gx^2}{2u^2\cos^2	heta_1}\) ...(5)
\(\Rightarrow y = x	an	heta_2 - \dfrac{gx^2}{2u^2\cos^2	heta_2}\) ...(6)
\(\Rightarrow 	an	heta_1 - 	an	heta_2 = \dfrac{gx}{2u^2}\left[\dfrac{1}{\cos^2	heta_1} - \dfrac{1}{\cos^2	heta_2}ight]\) {using (5) & (6)}
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{\sin	heta_1}{\cos	heta_1} - \dfrac{\sin	heta_2}{\cos	heta_2} = \dfrac{gx}{2u^2}\left[\dfrac{\cos^2	heta_2 - \cos^2	heta_1}{\cos^2	heta_2 	imes \cos^2	heta_1}ight]\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{\sin(	heta_1 - 	heta_2)}{\cos	heta_1 + \cos	heta_2} = \dfrac{gx}{2u^2}\left(\dfrac{u\Delta t}{x}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow \Delta t = \dfrac{2u}{g}\left[\dfrac{\sin(	heta_1-	heta_2)}{\cos	heta_1 + \cos	heta_2}ight]\)
questions.hint: For the shells to collide, they must have the same x and y coordinates at the time of collision. Use the equations of motion and the trajectory equation for projectiles. Introduce a time delay \(\Delta t\) between the firings.
methodOfSolving: Write the x and y coordinates of the shells as functions of time.
Introduce a time delay \(\Delta t\) for the second shell.
For collision, equate the x and y coordinates of both shells.
Solve for \(\Delta t\).

questions.title: Danger Zone for Fighter Jet
questions.questionText: An enemy fighter jet is flying at a constant height of 250 m with a velocity of 500 \(ms^{-1}\). The fighter jet passes over an anti-aircraft gun that can fire at any time and in any direction with a speed of 100 \(ms^{-1}\). Determine the time interval during which the fighter jet is in danger of being hit by the gun bullets.
questions.solution:
The equation of trajectory of bullets is
\(y = x	an	heta - \left(\dfrac{gx^2}{2u^2}ight)\sec^2	heta\)
\(\Rightarrow y = x	an	heta - \dfrac{gx^2}{2u^2}(1+	an^2	heta)\) ...(1)

DIAGRAM[1,200]

For a given value of \(x\), maximum \(y\) can be determined from \(\dfrac{dy}{d(	an	heta)} = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow x - \dfrac{gx^2}{2u^2}(2	an	heta)=0\) \(\left\{  ecause d(	an^2	heta) = 2	an	heta \quad 	ext{and} \quad \dfrac{d(	an	heta)}{d(	an	heta)}=1 ight\}\)
\(\Rightarrow 	an	heta = \dfrac{u^2}{gx}\)
On substituting the expression for \(	an	heta\) in equation (1), we get
\(y_{MAX} = x\left(\dfrac{u^2}{gx}ight) - \dfrac{gx^2}{2u^2}\left(1+\dfrac{u^4}{g^2x^2}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow y_{MAX} = \dfrac{u^2}{2g} - \dfrac{gx^2}{2u^2}\)
The shell can hit an area defined by \(y \le y_{MAX}\)
\(\Rightarrow y \le \dfrac{u^2}{2g} - \dfrac{gx^2}{2u^2}\)
On substituting numerical values, \(y=250 \,	ext{m}\), \(u = 100 \,	ext{ms}^{-1}\), \(g=10 \,	ext{ms}^{-2}\), we get
\(\dfrac{x^2}{2000} \le 250\)
\(\Rightarrow x^2 \le 500000\)
\(\Rightarrow -500\sqrt{2} \le x \le 500\sqrt{2}\)
The fighter jet, can travel 1000\(\sqrt{2}\) m while it can be hit. So the plane is in danger for a period of \(t = \dfrac{x}{u} = \dfrac{1000\sqrt{2}}{500} = 2\sqrt{2} \,	ext{s}\).
questions.hint: The fighter jet is in danger if its height is less than or equal to the maximum height the projectile can reach for a given horizontal distance x. Find the maximum height for a given x and apply the given conditions.
methodOfSolving: Write the equation of trajectory for the projectile.
Find the maximum height \(y_{MAX}\) for a given \(x\) by differentiating the trajectory equation and setting it to zero.
Substitute the given values and find the range of \(x\) for which the projectile can hit the plane.
Find the distance the plane travels in the danger zone and divide by the velocity of the plane to get the time interval.

questions.title: Rate of Change of Angle Between Rod and Hemisphere
questions.questionText: Figure shows a hemisphere and a supported rod. Hemisphere is moving in right direction with a uniform velocity \(v_2\) and the end of rod which is in contact with ground is moving in left direction with a velocity \(v_1\).\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\n Find the rate at which the angle \(\theta\) is changing in terms of \(v_1\), \(v_2\), \(R\) and \(\theta\).
questions.solution:
Here \(x\) is the separation between centre of hemisphere and the end of rod. Rate of change of \(x\) is actually the relative velocity of end of rod and centre of hemisphere i.e., \((v_1+v_2)\). We are required to find the rate of change of \(	heta\) i.e., \(\dfrac{d	heta}{dt}\), knowing that \(\dfrac{dx}{dt}=v_1+v_2\).

DIAGRAM[1,200]

Since, \(x = R\csc	heta\)
Differentiating with respect to time we get
\(\dfrac{dx}{dt} = -R\csc	heta\cot	heta\dfrac{d	heta}{dt}\) \(\left\{  ecause \dfrac{d}{dt}(\csc	heta) = -\csc	heta\cot	heta ight\}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{d	heta}{dt} = -\dfrac{(v_1+v_2)\sin^2	heta}{R\cos	heta}\)
questions.hint: Relate the distance x between the center of the hemisphere and the end of the rod to the angle θ and radius R. Differentiate this relationship with respect to time. The rate of change of x is the relative velocity of the rod and the hemisphere.
methodOfSolving: Express \(x\) in terms of \(R\) and \(\theta\).
Differentiate \(x\) with respect to time to relate \(\dfrac{dx}{dt}\) and \(\dfrac{d\theta}{dt}\).
Substitute \(\dfrac{dx}{dt} = v_1 + v_2\) and solve for \(\dfrac{d\theta}{dt}\).

questions.title: Acceleration of Block on a Moving Wedge
questions.questionText: Figure shown a block \(A\) constrained to slide along the incline plane of the wedge \(B\) shown.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\n Block \(A\) is attached with a string which passes through three ideal pulleys and connected to the wedge \(B\). If wedge moves towards left with an acceleration \(a_0\), find the acceleration of the block with respect to the wedge and the ground.
questions.solution:
When the wedge moves to the left towards the wall by \(x\), then a portion \(2x\) of the string is loosened which makes the block A to go down by \(2x\). So, acceleration of the block with respect to the wedge is \(2a_0\). However, with respect to the ground the situation is shown for
\(a_A = \sqrt{a_0^2 + 4a_0^2 - 4a_0^2\cos	heta}\)
\(\Rightarrow a_A = a_0\sqrt{5-4\cos	heta}\)

DIAGRAM[2,200]
questions.hint: When the wedge moves a distance x to the left, a length 2x of the string is loosened, causing the block to slide down the incline. Consider the constraint motion of the block along the incline and the motion of the wedge.
methodOfSolving: Relate the displacement of the wedge to the displacement of the block along the incline.
Find the acceleration of the block with respect to the wedge.
Use vector addition to find the acceleration of the block with respect to the ground.
questions.answer: \(2a_0\) (with respect to wedge), \(a_0\sqrt{5-4\cos\theta}\) (with respect to ground)

questions.title: Angular Velocity of One Particle Relative to Another
questions.questionText: Find angular velocity of \(A\) with respect to \(B\) at the instant shown in the figure.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
DIAGRAM[2,200]
Angular velocity of A with respect to B is \(\omega_{AB} = \dfrac{(v_{AB})_\perp}{r_{AB}}\)
\(\Rightarrow v_{AB} = \sqrt{2}v = (v_{AB})_\perp\)
\(\Rightarrow r_{AB} = \sqrt{2}d\)
\(\Rightarrow \omega_{AB} = \dfrac{(v_{AB})_\perp}{r_{AB}} = \dfrac{v\sqrt{2}}{d\sqrt{2}} = \dfrac{v}{d}\)
questions.hint: The angular velocity of A with respect to B is the ratio of the perpendicular component of the relative velocity of A with respect to B to the distance between A and B.
methodOfSolving: Find the relative velocity of A with respect to B.
Determine the perpendicular component of the relative velocity.
Calculate the distance between A and B.
Divide the perpendicular component of the relative velocity by the distance between A and B to find the angular velocity.

questions.title: Velocity of Ring Leaving a Rotating Rod
questions.questionText: A ring which can slide along the rod are kept at mid-point of a smooth rod of length \(L\). The rod is rotated with constant angular velocity \(\omega\) about vertical axis passing through its one end. Ring is released from mid-point.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nFind the velocity of the ring when it just leave the rod.
questions.solution:
Centrifugal force at distance \(x\) is \(m\omega^2 x = ma\)
\(\Rightarrow \omega^2x = \dfrac{vdv}{dx}\)
Rearranging and integrating, we get

DIAGRAM[2,200]
\(\displaystyle\int_{L/2}^L \omega^2 x dx = \displaystyle\int_0^v v dv\)
\(\Rightarrow \omega^2 \left[\dfrac{x^2}{2}ight]_{L/2}^L = \left[\dfrac{v^2}{2}ight]_0^v\)
\(\Rightarrow \omega^2\left(\dfrac{L^2}{2} - \dfrac{L^2}{8}ight) = \dfrac{v^2}{2}\)
\(\Rightarrow v = \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\omega L\)
Velocity at time of leaving the rod is the resultant of tangential speed and the radial speed of the particle. So,
\(v' = \sqrt{(\omega L)^2 + \left(\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\omega Light)^2}\)
\(\Rightarrow v' = \dfrac{\sqrt{7}}{2}\omega L\)
questions.hint: The centrifugal force acting on the ring causes it to accelerate radially outwards. Integrate the centrifugal force to find the radial velocity. The net velocity is the vector sum of radial and tangential velocities.
methodOfSolving: Write expression for the centrifugal force at distance \(x\).
Relate the centrifugal force to the radial acceleration.
Integrate to find the velocity as a function of \(x\).
Determine the radial velocity when the ring leaves the rod.
Calculate the tangential velocity.
Find the resultant velocity by combining radial and tangential velocities.

questions.title: Two Blocks on a Rotating Turntable
questions.questionText:
Two blocks of mass \(m_1 = 10 \,	ext{kg}\) and \(m_2 = 5 \,	ext{kg}\) connected to each other by a massless inextensible string of length 0.3 m are placed along a diameter of the turntable. The coefficient of friction between the table and \(m_1\) is 0.5 while there is no friction between \(m_2\) and the table. The table is rotating with an angular velocity of 10 \(	ext{rads}^{-1}\) about a vertical axis passing through its centre \(O\). The masses are placed along the diameter of the table on either side of the centre \(O\) such that the mass \(m_1\) is at a distance of 0.124 m from \(O\). The masses are observed to be at rest with respect to an observer on the turn table. \((g = 9.8 \,	ext{ms}^{-2})\). 
DIAGRAM[1,170]
(a) Calculate the frictional force on \(m_1\).
(b) What should be the minimum angular speed of the turntable so that the masses will slip from this position?
questions.solution:
Given \(m_1 = 10 \,	ext{kg}\), \(m_2 = 5 \,	ext{kg}\), \(\omega = 10 \,	ext{rads}^{-1}\)
\(r = 0.3 \,	ext{m}\), \(r_1 = 0.124 \,	ext{m}\)
\(\Rightarrow r_2 = r-r_1 = 0.176 \,	ext{m}\)

DIAGRAM[1,170]

(a) Masses \(m_1\) and \(m_2\) are at rest with respect to rotating table. Let \(f\) be the friction between mass \(m_1\) and table. Free body diagram of \(m_1\) and \(m_2\) with respect to table (non inertial frame of reference are shown in figure).

DIAGRAM[2,200]

Equilibrium of \(m_2\) gives \(T = m_2r_2\omega^2\) ...(1)
Since, \(m_2r_2\omega^2 < m_1r_1\omega^2 \quad \{m_2r_2 < m_1r_1\}\)
Therefore, \(m_1\omega^2 > T\) and friction on \(m_1\) will be inwards (towards centre)
Equilibrium of \(m_1\) gives \(f+T = m_1r_1\omega^2\) ...(2)
From equations (1) and (2), we get
\(f = m_1r_1\omega^2 - m_2r_2\omega^2\)
\(\Rightarrow f = (m_1r_1-m_2r_2)\omega^2\) ...(3)
\(\Rightarrow f = (10 	imes 0.124 - 5 	imes 0.176)(100) \,	ext{Newton}\)
\(\Rightarrow f = 36 \,	ext{N}\)
Therefore, frictional force on \(m_1\) is 36 N (inwards).
(b) Since, from equation (3), we have \(f=(m_1r_1-m_2r_2)\omega^2\)
So, the masses will start slipping when this force is greater than \(f_{max}\) i.e.,
\((m_1r_1 - m_2r_2)\omega^2 > f_{max} > \mu m_1g\)
Hence, the minimum value of \(\omega\) is
\(\omega_{min} = \sqrt{\dfrac{\mu m_1 g}{m_1r_1 - m_2r_2}} = \sqrt{\dfrac{0.5 	imes 10 	imes 9.8}{10 	imes 0.124 - 5 	imes 0.176}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \omega_{min} = 11.67 \,	ext{rads}^{-1}\)
questions.hint: Consider the forces acting on each block in the rotating frame of reference.  The tension in the string provides the centripetal force for m2.  For m1, the difference between the centripetal force and the tension is balanced by friction.
methodOfSolving: Draw free body diagrams for both blocks.
Write the force balance equations for each block.
Solve for the frictional force on m1.
For the blocks to slip, the required centripetal force must be greater than the maximum static friction.
Find the minimum angular speed for slipping.

questions.title: Angular Velocity for Vertical Rod with Suspended Masses
questions.questionText: Two balls of mass \(m_1\) and \(m_2\) are suspended by two threads of lengths \(l_1\) and \(l_2\) at the end of a freely hanging rod.\nDIAGRAM[1,180]\nDetermine the angular velocity \(\omega\) at which the rod must be rotated about the vertical axis so that it remains vertical.
questions.solution:
Free body diagrams of two masses and the rod are as shown in figure.
DIAGRAM[3,200]DIAGRAM[2,200]
For \(m_1\)
Equations of motion are,
\(T_1\sin	heta_1 = m_1\omega^2l_1\sin	heta_1\) ...(1)
\(T_1\cos	heta_1 = m_1g\) ...(2)
For \(m_2\)
\(T_2\sin	heta_2 = m_2\omega^2l_2\sin	heta_2\) ...(3)
\(T_2\cos	heta_2 = m_2g\) ...(4)
For the rod to remain in vertical position, \(T_1\sin	heta_1 = T_2\sin	heta_2\) ...(5)
Solving the above equations, we get \(\omega^4 = \left(\dfrac{m_1^2g^2}{m_1^2l_1^2} - \dfrac{m_2^2g^2}{m_2^2l_2^2}ight)\)
questions.hint: Consider the forces acting on each ball and the rod. For the rod to remain vertical, the net horizontal force on it must be zero. The tension in the threads provides the centripetal force for the balls to rotate.
methodOfSolving: Draw free body diagrams for the masses and the rod.
Write the equations of motion for each mass, considering the horizontal and vertical components of tension and the centripetal force.
For the rod to remain vertical, the horizontal components of tension must balance.
Solve the equations to find the angular velocity \(\omega\).

questions.title: Equilibrium of Beads on a Circular Ring
questions.questionText: Two small beads of weight \(W_1\) and \(W_2\) each capable of sliding freely on a smooth circular ring fixed in the vertical plane are connected by a light string. Show that in the position of equilibrium in which the string be straight and inclined at an angle \(\theta\) to the horizontal we have \((W_1+W_2)\tan\theta = (W_1-W_2)\tan\dfrac{\alpha}{2}\). Here, \(\alpha\) is the angle subtended by the string at the centre.
questions.solution:
Beads are in equilibrium under three concurrent forces. So applying Lami’s theorem,
For Bead 1:
\(\dfrac{W_1}{\sin\{180 - (90-\dfrac{\alpha}{2})\}} = \dfrac{T}{\sin\{90+	heta+90-\dfrac{\alpha}{2}\}}\)
\(\Rightarrow T = \dfrac{W_1\sin(\dfrac{\alpha}{2}-	heta)}{\cos\dfrac{\alpha}{2}}\) ...(1)

DIAGRAM[1,200]

For Bead 2:
\(\dfrac{W_2}{\sin\{180-(90-\dfrac{\alpha}{2})\}} = \dfrac{T}{\sin\{90+90-\dfrac{\alpha}{2}-	heta\}}\)
\(\Rightarrow T = \dfrac{W_2\sin(\dfrac{\alpha}{2}+	heta)}{\cos\dfrac{\alpha}{2}}\) ...(2)
Equating equations (1) and (2), we get
\(W_1\sin\left(\dfrac{\alpha}{2}-	hetaight) = W_2\sin\left(\dfrac{\alpha}{2} + 	hetaight)\)
Since \(\sin(A \pm B) = \sin A \cos B \pm \cos A \sin B\)
\(\Rightarrow W_1\left[\sin\left(\dfrac{\alpha}{2}ight)\cos	heta - \sin	heta\cos\left(\dfrac{\alpha}{2}ight)ight] = W_2\left[\sin\left(\dfrac{\alpha}{2}ight)\cos	heta + \sin	heta\cos\left(\dfrac{\alpha}{2}ight)ight]\)
Dividing the equation by \(\cos	heta \cos\left(\dfrac{\alpha}{2}ight)\), we get
\((W_1+W_2)	an	heta = (W_1-W_2)	an\left(\dfrac{\alpha}{2}ight)\)
questions.hint: Apply Lami's theorem to each bead, considering the forces acting on them: weight, tension in the string, and normal reaction from the ring. Equate the expressions for tension and simplify to obtain the desired relationship.
methodOfSolving: Draw a free body diagram for each bead.
Apply Lami's theorem to each bead, considering the three forces acting on it.
Equate the expressions for tension derived from Lami's theorem.
Use trigonometric identities to simplify and obtain the final result.

questions.title: Equilibrium of a Beam Leaning Against a Wall
questions.questionText:
A uniform beam of mass \(m\) is inclined at an angle \(	heta\) to the horizontal. Its upper end produces a ninety degree bend in a very rough rope tied to a wall and its lower end rests on a rough floor.
DIAGRAM[1,200]
(a) If the coefficient of static friction between beam and floor is \(\mu_s\), determine an expression for the maximum mass \(M\) that can be suspended from the top before the beam slips.
(b) Determine the magnitude of the reaction force at the floor and the magnitude of the force exerted by the beam on the rope at \(P\) in terms of \(m\), \(M\) and \(\mu_s\).
questions.solution:
(a) For equilibrium, \(\Sigma F_x = \Sigma F_y = 0\) and \(\Sigma 	au = 0\) with pivot point at the contact on the floor.
Then \(\Sigma F_x = T - \mu_s N = 0\) ...(1)
\(\Sigma F_y = N - Mg - mg = 0\) ...(2)
\(\Sigma 	au = Mg(L\cos	heta) + mg\left(\dfrac{L}{2}\cos	hetaight) - T(L\sin	heta) = 0\) ...(3)

DIAGRAM[2,170]

Solving equations (1), (2) and (3), we get \(M = \dfrac{m}{2}\left(\dfrac{2\mu_s\sin	heta - \cos	heta}{\cos	heta - \mu_s\sin	heta}ight)\)
This answer is the maximum value for \(M\) if \(\mu_s < \cot	heta\).
If \(\mu_s \ge \cot	heta\), the mass \(M\) can increase without limit. It has no maximum value, and part (b) cannot be answered as stated either. In the case \(\mu_s < \cot	heta\), we proceed.
(b) At the floor, we have the normal force in the \(y\)-direction and frictional force in the \(x\)-direction. The reaction force then is
\(R = \sqrt{N^2 + (\mu_s N)^2} = (M+m)g\sqrt{1+\mu_s^2}\)
At point \(P\), the force of the beam on the rope is \(F = \sqrt{T^2+(Mg)^2} = g\sqrt{M^2 + \mu_s^2(M+m)^2}\)
questions.hint: For equilibrium, the sum of forces in both x and y directions should be zero, and the net torque about any point should also be zero. Use the conditions for static equilibrium to relate M, m, \(\mu_s\), and \(\theta\).
methodOfSolving: Draw a free body diagram of the beam, showing all forces acting on it.
Write the equilibrium equations for forces in x and y directions.
Choose a pivot point (e.g., the point where the beam contacts the floor) and write the torque equilibrium equation.
Solve the equations to find M.
Find the reaction force at the floor and the force on the rope at P using the calculated values.

questions.title: Velocity of Disc on Inclined Plane with Friction
questions.questionText: A small disc \(A\) is placed on an inclined plane forming an angle \(\alpha\) with the horizontal and is imparted an initial velocity \(v_0\). Find how the velocity of the disc depends on the angle \(\phi\) if the friction coefficient \(\mu = \tan\alpha\) and at the initial moment \(\phi_0 = \dfrac{\pi}{2}\).
questions.solution:
Let \(a\) be the acceleration of disc in the direction of its velocity (tangential acceleration). Then
\(a = g\sin\alpha\cos\phi - \mu g\cos\alpha\)
\(\Rightarrow a = g\sin\alpha(\cos\phi - 1)\) \(\quad ( ecause \mu=	an\alpha)\) ...(1)
Similarly, if \(a_x\) be the acceleration of disc along x-direction, then
\(a_x = g\sin\alpha - (\mu g\cos\alpha)\cos\phi\)
\(\Rightarrow a_x = g\sin\alpha(1-\cos\phi)\) ...(2)

DIAGRAM[1,200]DIAGRAM[2,150]

Adding equations (1) and (2), we get
\(a+a_x = 0\)
Integrating, we get
\(v+v_x = c\)
Here, \(c\) is a constant and \(v_x = v\cos\phi\)
\(\Rightarrow v + v\cos\phi = c\) ...(3)
Since, at \(\phi_0 = \dfrac{\pi}{2}\), we have \(v=v_0\)
\(\Rightarrow c = v_0\)
Substituting in equation (3), we get
\(v = \dfrac{v_0}{1+\cos\phi}\)
questions.hint: Consider the tangential and x-components of the disc's acceleration. The friction force opposes the motion of the disc.  Integrate the net acceleration to find the velocity as a function of the angle φ.
methodOfSolving: Resolve the forces acting on the disc into components along the incline and perpendicular to the incline.
Write the equations for tangential acceleration (\(a\)) and acceleration along the x-direction (\(a_x\)).
Add the two acceleration equations and integrate to find the relationship between \(v\) and \(v_x\).
Substitute \(v_x = v\cos\phi\) and use the initial condition to find the constant of integration.
Express \(v\) in terms of \(\phi\).

questions.title: Block Sliding on a Plank on a Horizontal Road
questions.questionText:
Figure shows a small block \(A\) of mass \(m\) kept at the left end of a plank \(B\) of mass \(M = 2m\) and length \(l\). The system can slide on a horizontal road. The system is started towards right with the initial velocity \(v\). The friction coefficients between the road and the plank is \(\dfrac{1}{2}\) and that between the plank and the block is \(\dfrac{1}{4}\). 
DIAGRAM[1,200]
Find
(a) the time elapsed before the block separates from the plank.
(b) displacement of block and plank relative to ground till that moment.
questions.solution:
There will be relative motion between block and plank and plank and road. So at each surface limiting friction will act. The direction of friction forces at different surfaces are as shown in figure.

DIAGRAM[2,250]

Here, \(f_1 = \left(\dfrac{1}{4}ight)(mg)\) and \(f_2 = \left(\dfrac{1}{2}ight)(m+2m)g = \left(\dfrac{3}{2}ight)mg\)
Retardation of A is \(a_1 = \dfrac{f_1}{m} = \dfrac{g}{4}\) and retardation of B is \(a_2 = \dfrac{f_2-f_1}{2m} = \dfrac{5}{8}g\)
Since, \(a_2 > a_1\)
Relative acceleration of A with respect to B is \(a_r = a_2 - a_1 = \dfrac{3}{8}g\)
Initial velocity of both A and B is \(v\). So there is no relative initial velocity. Hence,
(a) Applying \(s = \dfrac{1}{2}at^2\)
\(\Rightarrow l = \dfrac{1}{2}a_r t^2 = \dfrac{3}{16}gt^2\)
\(\Rightarrow t = \sqrt{\dfrac{16l}{3g}} = 4\sqrt{\dfrac{l}{3g}}\)
(b) Displacement of block is given by
\(s_A = u_At - \dfrac{1}{2}a_A t^2 \)
\(\Rightarrow s_A = 4v\sqrt{\dfrac{l}{3g}} - \dfrac{1}{2}\left(\dfrac{g}{4}ight)\left(\dfrac{16l}{3g}ight) \)
\(\Rightarrow s_A = 4v\sqrt{\dfrac{l}{3g}} - \dfrac{2l}{3} \quad \left\{ a_A = a_1 = \dfrac{g}{4} ight\}\)
\(\Rightarrow s_A = 4v\sqrt{\dfrac{l}{3g}} - \dfrac{2l}{3}\)
Displacement of plank is given by
\(s_B = u_Bt - \dfrac{1}{2}a_B t^2 \)
\(s_B = 4v\sqrt{\dfrac{l}{3g}} - \dfrac{1}{2}\left(\dfrac{5}{8}gight)\left(\dfrac{16l}{3g}ight) \)
\(\Rightarrow s_B= 4v\sqrt{\dfrac{l}{3g}} - \dfrac{5l}{3} \quad \left\{ a_B = a_2 \dfrac{5g}{8} ight\}\)
\(\Rightarrow s_B = 4v\sqrt{\dfrac{l}{3g}} - \dfrac{5l}{3}\)
Here we observe that \(s_A - s_B = l\). This is a quite obvious result because the block A has moved a distance \(l\) relative to plank.
questions.hint: Consider the relative motion between the block and the plank.  The friction forces between the block and plank, and between the plank and road, cause decelerations. The block separates from the plank when the relative displacement between them is equal to the length of the plank.
methodOfSolving: Determine the friction forces acting on the block and the plank.
Calculate the decelerations of the block (\(a_1\)) and the plank (\(a_2\)).
Find the relative acceleration \(a_r\) between the block and the plank.
Use the equation of motion for relative displacement to find the time of separation.
Calculate the displacements of the block and the plank relative to the ground using their respective decelerations and the calculated time.

Assuming all surfaces to be smooth, find the force exerted by the vertical wall \(OM\) on wedge, when the ball is in position \(B\) \((g = 10 \,\text{ms}^{-2})\).\nDIAGRAM[1,200]

\(\Rightarrow v^2 = 2(10)(0.25) = 5 \,	ext{m}^2	ext{s}^{-2}\) ...(1)

questions.title: Ratio of Friction Forces on a Rotating Sphere
questions.questionText: DIAGRAM[1,200]\nA sphere is rotating between two rough inclined walls as shown in Figure. The coefficient of friction between each wall and the sphere is \(\dfrac{1}{3}\). If \(f_1\) and \(f_2\) be the friction forces at \(P\) and \(Q\). Find the ratio \(\dfrac{f_1}{f_2}\).
questions.solution:
Let \(\mu\) be the friction coefficient between sphere and each wall. Free body diagram of sphere is

DIAGRAM[2,200]

Net force on the sphere in horizontal direction is zero. So,
\(N_1\cos 60^\circ + \mu N_2 \cos 60^\circ = N_2\cos 30^\circ + \mu N_1\cos 30^\circ\)
\(\Rightarrow N_1 + \mu N_2 = \sqrt{3}(N_2 + \mu N_1)\)
\(\Rightarrow N_1(1-\sqrt{3}\mu) = N_2(\sqrt{3}-\mu)\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{N_1}{N_2} = \dfrac{\sqrt{3}-\mu}{1-\sqrt{3}\mu}\)
Substituting \(\mu = \dfrac{1}{3}\) we get,
\(\dfrac{N_1}{N_2} = \dfrac{\sqrt{3}-\dfrac{1}{3}}{1-\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{3}} = \dfrac{3\sqrt{3}-1}{3-\sqrt{3}} = 1 + \dfrac{4}{\sqrt{3}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{f_1}{f_2} = \dfrac{\mu N_1}{\mu N_2} = 1 + \dfrac{4}{\sqrt{3}}\)
questions.hint: Draw a free body diagram of the sphere, showing the normal reactions and friction forces from both walls. Since the sphere is rotating, the net force in the horizontal direction must be zero.  The friction force is proportional to the normal reaction.
methodOfSolving: Draw the free body diagram of the sphere.
Resolve the normal reactions \(N_1\) and \(N_2\) and frictional forces \(f_1\) and \(f_2\) into horizontal and vertical components.
For horizontal equilibrium, equate the net horizontal force to zero: \(N_1\cos 60^\circ + \mu N_2 \cos 60^\circ = N_2\cos 30^\circ + \mu N_1\cos 30^\circ\)
Solve for the ratio of normal reactions \(\dfrac{N_1}{N_2}\).
Use the relationship between friction and normal reaction (\(f = \mu N\)) to find \(\dfrac{f_1}{f_2}\).

questions.title: Maximum Force for No Motion
questions.questionText: The maximum value of the force \(F\) such that the block shown in the arrangement, does not move. \nDIAGRAM[1,250]\n\(m = \sqrt{3} \,\text{kg}\), \(\mu = \dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{3}}\)

\(\Rightarrow F\cos 60^\circ \le \mu(mg+F\sin 60^\circ)\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{F}{2} \le \dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{3}}\left(\sqrt{3}g + \dfrac{F\sqrt{3}}{2}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{F}{2} \le \dfrac{g}{2} + \dfrac{F}{4}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{F}{2} \le \dfrac{8}{2}\)
\(\Rightarrow F_{max} = 20 \,	ext{N}\)

methodOfSolving: Resolve \(F\) into horizontal (\(F\cos 60^\circ\)) and vertical (\(F\sin 60^\circ\)) components.
Find the normal reaction \(N = mg + F\sin 60^\circ\).
Write the condition for no motion: \(F\cos 60^\circ \le \mu N\).
Substitute the values and solve for the maximum value of \(F\).

questions.title: Work Done on a Block Pulled by a Car
questions.questionText: The 100 kg block is being dragged across the smooth surface by means of a car. If the towing cable passes over a small pulley at \(A\), calculate the work done on the block when \(\theta = 60^\circ\). The block is at rest when \(\theta = 30^\circ\) and the car exerts a constant force \(F = 500 \,\text{N}\) on the cable.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
The total work done on the string should be zero, since the string is inextensible. Now, work done by car on the string must match the work done by string on the block. Displacement of the car is \(8 \,	ext{m} \csc 30^\circ - 8 \,	ext{m} \csc 60^\circ\). This displacement times the force is the answer.
\(	ext{Work done} = 	ext{Force} 	imes 	ext{Displacement}\)
Displacement of the car:
\( = 8\csc 30^\circ - 8\csc 60^\circ \)
\(= 8\left(\dfrac{1}{\sin 30^\circ} - \dfrac{1}{\sin 60^\circ}ight) \)
\(= 8\left(2-\dfrac{2}{\sqrt{3}}ight) \)
\(= \dfrac{16}{\sqrt{3}}(\sqrt{3}-1) \,	ext{m}\)
Work done by the car:
\(= 500 	imes \dfrac{16(\sqrt{3}-1)}{\sqrt{3}} \)
\(\approx 500 	imes 16 	imes (1-0.577) \)
\(\approx 3413 \,	ext{J}\)
questions.hint: The work done by the car on the cable is equal to the work done on the block. The displacement of the car can be calculated using trigonometry, considering the change in the angle \(\theta\) and the fixed vertical distance.
methodOfSolving: Calculate the initial and final lengths of the cable from the car to the pulley using trigonometry.
The difference between the initial and final lengths is the displacement of the car.
Multiply the displacement of the car by the constant force exerted to find the work done.

questions.title: Power Developed by a Force Lifting a Collar
questions.questionText: The 50 N collar starts from rest at \(A\) and is lifted with a constant speed of \(0.6 \,\text{ms}^{-1}\) along the smooth rod. Determine the power developed by the force \(F\) at the instant shown.DIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
Since the collar is lifted with a constant speed of \(0.6 \,	ext{ms}^{-1}\). So
\(F\cos	heta - mg = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow F\cos	heta = 5(10) = 50\)
\(\Rightarrow F = \dfrac{50}{\cos	heta}\) ...(1)
Now \(P = \vec{F} \cdot \vec{v}\)
\(\Rightarrow P = \left(\dfrac{50}{\cos	heta}ight)(v\cos	heta)\)
\(\Rightarrow P = 50v\)
\(\Rightarrow P = 30 \,	ext{W} \quad ( ecause v = 0.6 \,	ext{ms}^{-1})\)
questions.hint: Power is the dot product of force and velocity.  Since the collar is moving at a constant speed, the net force acting on it is zero.  Resolve the force F into components along and perpendicular to the rod.
methodOfSolving: Write the equation for power: \(P = \vec{F} \cdot \vec{v}\).
Since the speed is constant, the net force along the rod is zero. Thus, \(F\cos\theta = mg\).
Calculate \(F\) using the equilibrium condition.
Find the component of \(F\) in the direction of velocity.
Calculate the power \(P\).

questions.title: Velocity of Block at Separation from Surface
questions.questionText: Two blocks \(A\) and \(B\) each having mass of 0.32 kg are connected by a light string passing over a smooth pulley as shown in Figure. The horizontal surface on which the block \(A\) slides is smooth. The block \(A\) is attached to a spring of force constant \(40 \,\text{Nm}^{-1}\) whose other end is fixed to a support 0.40 m above the horizontal surface. Initially, when the system is released to move, the spring is vertical and unstretched.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nFind the velocity of the block \(A\) at the instant it breaks off the surface below it. (Take \(g = 10 \,\text{ms}^{-2}\)).
questions.solution:
Let the block breaks off the surface when it travels a distance \(x\) as shown in figure.

DIAGRAM[2,200]

So, the block A starts loosing contact with the surface below it at point \(A'\) after travelling a distance \(x\). In this process the block B will shift from B to \(B'\) such that \(BB' = AA' = x\) (as string is inextensible) and so there is a loss of gravitational potential energy of block B equal to \(mgx\).
This energy is partly stored as elastic potential energy in the spring which is stretched by \(\Delta L\), and partly appears as kinetic energy of blocks A and B. So, by Conservation of Mechanical Energy, we have
\(mgx = \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}k(\Delta L)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow v^2 = gx - \dfrac{k(\Delta L)^2}{2m}\) ...(1)
Now, for vertical equilibrium of block A at \(A'\)
\(N + F\cos	heta = mg\) ...(2)
But for spring \(F = k\Delta L\) and for breaking off, we have \(N=0\). So, the above equation reduces to
\(k\Delta L\cos	heta = mg\) ...(3)
where, \(\Delta L = \dfrac{L}{\cos	heta} - L = L\left(\dfrac{1}{\cos	heta}-1ight)\) ...(4)
So, substituting the value of \(\Delta L\) from Equations (3) in (4) and solving for \(\cos	heta\), we get
\(\cos	heta = 1 - \dfrac{mg}{kL} = 1 - \dfrac{0.32 	imes 10}{40 	imes 0.40} = \dfrac{4}{5}\)
\(\Rightarrow \Delta L = \left(\dfrac{L}{\cos	heta}-Light) = \dfrac{0.4 	imes 5}{4} - 0.4 = 0.1 \,	ext{m}\) and \(x = L	an	heta = (0.4)\left(\dfrac{3}{4}ight) = 0.3 \,	ext{m}\)
Substituting these values of \(\Delta L\) and \(x\) in Equation (1), we get
\(v = \sqrt{10 	imes 0.3 - \dfrac{40 	imes (0.1)^2}{2 	imes 0.32}} = \sqrt{3 - 0.625} = \sqrt{2.375}\)
\(\Rightarrow v = 1.54 \,	ext{ms}^{-1}\)
questions.hint: Consider conservation of energy. When block A loses contact, the normal reaction becomes zero. Use the condition for vertical equilibrium of block A at the point of separation.
methodOfSolving: Apply conservation of mechanical energy to relate \(mgx\), \(\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2\), \(\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2\), and \(\dfrac{1}{2}k(\Delta L)^2\).
Write the equation for vertical equilibrium for block A: \(N + F\cos\theta = mg\).
Use the conditions \(N=0\) and \(F = k\Delta L\) at separation to find \(\Delta L\).
Substitute the values of \(\Delta L\) and \(x\) into the energy conservation equation to find \(v\).

questions.title: Speed of Bodies in a Pulley System
questions.questionText: In the arrangement shown, calculate the speed of the bodies 1 and 2 having masses 0.5 kg and 2 kg respectively at the moment the block \(m_2\) hits the wall \(AB\). Assume that the bodies are released from rest. Take \(g = 10 \,\text{ms}^{-2}\).\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
From conservation of energy,
\(m_2gh_2 = m_1gh_1 + \dfrac{1}{2}m_1v_1^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}m_2v_2^2\)

DIAGRAM[2,200]

Using our knowledge of constraint relations, we get 
\(v_1 = v_2\cos	heta\)
\(\Rightarrow 2 	imes 10 	imes 1 = (0.5)(10)(\sqrt{5}-2) + \dfrac{1}{2} 	imes 0.5 	imes v_2^2 \left(\dfrac{2}{\sqrt{5}}ight)^2 + \dfrac{1}{2} 	imes 2 	imes v_2^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 20 = 1.18 + 0.2v_2^2 + v_2^2\)
\(\Rightarrow v_2 = 3.96 \,	ext{ms}^{-1}\) and \(v_1 = v_2\cos	heta = \dfrac{2}{\sqrt{5}} 	imes 3.96\)
\(\Rightarrow v_1 = 3.54 \,	ext{ms}^{-1}\)
