methodOfSolving: Apply conservation of energy: \(m_2gh_2 = m_1gh_1 + \dfrac{1}{2}m_1v_1^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}m_2v_2^2\).
Relate \(v_1\) and \(v_2\) using the constraint \(v_1 = v_2 \cos\theta\), where \(\theta\) can be determined from the geometry of the problem.

questions.title: Work Done by Friction on a Sliding Bar
questions.questionText: A horizontal plane supports a plank with a bar of mass 1 kg placed on it and attached by a light elastic non deformed cord of length 40 cm to a point \(O\) as shown in figure.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nThe coefficient of friction between the bar and plank is 0.2. The plank is slowly shifted to the right until the bar starts sliding over it. It occurs at the moment when the cord deviates from the vertical by \(30^\circ\). Calculate the work done (in millijoule) that has been performed by that moment due to friction force acting on the bar in the reference frame attached to the plane.
questions.solution:
The intermediate force diagram of the system, when the cord makes an angle \(	heta (<30^\circ)\) is shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[2,200]

\(T = kx\)
At this instant, the extension in cord is
\(x = \dfrac{l}{\cos	heta} - l\)
\(= l(\sec	heta - 1)\) ...(1)
If the force constant of the cord is \(k\), then the tension developed in the cord is given by \(T = kx\).
The bar will start sliding when
\(kx\sin	heta = f_1 = \mu N\) ...(2)
where \(N = mg - kx\cos	heta = mg\)
Substituting this value of \(N\) in equation (1), we get
\(kx\sin	heta = \mu(mg - kx\cos	heta)\)
\(\Rightarrow kx(\sin	heta + \mu\cos	heta) = \mu mg\)
\(\Rightarrow k = \dfrac{\mu mg}{x(\sin	heta + \mu\cos	heta)}\)
Substituting the value of \(x\) from equation (1), we get
\(\Rightarrow k = \dfrac{\mu mg}{l(\sec	heta - 1)(\sin	heta + \mu\cos	heta)}\)
According to Modified Work-Energy Theorem (MWET), we have
\(W_{nc} = \Delta U + \Delta K\)
where, \(\Delta U = \dfrac{1}{2}kx^2\) and \(\Delta K = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow W_{nc} = \dfrac{1}{2}kx^2 = \dfrac{kx^2}{2}\)
\(\Rightarrow W_{nc} = \dfrac{\mu mgl^2(\sec	heta-1)^2}{2l(\sec	heta-1)(\sin	heta + \mu\cos	heta)} = \dfrac{\mu mgl(1-\cos	heta)}{2\cos	heta(\sin	heta+\mu\cos	heta)}\)
Substituting the numerical data, we get
\(W = 0.09 \,	ext{J} = 90 \,	ext{mJ}\)
questions.hint: The work done by friction is equal to the change in potential energy of the stretched cord. Use the work-energy theorem. The bar starts sliding when the horizontal component of tension in the cord equals the limiting friction.
methodOfSolving: Calculate the extension \(x\) in the cord when it makes an angle \(\theta\) with the vertical: \(x = l(\sec\theta - 1)\).
Write the condition for sliding: \(T\sin\theta = \mu N\), where \(T = kx\) and \(N = mg - T\cos\theta\).
Solve for the spring constant \(k\).
Use the work-energy theorem: The work done by non-conservative forces (friction) is equal to the change in potential energy plus the change in kinetic energy.
Calculate the work done by friction using \(W_{nc} = \Delta U = \dfrac{1}{2}kx^2\).

questions.title: Maximum Extension of a Spring in a System of Blocks
questions.questionText: Two blocks of mass \(m_1 = 2 \,\text{kg}\) and \(m_2 = 4 \,\text{kg}\) are attached by light ideal spring of force constant \(k = 1000 \,\text{Nm}^{-1}\). The system is kept on a smooth inclined plane inclined \(30^\circ\) with horizontal. A force \(F = 15 \,\text{N}\) is applied on \(m_1\) and system is released from rest. The block \(m_2\) is connected with a light string whose another end is attached with a mass \(m_3 = 1 \,\text{kg}\). Assume initially the spring is at relaxed position and the system is released from rest.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nFind the maximum extension of the spring.
questions.solution:
At some instant of time let \(m_1\) be displaced downwards by \(x_1\) and \(m_2\) be displaced downwards by \(x_2\), with \(x_2 > x_1\). Elongation of spring at this instant is then given by \(x = x_2 - x_1\).
Writing equation of motion for \(m_1\), \(m_2\) and \(m_3\), we have,
For \(m_1\), we have
\(m_1g\sin	heta + kx - F = m_1a_1\)
\(\Rightarrow a_1 = \dfrac{m_1g\sin	heta + kx - F}{m_1}\) ...(1)
For \(m_2\), we have
\(T + m_2g\sin	heta - kx = m_2a_2\) ...(2)
For \(m_3\), we have
\(m_3g - T = m_3a_2\) ...(3)
Adding (2) and (3), we get
\(a_2 = \dfrac{m_2g\sin	heta - kx + m_3g}{m_2+m_3}\) ...(4)
Acceleration of \(m_2\) relative to \(m_1\) is given by \(a = a_2 - a_1\)
\(\Rightarrow a = \dfrac{m_2g\sin	heta - kx + m_3g}{(m_2+m_3)} - \dfrac{m_1g\sin	heta + kx - F}{m_1}\)
Substituting the given values, we get
\(a = 8.5 - 700x\)
\(\Rightarrow v\dfrac{dv}{dx} = 8.5 - 700x\)
\(\Rightarrow \displaystyle\int_0^0 vdv = \displaystyle\int_0^{x_{max}} (8.5 - 700x)dx\)
\(\Rightarrow x_{max} = 0.024 \,	ext{m}\)
\(\Rightarrow x_{max} = 2.4 \,	ext{cm}\)
questions.hint: Consider the forces acting on each block and apply Newton's second law. The elongation of the spring is the difference in displacements of the two blocks.  The relative acceleration between the blocks will be zero when the spring reaches maximum extension.
methodOfSolving: Write the equations of motion for each block, considering the forces acting on them (gravity, spring force, tension, applied force).
Find the acceleration of \(m_2\) relative to \(m_1\).
Substitute the given values and express relative acceleration \(a\) in terms of \(x\).
Integrate \(vdv/dx = a\) with appropriate limits to find the maximum extension \(x_{max}\).

questions.title: Time Taken to Reach Horizontal Diameter in Circular Tube
questions.questionText: A smooth circular tube of radius \(R\) is fixed in a vertical plane. A particle is projected from its lowest point with a velocity just sufficient to carry it to the highest point. Calculate the time taken by the particle to reach the end of the horizontal diameter.
questions.solution:
Minimum velocity of particle at the lowest position to complete the circle should be \(\sqrt{4gR}\) inside a tube. So, \(u=\sqrt{4gR}\)

DIAGRAM[1,200]

At any instant, \(h\) has a function of \(	heta\) is given by \(h = R(1-\cos	heta)\)
Since, \(v^2 = u^2 - 2gh\)
\(\Rightarrow v^2 = 4gR - 2gR(1-\cos	heta)\)
\(\Rightarrow v^2 = 2gR(1+\cos	heta)\)
\(\Rightarrow v^2 = 2gR\left(2\cos^2\left(\dfrac{	heta}{2}ight)ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow v = 2\sqrt{gR}\cos\left(\dfrac{	heta}{2}ight)\)
Since \(v = \dfrac{ds}{dt}\)
\(\Rightarrow ds = vdt\)
Since, \(ds = Rd	heta\)
\(\Rightarrow Rd	heta = 2\sqrt{gR}\cos\left(\dfrac{	heta}{2}ight)dt\)
\(\Rightarrow \displaystyle\int_0^t dt = \dfrac{1}{2}\sqrt{\dfrac{R}{g}}\displaystyle\int_0^{\pi/2} \sec\left(\dfrac{	heta}{2}ight)d	heta\)
\(\Rightarrow t = \sqrt{\dfrac{R}{g}}\left[\ln\left(\sec\dfrac{	heta}{2} + 	an\dfrac{	heta}{2}ight)ight]_0^{\pi/2}\)
\(\Rightarrow t = \sqrt{\dfrac{R}{g}}\ln(1+\sqrt{2})\)
questions.hint: Use conservation of energy to find the velocity as a function of the angle θ.  Relate the arc length ds to the angle dθ and the radius R. Integrate the velocity with respect to time to get the required time.
methodOfSolving: Determine the initial velocity \(u\) using conservation of energy.
Express the velocity \(v\) at any angle \(\theta\) using conservation of energy and \(h=R(1-\cos\theta)\).
Relate the arc length \(ds\) to \(Rd\theta\).
Use \(v = \dfrac{ds}{dt}\) and integrate to find the time \(t\) to reach the horizontal diameter (\(\theta = \pi/2\)).

questions.title: Angular Position for Maximum Vertical Acceleration
questions.questionText: A heavy particle slides under gravity down the inside of a smooth vertical tube held in vertical plane. It starts from the highest point with velocity \(\sqrt{2ag}\), where \(a\) is the radius of the circle. Find the angular position \(\theta\) (as shown in figure) at which the vertical acceleration of the particle is maximum.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
At position \(	heta\), we have
\(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2gh\)
where \(h = a(1-\cos	heta)\)
\(\Rightarrow v^2 = (\sqrt{2ag})^2 + 2ag(1-\cos	heta)\)
\(\Rightarrow v^2 = 2ag(2-\cos	heta)\) ...(1)
Also, we have
\(N + mg\cos	heta = \dfrac{mv^2}{a}\)
\(\Rightarrow N + mg\cos	heta = 2mg(2-\cos	heta)\)
\(\Rightarrow N = mg(4-3\cos	heta)\)
Net vertical force acting on the particle is
\(F = N\cos	heta + mg = mg(4\cos	heta - 3\cos^2	heta+1)\)
This force (or acceleration) will be maximum when \(\dfrac{dF}{d	heta}=0\)
\(\Rightarrow -4\sin	heta + 6\sin	heta\cos	heta = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow \sin	heta(-4+6\cos	heta)=0\)
Either \(\sin	heta = 0 \Rightarrow 	heta=0^\circ\) (Not Acceptable)
or \(\cos	heta = \dfrac{2}{3} \Rightarrow 	heta = \cos^{-1}\left(\dfrac{2}{3}ight)\)
Hence, the desired position is at \(	heta = \cos^{-1}\left(\dfrac{2}{3}ight)\)
questions.hint: Use conservation of energy to find the velocity of the particle at angle θ. The normal reaction force provides the centripetal force. The net vertical force is the sum of the vertical component of the normal reaction and the weight.  For maximum vertical acceleration, the derivative of the net vertical force with respect to θ must be zero.
methodOfSolving: Determine the velocity \(v\) at angle \(\theta\) using conservation of energy.
Find the normal reaction \(N\) using the centripetal force equation: \(N + mg\cos\theta = \dfrac{mv^2}{a}\).
Calculate the net vertical force \(F\) acting on the particle: \(F = N\cos\theta + mg\).
Differentiate \(F\) with respect to \(\theta\) and set the derivative to zero to find the angle for maximum vertical acceleration.

questions.title: Bungee Jumper Dynamics
questions.questionText:
A bungee jumper of mass \(m\) kg attached to a light elastic cord (bungee cord) of unstretched length \(L\) jumps from a tall bridge of height \(h\) m. The cord first straightens and then extends as the jumper falls. This prevents the jumper from hitting the water. Assume that the bungee cord behaves like a spring with stiffness constant \(k\).
(a) Calculate the maximum allowed length \(L\) of the unstretched bungee cord to keep the jumper alive? (Assume that the stiffness constant of the cord is constant throughout the fall of the bungee jumper)
(b) Before the bungee jumper jumps off the bridge, his instructor of same mass verified the stiffness constant of the bungee cord by lowering himself very slowly from the bridge to the full extent of the cord and measured his remaining distance \(d\) from the water surface. Calculate \(d\). 
Assume air drag to be negligible, no heat is dissipated in the string, only gravitation and spring forces to be present.
questions.solution:
Given that, \(L\) is the unstretched length of the cord.
\(h\) = 100 m, \(k = 100 \,	ext{Nm}^{-1}\), \(m = 50 \,	ext{kg}\). Let \(x\) denote the distance through which the bungee jumper has fallen from the bridge
(a) We want to choose \(L\) so that the jumper comes to a stop just before touching the water surface. At this moment, the extension in the cord is \(x = (h-L)\) 

DIAGRAM[1,200]

So, by Law of Conservation of Mechanical Energy, we have loss in gravitational potential energy of the jumper equals the gain in elastic potential energy of the bungee cord.
\(\Rightarrow mgh = \dfrac{1}{2}kx^2\)
\(\Rightarrow mgh = \dfrac{1}{2}k(h-L)^2\)
\(\Rightarrow L = h - \sqrt{\dfrac{2mgh}{k}}\)
(b) The bungee jumper will hang freely at the distance \(d\) above the water when the weight of the instructor is balanced by the spring force developed in the cord i.e. at equilibrium. If \(x_{eq}\) be the extension in the bungee cord at equilibrium, then we have
\(kx_{eq} = mg\)
where \(x_{eq} = h-L-d\)
\(\Rightarrow k(h-L-d) = mg\)
\(\Rightarrow d = h - L - \dfrac{mg}{k}\)
questions.hint: (a) Use conservation of mechanical energy. The loss in gravitational potential energy of the jumper is equal to the gain in elastic potential energy of the cord.\n(b) At equilibrium, the weight of the instructor is balanced by the spring force in the cord.
methodOfSolving: (a) Apply conservation of energy: \(mgh = \dfrac{1}{2}kx^2\), where \(x = h-L\). Solve for \(L\).
(b) At equilibrium, the weight of the instructor equals the spring force: \(mg = kx_{eq}\), where \(x_{eq} = h-L-d\). Solve for \(d\).

questions.title: Center of Mass of a Cut Sphere
questions.questionText: A small part \(A\) is cut from a solid sphere by a plane at a distance \(\dfrac{R}{2}\) from its centre as shown in Figure.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nFind the location of centre of mass of object \(A\) from the centre of the sphere.
questions.solution:
To find centre of mass of object \(A\), we consider a small elemental disc of width \(dx\) at a distance \(x\) from the centre \(C\) as shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[2,200]

Radius \(r\) of this elemental disc is \(r = \sqrt{R^2 - x^2}\).
If \(ho\) be the density of the sphere, then mass of the elemental disc \(dm = ho dV = ho(\pi r^2 dx) = \piho(R^2-x^2)dx\)
Mass of object A can be obtained as
\(M = \displaystyle\int_{R/2}^R dm = \piho\displaystyle\int_{R/2}^R(R^2-x^2)dx\)
\(\Rightarrow M = \piho\left[R^2x - \dfrac{x^3}{3}ight]_{R/2}^R\)
\(\Rightarrow M = \piho\left[\left(R^3-\dfrac{R^3}{3}ight) - \left(\dfrac{R^3}{2} - \dfrac{R^3}{24}ight)ight] = \dfrac{5}{24}\piho R^3\)
Since, \(y_{cm} = \dfrac{1}{M}\displaystyle\int_{R/2}^R x dm\)
\(\Rightarrow y_{cm} = \dfrac{24}{5\piho R^3}\displaystyle\int_{R/2}^R \piho(R^2-x^2)xdx\)
\(\Rightarrow y_{cm} = \dfrac{24}{5R^3}\left[\dfrac{R^2x^2}{2} - \dfrac{x^4}{4}ight]_{R/2}^R\)
\(\Rightarrow y_{cm} = \dfrac{12}{5R^3}\left[\left(\dfrac{R^4}{2}-\dfrac{R^4}{4}ight) - \left(\dfrac{R^4}{4	imes2}-\dfrac{R^4}{4	imes32}ight)ight] = \dfrac{27}{40}R\)
questions.hint: Consider a small elemental disc of width dx at a distance x from the center of the sphere. Find the mass of this disc and integrate to get the mass of the cut portion. Then, integrate the product of the distance x and the mass dm to find the center of mass.
methodOfSolving: Consider an elemental disc of width \(dx\) at distance \(x\) from the center.
Determine the radius \(r\) of the disc: \(r = \sqrt{R^2 - x^2}\).
Calculate the mass \(dm\) of the disc: \(dm = \rho\pi r^2 dx\).
Integrate \(dm\) from \(R/2\) to \(R\) to find the mass \(M\) of the cut portion.
Calculate the center of mass \(y_{cm}\) using \(y_{cm} = \dfrac{1}{M} \displaystyle\int x dm\).

questions.title: Displacement of Center of Mass of Man-Ladder System
questions.questionText: A rope thrown over a pulley has a ladder with a man \(A\) on one of its ends and a counter balancing mass \(M\) on its other end. The man whose mass is \(m\), climbs upwards by \(\Delta r\) relative to the ladder and then stops. Assuming the masses of the pulley and the rope to be negligible, pulley to be frictionless at the axis, calculate the displacement of the centre of mass of this system.
questions.solution:
Counter balancing mass \(M\) applied at the other end means that \(M = m + m_{ladder}\)
\(\Rightarrow m_{ladder} = M-m\)
\(m_{pulley} \approx m_{rope} \approx 0\)
Displacement of man with respect to ladder is \(y_{m/l} = \Delta r\)

DIAGRAM[1,160]

When man moves up by \(\Delta r\), then let ladder move down by \(y\) and hence counter weight moves up by \(y\). So, effective displacement of man is \(\Delta r - y\).
The displacement of CM is given by
\(\Delta r_{cm} = \dfrac{m_l \Delta r_l + m_m \Delta r_m + m_c \Delta r_c}{m_l+m_m+m_c}\)
\(\Rightarrow \Delta r_{cm} = \dfrac{(M-m)y + m(\Delta r - y) + M(-y)}{M-m+m+M}\)
\(\Rightarrow \Delta r_{cm} = \dfrac{m\Delta r}{2M} \,	ext{, upwards}\)
questions.hint: When the man climbs up the ladder, the ladder and the counterbalancing mass will move.  The center of mass of the system will shift. Consider the relative displacements of the man, ladder, and counterbalancing mass. Since the pulley is frictionless and massless and the rope is massless, at equilibrium, Mg = mg + m_ladder g
methodOfSolving: Define the masses:  \(M\) for the counterbalance, \(m\) for the man, and \(M-m\) for the ladder.
Let the ladder move down by \(y\) when the man climbs up by \(\Delta r\).
The effective displacement of the man is \(\Delta r - y\).
Use the formula for the displacement of the center of mass: \(\Delta r_{cm} = \dfrac{\sum m_i \Delta r_i}{\sum m_i}\).
Substitute the values and solve for \(\Delta r_{cm}\).

questions.title: Center of Mass Displacement and Ladder Displacement
questions.questionText: Two ladders are hanging from ends of a light rope that passes over a light and smooth pulley. A monkey of mass \(2m\) hangs near the bottom of one ladder whose mass is \(M-2m\). Another monkey of mass \(m\) hangs near the bottom in the other ladder whose mass is \(M-m\) as shown in Figure.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nThe monkey of mass \(2m\) moves up a distance \(l\) with respect to the ladder. The monkey of mass \(m\) moves up a distance \(l/2\) with respect to the ladder. Does the centre of mass of the system change? If so, then calculate the displacement of centre of mass of the system. Also calculate the displacement of ladder.
questions.solution:
In this problem let us consider both the monkeys and the ladders as a system. When the monkeys are at rest, the tension force in the string is balanced by the weight of the system. However, when a monkey starts moving up, then he pulls the respective ladder in downward direction due to which the tension in string increases. Hence, there will be a net upward external force acting on the system and the displacement of centre of mass of the system will be in upward direction.
Let the displacement of Ladder 1 in this process be \(y\) upwards, then the displacement of Ladder 2 will be \(y\) downwards (because both the ladders are connected together by a single string). During this time the displacement of Monkey 1 will be \(l+y\) and that of Monkey 2 will be \(\dfrac{l}{2}-y\) as shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[2,200]

The displacement of the centre of mass of system is given by
\(\Delta y_{cm} = \dfrac{m_1\Delta y_1 + m_2\Delta y_2 + m_3\Delta y_3 + m_4\Delta y_4}{m_1+m_2+m_3+m_4}\) ...(1)
where, \(m_1 = M-2m\) is the mass of the Ladder 1
\(\Delta y_1 = y\) is the displacement of the Ladder 1
\(m_2 = 2m\) is the mass of the Monkey 2
\(\Delta y_2 = l+y\) is the displacement of the Monkey 2
\(m_3 = M-m\) is the mass of Ladder 2
\(\Delta y_3 = -y\) is the displacement of Ladder 2
\(m_4 = m\) is the mass of Monkey 2
\(\Delta y_4 = \dfrac{l}{2}-y\) is the displacement of Monkey 2
On substituting these values in equation (1), we get
\(\Delta y_{cm} = \dfrac{(M-2m)(y)+2m(l+y) - (M-m)y + m(\dfrac{l}{2}-y)}{(M-2m)+2m+(M-m)+m} = \dfrac{5ml}{4M}\)
\(\Rightarrow \Delta y_{cm} = \dfrac{5ml}{4M}\)
To calculate the displacement of ladder, let us consider ‘Ladder 1 and Monkey 1’ as System 1 and ‘Ladder 2 and Monkey 2’ as System 2.

DIAGRAM[3,200]

Since both the systems have equal mass and equal net external forces, and initially both are at rest, so the displacements of centre of mass of both the systems should be equal.
questions.hint: Consider the system of monkeys and ladders.  When the monkeys move, they exert forces on the ladders, changing the tension in the rope and causing the center of mass to shift. Since the pulley and rope are light and the pulley is frictionless, the two monkeys + ladder form systems of equal mass. At equilibrium, tension in the string balances the total weight.
methodOfSolving: Consider the monkeys and ladders as a system.
Determine the displacements of each ladder and monkey.
Use the formula for the displacement of the center of mass: \(\Delta y_{cm} = \dfrac{\sum m_i \Delta y_i}{\sum m_i}\).

To find the displacement of the ladders, consider two separate systems: 'Ladder 1 and Monkey 1', and 'Ladder 2 and Monkey 2'.  These systems have equal mass and are subject to equal and opposite external forces (from the tension in the rope).
Since the initial velocities are zero, their center of mass displacements are equal.

questions.title: Amplitude of Wedge Oscillation after Ball Impact
questions.questionText: A ball of mass \(m\) when dropped from certain height strikes a wedge \(M\) kept on smooth horizontal surface and move horizontally just after impact as shown in diagram.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nIf the ball strikes the ground at a distance \(d\) from its initial line of fall, determine the amplitude of oscillation of wedge after being hit by the ball.
questions.solution:
Since, \(h = \dfrac{1}{2}gt^2\Rightarrow t = \sqrt{\dfrac{2h}{g}}\)
Let \(v_1\) be the horizontal velocity of ball after collision. Then \(d = v_1t\Rightarrow v_1 = \dfrac{d}{t} = d\sqrt{\dfrac{g}{2h}}\)
Suppose, \(v_2\) be the velocity of wedge just after collision. Then from conservation of linear momentum, we have, \(Mv_2 = mv_1\Rightarrow v_2 = \dfrac{m}{M}v_1 = \dfrac{md}{M}\sqrt{\dfrac{g}{2h}}\)
By Law of Conservation of Energy, we have
\(\dfrac{1}{2}kA^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}Mv_2^2\)
\(\Rightarrow 	ext{Amplitude, } A = v_2\sqrt{\dfrac{M}{k}} = \dfrac{md}{M}\sqrt{\dfrac{gM}{2hk}}\)
questions.hint: Use conservation of energy to find the time of fall of the ball.  The horizontal distance traveled by the ball is related to its horizontal velocity and the time of fall.  Apply conservation of momentum during the collision and conservation of energy for the wedge-spring system.
methodOfSolving: Calculate the time of fall \(t\) using the equation of motion for vertical displacement.
Determine the horizontal velocity \(v_1\) of the ball after impact: \(d = v_1 t\).
Apply conservation of linear momentum to find the velocity \(v_2\) of the wedge just after collision: \(Mv_2 = mv_1\).
Use conservation of energy for the wedge-spring system: \(\dfrac{1}{2}kA^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}Mv_2^2\). Solve for the amplitude \(A\).

questions.title: Minimum Collisions for Reduced Pendulum Amplitude
questions.questionText: A simple pendulum is suspended from a peg on a vertical wall. The pendulum is pulled away from the wall to a horizontal position (see figure) and released.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nThe ball hits the wall, the coefficient of restitution being \(\dfrac{2}{\sqrt{5}}\). What is the minimum number of collisions after which the amplitude of oscillation becomes less than 60 degrees?
questions.solution:
As shown in figure initially when the bob is at A, its potential energy is \(mgl\).

DIAGRAM[2,200]

When the bob is released and it strikes the wall at B, its potential energy \(mgl\) is converted into its kinetic energy. If \(v\) be the velocity with which the bob strikes the wall, then
\(mgl = \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2\) or \(v = \sqrt{2gl}\) ...(1)
Speed of the bob after rebounding (first time) \(v_1 = ev = e\sqrt{2gl}\) ...(2)
The speed after second rebound is \(v_2 = e^2\sqrt{2gl}\)
In general, after \(n\) rebounds, the speed of the bob is \(v_n = e^n\sqrt{2gl}\) ...(3)
Let the bob rises to a height \(h\) after \(n\) rebounds. Applying the Law of Conservation of Energy, we have \(\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 = mgh\)
\(\Rightarrow h = \dfrac{v_n^2}{2g} = (e^{2n})(2gl) = le^{2n}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{h}{l} = \left(\dfrac{2}{5}ight)^n = \left(\dfrac{4}{5}ight)^n\) ...(4)
If \(	heta_n\) be the angle after \(n\) collisions, then \(h = l - l\cos	heta_n = l(1-\cos	heta_n)\) ...(5)
From equations (4) and (5), we have
\(\left(\dfrac{4}{5}ight)^n = (1-\cos	heta_n)\)
For \(	heta_n\) to be less than \(60^\circ\) i.e., \(\cos	heta_n\) is greater than \(\dfrac{1}{2}\), i.e., \((1-\cos	heta_n)\) is less than \(\dfrac{1}{2}\), we have
\(\left(\dfrac{4}{5}ight)^n < \left(\dfrac{1}{2}ight)\)
This condition is satisfied for \(n=4\).
So, required number of collisions is 4.
questions.hint: The initial potential energy of the bob is converted into kinetic energy just before the collision. The coefficient of restitution relates the velocities before and after each collision.  The maximum angle of swing after each collision is related to the bob's height. Repeated use of equation (5) with replacement of h with new h leads to required condition. Also, use of logs with required condition leads to required n.
methodOfSolving: Calculate the velocity of the bob just before the first collision using energy conservation.
Determine the velocity after each collision using the coefficient of restitution.
Relate the height \(h\) reached after each collision to the velocity after collision using energy conservation.
Connect the height \(h\) to the angle \(\theta_n\) using trigonometry.
Find the number of collisions \(n\) for which \(\theta_n < 60^\circ\).

questions.title: Collision of Two Spheres on a Horizontal Table
questions.questionText: Two smooth spheres \(A\) and \(B\), of equal radius but masses \(m\) and \(M\), are free to move on a horizontal table. \(A\) is projected with speed \(u\) towards \(B\) which is at rest. On impact, the line joining their centres is inclined at an angle \(\theta\) to the velocity of A before impact. If \(e\) is the coefficient of restitution between the spheres, find the speed with which \(B\) begins to move. If \(A\)'s path after impact is perpendicular to its path before impact, show that \(\tan^2\theta = \dfrac{eM-m}{M+m}\).
questions.solution:
When \(B\) is struck by the impulse \(J\), it begins to move in the direction of \(J\) as shown in the diagram.

DIAGRAM[1,200]

Along the line of centres, we apply
(a) Conservation of Linear Momentum,
\(mu\cos	heta = MV \) ...(1)
(b) Law of restitution,
\(eu\cos	heta = V + v\) ...(2)
Solving equations (1) and (2), we get
\(v = \dfrac{(eM-m)u\cos	heta}{(M+m)}\)
and \(V = \dfrac{(1+e)mu\cos	heta}{M+m}\)
Hence, \(	an\phi = \dfrac{u\sin	heta}{v} = \dfrac{(M+m)u\sin	heta}{(eM-m)u\cos	heta} = \dfrac{(M+m)	an	heta}{(eM-m)}\)
But the paths of A before and after impact are at right angles, therefore, \(\cot\phi = 	an	heta\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{(eM-m)	an	heta}{M+m} = 	an	heta\)
\(\Rightarrow 	an^2	heta = \dfrac{eM-m}{M+m}\)
questions.hint: Apply the principles of conservation of linear momentum and the law of restitution along the line of centers.  The velocity of A perpendicular to the line of centers remains unchanged.  Use the given condition about A's path to relate the angles θ and φ.
methodOfSolving: Apply conservation of linear momentum along the line of centers: \(mu\cos\theta = MV - mv\), where \(V\) is the velocity of \(B\) and \(v\) is the component of \(A\)'s velocity along the line of centers after impact.
Apply the law of restitution along the line of centers:  \(e u\cos\theta = V + v\).
Solve the above two equations for \(v\) and \(V\).
The component of \(A\)'s velocity perpendicular to the line of centers remains unchanged: \(u\sin\theta\).
\(\tan\phi = \dfrac{u\sin\theta}{v}\), where φ is the angle A's velocity makes after impact.
Use the given condition that A's path after impact is perpendicular to its path before impact, which implies \(\cot\phi = \tan\theta\).
Solve the resulting equation to show that \(\tan^2\theta = \dfrac{eM-m}{M+m}\).

questions.title: Fraction of Kinetic Energy Converted to Potential Energy in Elastic Collision
questions.questionText: A ball moving translationally collides elastically with another stationary ball of the same mass. At the moment of impact the angle between the straight line passing through the centres of the balls and the direction of the initial motion of the striking ball is equal to \(\alpha = 45^\circ\). Assuming the balls to be smooth, find the fraction \(\eta\) of the kinetic energy of the striking ball that turned into potential energy at the moment of the maximum deformation.
questions.solution:
Let a ball of mass \(m\) with velocity \(u\) collides with stationary ball as shown in figure.

DIAGRAM[1,150]

Applying the Law of Conservation of Momentum along x-axis, we have
\(mu\cos\alpha = mv_{1x} + mv_{2x}\)
At the moment of maximum deformation \(v_{1x} = v_{2x}\)
\(\Rightarrow u\cos\alpha = v_{1x} + v_{2x} = 2v_{1x}\) or \(v_{1x} = \dfrac{u\cos\alpha}{2}\)
Initial kinetic energy, \(K_{initial} = \dfrac{1}{2}mu^2\)
Final kinetic energy, \(K_{final} = \dfrac{1}{2}mv_{1x}^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}mv_{1y}^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}mv_{2x}^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}mv_{1y}^2\)
\(\Rightarrow K_{final} = \dfrac{1}{2}mv_{1x}^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}mv_{1y}^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}mv_{2x}^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}mv_{2y}^2 = 2\left(\dfrac{1}{2}mv_{x}^2ight) + mv_{1y}^2\)
\(\Rightarrow K_{final} = \dfrac{mu^2\cos^2\alpha}{4} + \dfrac{mu^2\sin^2\alpha}{2} \)
\(\Rightarrow K_{final} = \dfrac{mu^2\cos^2 45^\circ}{4} + \dfrac{mu^2\sin^2 45^\circ}{2} = \dfrac{3mu^2}{8}\)
Therefore, potential energy at the moment of maximum deformation is
\(U = \dfrac{1}{2}mu^2 - \dfrac{3}{8}mu^2 = \dfrac{mu^2}{8}\)
So, the desired fraction \(\eta\) is given by
\(\eta = \dfrac{\dfrac{mu^2}{8}}{\dfrac{mu^2}{2}} = \dfrac{1}{4}=0.25\)
questions.hint: At the moment of maximum deformation, the velocities of the two balls are equal. Apply conservation of momentum along the x-axis and consider the kinetic energy before and after the collision.
methodOfSolving: Apply conservation of momentum along the x-axis.  At maximum deformation, the velocities of the balls along the line of centers are equal:  \(u\cos\alpha = v_{1x} + v_{2x} = 2v_{1x}\).
Calculate the initial kinetic energy: \(\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2\).
Calculate the final kinetic energy (at maximum deformation): \(\dfrac{1}{2}mv_{1x}^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}mv_{1y}^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}mv_{2x}^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}mv_{2y}^2\).
Find the potential energy at maximum deformation \(U\) by subtracting final kinetic energy from initial kinetic energy.
Calculate the fraction \(\eta = \dfrac{U}{\text{Initial Kinetic Energy}}\).

questions.title: Range of Coefficient of Restitution for Projectile on Inclined Plane
questions.questionText: A particle \(P\) is projected from a point \(O\) on a smooth plane inclined to the horizontal at \(\tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\). The particle is projected at \(\tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{3}{4}\right)\) to the plane. It hits the plane at higher point \(A\) and rebounds. Find the possible range of the coefficient of restitution \(e\) if the particle \(P\) continues to move up the plane after the impact.
questions.solution:
Time of flight of the particle is

DIAGRAM[1,350]
\(T = \dfrac{2u_y}{g\cos eta} = \dfrac{2u\sin\alpha}{g\cos eta} = \dfrac{\left(2uight)\left(\dfrac{3}{5}ight)}{g\left(\dfrac{2}{\sqrt{5}}ight)} = \dfrac{3u}{\sqrt{5}g}\)
At A, \(v_x = u_x + a_xT\) and \(v_y = u_y + a_yT\)
Substituting values, we get
\(v_x = \dfrac{4}{5}u\)
\(v_y = -\dfrac{3}{5}u\)

DIAGRAM[2,350]
From the Figure, we get \(u = e\left(\dfrac{3}{5}uight)\)
Just after impact, the resultant velocity \(v'\) of \(P\) is inclined to the plane at an angle \(	heta\), where
\(	an	heta = \dfrac{\left(\dfrac{3}{5}ight)eu}{u} = 3e\)
DIAGRAM[3,280]

P continues to move up the plane if, \(	heta < \phi\), where \(\phi = \dfrac{\pi}{2} -  eta\)
\(\Rightarrow 	an	heta < 	an\left(\dfrac{\pi}{2} -  etaight)\)
\(\Rightarrow 	an	heta < \cot eta\)
\(\Rightarrow 3e < \dfrac{2}{1}\)
\(\Rightarrow e < \dfrac{2}{3}\)
Since, we also know that \(e \ge 0\), so the possible range of e is \(0 \le e \le \dfrac{2}{3}\)
questions.hint: Calculate the time of flight of the projectile. Then, consider the components of velocity just before and just after the impact.  For the particle to continue moving up the plane after impact, the angle its velocity makes with the plane must be less than the complement of the inclination angle.
methodOfSolving: Calculate the time of flight \(T\) using the equation \(T = \dfrac{2u\sin\alpha}{g\cos\beta}\).
Determine the components of the velocity just before impact using the equations of motion.
Apply the definition of coefficient of restitution along the line perpendicular to the inclined plane to relate velocities before and after impact.
Calculate \(\tan\theta\), where \(\theta\) is the angle of the velocity with the inclined plane after impact.
The particle will move up the plane if \(\theta\) is less than \(\phi = \dfrac{\pi}{2} - \beta\).  Apply this condition to find the range of \(e\).

questions.title: Velocity of Particle in a Three-Particle System
questions.questionText: Three particles \(A\), \(B\) and \(C\) of mass \(m\), \(2m\) and \(3m\) respectively lie on a smooth horizontal table at the vertices of an equilateral triangle. \(A\) and \(B\) as well as \(B\) and \(C\) are connected by light inextensible strings. \(C\) is given a velocity \(v_0\) parallel to \(AB\) as shown in Figure.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nShow that \(A\) eventually begins to move with a velocity \(\dfrac{2v_0}{19}\).
questions.solution:
For B-C system, by Law of Conservation of Momentum along y-direction, we have
\(0 = 3mv_{Cy} + 2mv_{By}\)
\(\Rightarrow v_{Cy} = -\dfrac{2}{3}v_{By}\)
If \(v_1\) and \(-v_2\) be the x and y components of final velocity of B, then \(v_{By} = -v_2\)
\(\Rightarrow v_{Cy} = \dfrac{2}{3}v_2\)

DIAGRAM[2,400] 

\(\Rightarrow\) \(v_0 = v_1 + v_3\) ...(1)
Components of velocities along BC for particles B and C will be equal. Hence,
\(v_1\cos 60^\circ + v_2\cos 30^\circ = v_3\cos 60^\circ - v_2\cos 30^\circ\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{v_1}{2} + \dfrac{\sqrt{3}v_2}{2} = \dfrac{v_3}{2} - \dfrac{\sqrt{3}v_2}{6}\)
\(\Rightarrow v_1 - v_3 + \dfrac{5}{\sqrt{3}}v_2 = 0\) ...(2)
Now, since Impulse = Change in Momentum, so for C, we have
Along x-axis, \(J\cos(60^\circ) = 3m(v_0-v_3)\Rightarrow \dfrac{1}{2}J = 3m(v_0-v_3)\) ...(3)
Along y-axis, \(J\cos(30^\circ) = 3m\left(\dfrac{2}{3}v_2ight) \Rightarrow \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}J = 2mv_2\) ...(4)
Solving equations (1), (2), (3) and (4) we get \(v_1 = \dfrac{2}{19}v_0\).
questions.hint: Use conservation of momentum and the fact that the components of velocities along the strings must be equal for connected particles. Consider impulse to relate the change in momentum of particle C to the tension in the strings.
methodOfSolving: Apply conservation of momentum along the y-direction for the B-C system.
The components of velocities along the strings BC and AB must be equal. This provides constraint equations.
Apply conservation of momentum for the entire system along the x-direction.
Apply the impulse-momentum theorem to particle C. The impulse due to tension in BC and BA changes C's momentum.
Solve the resulting equations to find \(v_1\), the x-component of B's velocity, which will eventually be the velocity of A.

questions.title: Collisions of Two Spheres with Different Masses
questions.questionText:
A large heavy sphere and a small light sphere are dropped onto a flat surface from a height \(h\). The large sphere collides with the surface with velocity \(v_0\) and immediately thereafter with the small sphere. The spheres are dropped so that all motion is vertical before the second collision and the small sphere hits the larger sphere at an angle \(\alpha\) from its upper most point, as shown in Figure. If all collisions are perfectly elastic and there is no surface friction between the spheres.
DIAGRAM[1,200]
(a) Find the angle made by velocity vector of small sphere with the vertical just after the second collision in the frame of large sphere.
(b) Find the vertical velocity of smaller sphere just after the collision with respect to ground.
questions.solution:
Since collision is elastic, so angle of reflection is same as that of incidence angle. In frame of big sphere, small sphere will rebound at an angle \(2\alpha\) with vertical as shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[2,200]

In frame of larger sphere, the smaller sphere is travelling with \(2v_0\) before second collision. Since larger sphere is massive in comparison to smaller sphere, so the smaller sphere will rebound with same velocity \(2v_0\) as collision is elastic and surface is frictionless. The small sphere will reflect at same angle.
questions.hint: (a) In the frame of the large sphere, the collision is elastic and occurs on a horizontal surface. The angle of reflection is equal to the angle of incidence.\n(b) Consider the relative velocity of the small sphere with respect to the large sphere before the collision. Since the large sphere is much heavier, its velocity doesn't change significantly after the collision.
methodOfSolving: (a) Determine the angle of reflection of the small sphere in the frame of reference of the large sphere, which is equal to the angle of incidence.

(b) Find the relative velocity of the small sphere with respect to the large sphere before the collision. Since the large sphere is much more massive, the small sphere rebounds with the same relative velocity but in the opposite direction. Calculate the vertical velocity with respect to the ground.

questions.title: Velocity of Ball After String Becomes Taut
questions.questionText: Two particles \(A\) and \(B\) each of mass \(m\) are attached by a light inextensible string of length \(2l\). The whole system lies on a smooth horizontal table with \(B\) initially at a distance \(l\) from \(A\). The particle at end \(B\) is projected across the table with speed \(u\) perpendicular to \(AB\). Find the velocity of ball \(A\) just after the string is taut.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
When the string becomes taut both particles begin to move with velocity components \(v\) in the direction AB.
Applying Law of Conservation of Linear Momentum in the direction AB, we get \(mu\cos 30^\circ = mv + mv\Rightarrow v = \dfrac{u\sqrt{3}}{4}\)

DIAGRAM[2,200]

Hence, the velocity of ball A just after the string becomes taut is \(\dfrac{u\sqrt{3}}{4}\).
questions.hint: When the string becomes taut, an impulse acts on both particles, causing a change in momentum.  The velocity component perpendicular to the string for particle B remains unchanged. Apply conservation of momentum along the direction of the string.
methodOfSolving: When the string becomes taut, both particles will have a velocity component \(v\) along the direction of the string AB.
Apply conservation of momentum along AB:  The initial momentum of B along AB is \(mu\cos30^\circ\). After the string is taut, both A and B have a velocity \(v\) along AB.
Thus, \(mu\cos30^\circ = 2mv\).  Solve for \(v\), which is the velocity of ball A just after the string becomes taut.

questions.title: Acceleration Ratio in a Bobbin-Block System
questions.questionText: A bobbin having inner radius \(r\) and outer radius \(R\) is placed on a rough horizontal surface. A light string wrapped on its inner core connects a block with the bobbin as shown in Figure.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nNow system is released from rest and bobbin moves on the horizontal surface without sliding. If the string does not slide from bobbin, calculate \(a/A\).
questions.solution:
Since the bobbin is in pure rolling, point \(P\) should be instantaneous centre (IC) of zero velocity. So, for pure rolling acceleration of the point of contact is zero, hence we have
\(\vec{a}_P = \vec{0}\)
\(\Rightarrow \vec{a}_P = \vec{a}_{PC} + \vec{a}_C = \vec{0}\)
\(\Rightarrow R\alpha - A = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow A = R\alpha\) ...(1)
Acceleration of the point \(Q\) with respect to the centre of mass \(C\) is shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[2,300]

\(|a_c| = A = R\alpha\), \(|a_o| = a = \alpha(R-r)\)
\(\vec{a}_Q = \vec{a}_{QC} + \vec{a}_C\)
where, \(a_Q = a\), \(a_{QC}=-r\alpha\) and \(a_c = A = R\alpha\)
\(a_Q = a = A-r = (R-r)\alpha\)
Since point \(Q\) is directly connected with block, it means the magnitude of acceleration of the point \(Q\) should be equal to the acceleration of the block
\(a_Q = a = a(R-r)\) ...(2)
From Equation (1) and (2), we get \(\dfrac{a}{A} = \dfrac{R-r}{r} = 1 - \dfrac{r}{R}\)
questions.hint: For pure rolling, the acceleration of the point of contact is zero. The acceleration of any point on the bobbin can be expressed as the vector sum of the acceleration of the center of mass and the acceleration of that point relative to the center of mass.
methodOfSolving: For pure rolling, the instantaneous center of rotation is the point of contact \(P\), and its acceleration \(a_P\) is zero.
Express \(a_P\) as the sum of the acceleration of the center of mass \(a_C = A\) and the acceleration of P relative to C:  \(a_P = R\alpha - A = 0\), which gives \(A = R\alpha\).
The acceleration of point Q (where the string is attached) is the same as the acceleration of the block \(a\).
Express the acceleration of Q as the sum of the acceleration of the center of mass and the acceleration of Q relative to the center of mass: \(a_Q = \vec{a}_{QC} + \vec{a}_C\).
\(a_Q = a = A - r\alpha = (R-r)\alpha\).
Using the two expressions for \(a\) and \(A\), find the ratio \(a/A\).

questions.title: Minimum Coefficient of Friction for Lifting a Rod
questions.questionText: Calculate minimum coefficient of friction between a thin homogeneous rod and the floor for which a person can slowly lift the rod upwards without slipping on the floor by applying a force perpendicular to the rod.
questions.solution:
Consider the equilibrium of the rod when it is inclined at an angle \(\alpha\) with the horizontal. The forces acting on the rod are shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[1,200]

Let us consider torque about the point of intersection \(O'\) of the force of gravity \(mg\) and the force \(F\) applied by the person perpendicular to the rod. Since the torque due to these forces about this point \(O'\) is zero, so doing this eliminates the unknown force \(F\).
At equilibrium, we have
\((\Sigma 	au)_{about \, O'} = 0\)
Since, moment arm for \(N\) about \(O'\) is \(l\cos\alpha\), while that for friction about \(O'\) is \(\left(\dfrac{l}{\sin\alpha} + l\sin\alphaight)\)
\(\Rightarrow Nl\cos\alpha - fl\left(\dfrac{1}{\sin\alpha} + \sin\alphaight) = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow f = N\left(\dfrac{\cos\alpha \sin\alpha}{1+\sin^2\alpha}ight) = N\left(\dfrac{\cos\alpha\sin\alpha}{2\sin^2\alpha + \cos^2\alpha}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow f = N\left(\dfrac{1}{2	an\alpha + \cot\alpha}ight)\)
Since, \(f \le \mu N\)
\(\Rightarrow N\left(\dfrac{1}{2	an\alpha+\cot\alpha}ight) \le \mu N\)
\(\Rightarrow \mu \ge \dfrac{1}{2	an\alpha + \cot\alpha}\) ...(1)
For \(\mu\) to be minimum, we must have
\(2	an\alpha + \cot\alpha = 	ext{MAXIMUM}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{d}{d\alpha}(2	an\alpha + \cot\alpha) = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow 2\sec^2\alpha - \csc^2\alpha = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow 	an\alpha = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\)
Substituting this value in equation (1), we get
\(\mu_{min} = \dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{2}}\)
questions.hint: Consider the forces acting on the rod: weight, normal reaction from the floor, friction force, and the applied force. For equilibrium, the net torque about any point must be zero. To eliminate the unknown applied force \(F\), choose the intersection of \(mg\) and \(F\) as the pivot point.
methodOfSolving: Draw a free body diagram of the rod, showing all the forces.
Choose the point of intersection of \(mg\) and \(F\) as the pivot point \(O'\).
Write the torque equilibrium equation about \(O'\): \(Nl\cos\alpha - fl(\dfrac{1}{\sin\alpha} + \sin\alpha) = 0\).
Express the friction force \(f\) in terms of the normal reaction \(N\) and \(\alpha\).
Use the condition \(f \le \mu N\) to find a relationship between \(\mu\) and \(\alpha\).
To minimize \(\mu\), maximize \(2\tan\alpha + \cot\alpha\) by taking its derivative with respect to \(\alpha\) and setting it to zero.
Solve for \(\alpha\) and substitute it back into the inequality for \(\mu\) to find \(\mu_{min}\).

questions.title: Condition for Pulling a Larger Roller Over a Smaller One
questions.questionText: Consider two heavy right circular rollers of radii \(R\) and \(r\), respectively at rest on a rough horizontal plane as shown in Figure.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nThe larger roller has a string wound around it to which a horizontal force \(P\) can be applied. Assume the coefficient of friction \(\mu\) has the same value for all surfaces in contact, calculate the necessary condition under which the larger roller can be pulled over the smaller one. Assume the smaller cylinder should neither roll nor slide.
questions.solution:
Let \(N_1\) be the reaction between the two cylinders and \(N_2\) be the normal reaction between the smaller cylinder and the horizontal surface. The forces acting on the smaller cylinder have been shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[2,350]

At equilibrium, we have
\(\Sigma F_x = N_1\cos\alpha - \mu N_2 - \mu N_1\cos(90-\alpha) = 0\) ...(1)
Also, torque about \(O_2\) (centre of smaller sphere) is zero, so we get
\(\Sigma 	au = \mu N_1 r - \mu N_2 r = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow N_1 = N_2\) ...(2)
Substituting equation (2) in equation (1), we get
\(\mu N_1 + \mu N_1\sin\alpha = N_1\cos\alpha\)
\(\Rightarrow \mu(1+\sin\alpha) = \cos\alpha\) ...(3)
Also, we see that \(\sin\alpha = \dfrac{R-r}{R+r}\)
\(\Rightarrow \cos\alpha = \sqrt{1-\sin^2\alpha} = \dfrac{2\sqrt{Rr}}{R+r}\)
Substituting these values in equation (3), we get
\(\mu\left(1 + \dfrac{R-r}{R+r}ight) = \dfrac{2\sqrt{Rr}}{R+r}\)
\(\Rightarrow \mu = \sqrt{\dfrac{r}{R}}\)
Hence the required condition is \(\mu \ge \sqrt{\dfrac{r}{R}}\).
questions.hint: Consider the forces acting on the smaller roller: the normal reaction from the larger roller, the normal reaction from the ground, and the friction forces. For the smaller roller to neither roll nor slide, the net force and net torque on it must be zero. Also, normal reaction betweeen floor and small cylinder must be same as that between cylinder themselves. As torque is taken at O2.
methodOfSolving: Draw a free body diagram for the smaller roller.
Write the equilibrium equations for forces in the horizontal direction:  \(N_1\cos\alpha - \mu N_2 - \mu N_1 \sin\alpha = 0\).
Write the torque equilibrium equation about the center of the smaller roller:  \(\mu N_1 r = \mu N_2 r\), which gives \(N_1 = N_2\).
Substitute \(N_1 = N_2\) into the force equilibrium equation.
Express \(\sin\alpha\) and \(\cos\alpha\) in terms of \(R\) and \(r\) using the geometry of the problem.
Substitute these values into the force equilibrium equation and solve for the condition on \(\mu\).

questions.title: Tension Reduction in a Suspended Rod
questions.questionText: A uniform rod \(AB\) of mass \(m\) and length \(2l\) is suspended by two strings \(OA\) and \(OB\) of equal length attached to a fixed point \(O\). The rod is at rest in a horizontal position and each string makes an angle \(\alpha\) with the horizontal.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nIf the string \(OB\) is cut, in what ratio the tension in \(OA\) will be instantaneously reduced?
questions.solution:
Initially \(2T_i\sin\alpha = mg\Rightarrow T_i = \dfrac{mg}{2\sin\alpha}\) ...(1)
When the string \(OB\) is cut, let the tension in string \(OA\) be \(T_f\), then equations of motion for centre of mass of rod are

DIAGRAM[2,200]

\(a_x = \dfrac{T_f\cos\alpha}{m}\) ...(2)
\(a_y = \dfrac{mg - T_f\sin\alpha}{m}\) ...(3)
If \(\alpha\) be the angular acceleration of the rod about its centre of mass \(C\), then
\(\alpha = \dfrac{T_f(l\sin\alpha)}{\dfrac{ml(2l)^2}{12}} = \dfrac{3T_f\sin\alpha}{ml}\) ...(4)
At the instant \(OB\) is cut, point \(A\) moves perpendicular to \(OA\), so acceleration of point \(A\) along \(AO\) should be zero, so

DIAGRAM[3,150]

\(a_x\cos\alpha + l\alpha\sin\alpha = a_y\sin\alpha\)
Substituting the values, we get
\(\dfrac{T_f\cos^2\alpha}{m} + \dfrac{3T_f\sin^2\alpha}{m} = \dfrac{(mg-T_f\sin\alpha)\sin\alpha}{m}\)
Solving this equation, we get \(T_f = \dfrac{mg\sin\alpha}{\cos^2\alpha + 4\sin^2\alpha}\) ...(5)
From equations (1) and (5), we get
\(\dfrac{T_f}{T_i} = \dfrac{2\sin^2\alpha}{\cos^2\alpha + 4\sin^2\alpha} = \dfrac{2\sin^2\alpha}{1+3\sin^2\alpha}\)
questions.hint: Initially, the tensions in both strings support the weight of the rod. When string OB is cut, the tension in OA changes, and the rod experiences both linear and angular acceleration. The acceleration of point A must be perpendicular to OA.
methodOfSolving: Write the initial equilibrium condition: \(2T_i\sin\alpha = mg\).
When OB is cut, let the new tension in OA be \(T_f\).  Write equations for the horizontal and vertical accelerations of the center of mass.
Calculate the angular acceleration of the rod about its center of mass.
The acceleration of point A is perpendicular to OA. Resolve the acceleration components and the angular acceleration to write an equation for the motion of point A.
Solve for \(T_f\).
Find the ratio \(T_f/T_i\).

questions.title: Angle of Inclination of a Pulled Hemisphere
questions.questionText: A hemisphere of radius \(r\) and mass \(M\) is pulled by means of a string (Figure) so that it moves with a uniform velocity. If \(\mu\) is the coefficient of friction with the surface, find the angle of inclination of the hemisphere. Given that the centre of gravity of the hemisphere lies at a distance \(\dfrac{3r}{8}\) from centre.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
The hemisphere is moving with uniform velocity. Hence, it is in equilibrium, both rotational as well as translational. So,
\(N = mg\) ...(1)
\(F = \mu N\) ...(2)

DIAGRAM[2,200]

For rotational equilibrium about the bottom-most point,
\(\sum 	au_{bottom-most \, point} = 0\)
\(\Rightarrow F(r-r\sin	heta) - mg\left(\dfrac{3r}{8}\sin	hetaight) = 0\) ...(3)
Solving equations (1), (2) and (3), we get
\(\sin	heta = \dfrac{8\mu}{3+8\mu}\)
questions.hint: Since the velocity is uniform, the hemisphere is in translational and rotational equilibrium. The net force and the net torque about any point must be zero. Consider the forces acting on the hemisphere: weight, normal reaction, friction force, and the applied force. Apply the conditions of equilibrium. Since, the centre of mass is \(\dfrac{3r}{8}\) from the centre of the hemisphere. The moment arm for the pulling force is measured from the bottom most point which is instantaneous center of rotation with respect to ground.
methodOfSolving: Write the equations for translational equilibrium: \(N = Mg\) and \(F = \mu N\).
Choose the bottom-most point as the pivot and write the equation for rotational equilibrium:  \(F(r - r\sin\theta) = Mg(\dfrac{3r}{8}\sin\theta)\).
Solve the equations to find \(\sin\theta\).

questions.title: Angular Velocity of Rod After Sticking to Hook
questions.questionText: A rod of mass \(M\) and length \(L\) is falling vertically with speed \(v\). Suddenly its one end gets stuck in a frictionless hook.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nFind the angular velocity of the rod just after its end gets stuck.
questions.solution:
Since all the impulse forces during the impact are applied by the hook so they don’t produce any torque about the hook and hence angular momentum of the rod about the hook is conserved.
Initial angular momentum about hook is
\(H_i = mvr_\perp = Mv\left(\dfrac{L}{2}ight)\)
Final angular momentum about the hook is
\(H_f = I\omega = \left(\dfrac{ML^2}{3}ight)\omega\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{MvL}{2} = \dfrac{ML^2}{3}\omega\)
\(\Rightarrow \omega = \dfrac{3v}{2L}\)
questions.hint: Consider the conservation of angular momentum about the hook. The impulse forces during the impact act at the hook, so they don't produce any torque about the hook.
methodOfSolving: Calculate the initial angular momentum of the rod about the hook: \(H_i = Mv(\dfrac{L}{2})\).
Calculate the final angular momentum of the rod about the hook: \(H_f = I\omega\), where \(I = \dfrac{ML^2}{3}\) is the moment of inertia of the rod about the hook.
Apply conservation of angular momentum: \(H_i = H_f\).
Solve for \(\omega\).

questions.title: Final Linear and Angular Velocity of Rolling Discs
questions.questionText: The assembly of two discs as shown in Figure is placed on a rough horizontal surface and the front disc is given an initial angular velocity \(\omega_0\). \nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nDetermine the final linear and angular velocity when both the discs start rolling. It is given that friction is sufficient to sustain rolling in the rear wheel from the beginning of motion.
questions.solution:
By Law of Conservation of Angular Momentum, we have \(L_i = L_f\) {about bottom most point}

DIAGRAM[2,200]

\(I\omega_0 = 2(I\omega + mRv)\)
\(\Rightarrow \left(\dfrac{1}{2}mR^2ight)\omega_0 = 2\left(\dfrac{1}{2}mR^2\omega + mR(\omega R)ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow \omega = \dfrac{\omega_0}{6}\)
\(\Rightarrow v = \omega R = \dfrac{\omega_0 R}{6}\)
questions.hint: Consider the conservation of angular momentum of the system about the point of contact of the rear disc with the ground. When both discs are rolling, their linear velocities are related to their angular velocities.
methodOfSolving: Apply the conservation of angular momentum about the point of contact of the rear disc. The initial angular momentum is \(I\omega_0\). The final angular momentum is the sum of angular momentum about center of masses and angular momentum of center of mass about point of contact.
When rolling starts, \(v = \omega R\) for both discs, where \(v\) is the linear velocity and \(\omega\) is the angular velocity.
Solve for \(v\) and \(\omega\).

questions.title: Maximum Torque on a Cylinder on an Oscillating Platform
questions.questionText:
A cylinder of mass \(m\) and radius \(R\) is resting on a horizontal platform (which is parallel to \(xy\) plane) with its axis fixed along the \(y\)-axis and free to rotate about its axis as shown in Figure.
DIAGRAM[1,250]
\(x = A\cos(\omega t)\)
The platform is given a motion in the \(x\)-direction given by \(x = A\cos(\omega t)\). There is no slipping between the cylinder and platform. Calculate the maximum torque acting on the cylinder during its motion.
questions.solution:
We must know that maximum torque will act on cylinder when it is ta the extreme positions of oscillatory motion. The cylinder moves under the influence of pseudo force with respect to platform as shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[2,150]

Thus, equation of motion of cylinder is
\(mA\omega^2\cos\omega t = f = ma_{max}\) ...(1)
and \(fR = \dfrac{1}{2}mR^2\left(\dfrac{a_{max}}{R}ight)\) ...(2)
Adding (1) and (2), we get \(A\omega^2 = \dfrac{3}{2}a_{max}\Rightarrow a_{max} = \dfrac{2A\omega^2}{3}\)
Maximum angular acceleration is \(\alpha_{max} = \dfrac{a_{max}}{R} = \dfrac{2A\omega^2}{3R}\)
Maximum torque on cylinder is
\(	au_{max} = I\alpha_{max}\)
\(\Rightarrow 	au_{max} = \dfrac{1}{2}MR^2\left(\dfrac{2A\omega^2}{3R}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow 	au_{max} = \dfrac{1}{3}mAR\omega^2\)
questions.hint: The maximum torque acts on the cylinder when the platform is at its extreme positions. Consider the pseudo force acting on the cylinder and use the equations of motion for rotational motion.
methodOfSolving: The maximum torque will occur at the extreme positions of the platform's motion, where the pseudo force is maximum.
Draw a free body diagram of the cylinder showing the pseudo force and the friction force.
Write the equation of motion for the cylinder: \(mA\omega^2 = f = ma_{max}\).
Relate the friction force \(f\) to the angular acceleration \(\alpha\): \(fR = \dfrac{1}{2}mR^2 \alpha\).
Solve for \(a_{max}\).
Find the maximum angular acceleration: \(\alpha_{max} = \dfrac{a_{max}}{R}\).
Calculate the maximum torque: \(\tau_{max} = I\alpha_{max}\), where \(I = \dfrac{1}{2}mR^2\).

questions.title: Time of Rise for Sphere on Inclined Plane
questions.questionText: A sphere of radius \(r\) is projected up an inclined plane for which \(\mu = \dfrac{1}{7}\tan\theta\) with a velocity \(v_0\) and initial angular velocity \(\omega_0\) such that, \(v_0 > r\omega_0\). \nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nFind the total time of rise.
questions.solution:
Initially i.e., at \(t=0\), we have \(v_0 > r\omega_0\), therefore, there is forward slipping. Hence, friction will be down the incline.
Once \(v = r\omega\), force of friction becomes up the incline, so
\(a = \dfrac{-\mu mg\cos	heta + mg\sin	heta}{m} = \dfrac{8}{7}g\sin	heta \quad \left\{  ecause \mu = \dfrac{1}{7}	an	heta ight\}\)
Also, \(\alpha = \dfrac{	au}{I} = \dfrac{\mu mg\cos	heta}{\dfrac{2}{5}mr^2}r = \dfrac{5g\sin	heta}{14} \quad \left\{  ecause \mu = \dfrac{1}{7}	an	heta ight\}\)

DIAGRAM[2,200]

This will last till pure rolling begins, so \(v = r\omega\)
\(\Rightarrow (v_0 - at_1) = r(\omega_0+\alpha t_1)\)
Substituting the values, we get \(t_1 = \dfrac{2}{3}\left(\dfrac{v_0-r\omega_0}{g\sin	heta}ight)\)
Since \(v = v_0 - at_1\)
\(\Rightarrow v = v_0 - \left(\dfrac{8}{7}g\sin	hetaight)\left(\dfrac{2}{3}ight)\left(\dfrac{v_0-r\omega_0}{g\sin	heta}ight)\)
\(\Rightarrow v = \dfrac{5}{21}v_0 + \dfrac{16}{21}r\omega_0\)
Once \(v=r\omega\) i.e., the condition of pure rolling is obtained, then minimum value of \(\mu\) required to maintain pure rolling is
\(\mu_{min} = \dfrac{	an	heta}{1+\dfrac{mr^2}{I}} = \dfrac{	an	heta}{1+\dfrac{5}{2}} = \dfrac{tan	heta}{3.5}\)
However, \(\mu_{given} = \dfrac{1}{7}	an	heta\) and since \(\mu_{given} < \mu_{min}\) so slipping will occur even after that and so the force of friction is upwards and maximum.
So, linear retardation is
\(a' = g\sin	heta - \mu g\cos	heta = \dfrac{6}{7}g\sin	heta\)
If \(t_2\) be the further time taken by sphere to rise, then \(0 = v - a't_2\)
\(\Rightarrow t_2 = \dfrac{v}{a'} = \dfrac{\dfrac{5}{21}v_0 + \dfrac{16}{21}r\omega_0}{\dfrac{6}{7}g\sin	heta} = \dfrac{5v_0+16r\omega_0}{18g\sin	heta}\)
So, we get, \(T = t_1+t_2 = \dfrac{17v_0 + 4r\omega_0}{18g\sin	heta}\)
questions.hint: Initially, the sphere is slipping, so the friction force acts down the incline. When pure rolling begins (v=rω), the direction of friction may reverse. Find the time taken for pure rolling to begin.  Then, find the time taken for the sphere to come to rest after pure rolling starts.
methodOfSolving: Determine the initial direction of friction.
Calculate linear acceleration \(a\) and angular acceleration \(\alpha\).
Find the time \(t_1\) for pure rolling to begin (\(v=r\omega\)).  Use \(v = v_0 - at\) and \(\omega = \omega_0 + \alpha t\).
Calculate the velocity \(v\) when pure rolling begins.
Determine the minimum coefficient of friction \(\mu_{min}\) required to maintain pure rolling.
Compare \(\mu_{given}\) with \(\mu_{min}\) to determine if slipping continues after pure rolling starts.
Calculate the new linear deceleration \(a'\) after pure rolling begins.
Calculate the time \(t_2\) for the sphere to stop after pure rolling begins.
The total time of rise is \(T = t_1 + t_2\).

questions.title: Torque on a Cylinder in a V-Shaped Groove
questions.questionText: A cylinder of mass \(M\) and radius \(R\) is rotated in a uniform V-shaped groove with constant angular velocity \(\omega\). The coefficient of friction between the cylinder and each surface is \(\mu\). \nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nWhat torque must be applied to the cylinder to keep it rotating?
questions.solution:
The forces acting on the cylinder are shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[2,200]

For vertical equilibrium of cylinder, we have
\(N_1\cos 45^\circ + N_2\cos 45^\circ + \mu N_1\cos 45^\circ = \mu N_2\cos 45^\circ + Mg\)
\(\Rightarrow N_1(1+\mu) + N_2(1-\mu) = \sqrt{2}Mg\) ...(1)
For horizontal equilibrium of cylinder,
\(N_1\sin 45^\circ = N_2\sin 45^\circ + \mu N_1\sin 45^\circ + \mu N_2\sin 45^\circ\)
\(\Rightarrow N_1(1-\mu) - N_2(1+\mu) = 0\) ...(2)
Solving these two equations, we get
\(2N_1(1+\mu^2) = \sqrt{2}Mg(1+\mu)\)
\(\Rightarrow N_1 = \dfrac{\sqrt{2}Mg(1+\mu)}{2(1+\mu^2)}\)
From (2), we get
\(N_2 = \dfrac{\sqrt{2}Mg(1-\mu)}{2(1+\mu^2)}\)
The required torque is,
\(	au = \mu N_1 R + \mu N_2 R = \mu R(N_1+N_2)\)
\(\Rightarrow 	au = \dfrac{\sqrt{2}\mu MgR}{1+\mu^2}\)
questions.hint: Consider the forces acting on the cylinder: normal reactions from both sides of the groove, friction forces, and weight. For the cylinder to rotate at a constant angular velocity, it must be in equilibrium.  Apply the conditions for both translational and rotational equilibrium.
methodOfSolving: Draw a free body diagram of the cylinder, showing the forces acting on it.
Resolve the forces into horizontal and vertical components.
Write equations for vertical and horizontal equilibrium.
Solve these equations to find the normal reaction forces \(N_1\) and \(N_2\).
The required torque is the sum of the torques due to friction from both surfaces: \(\tau = \mu N_1 R + \mu N_2 R\).

questions.title: Distance Between Impacts of Ball and Plank
questions.questionText: A spherical ball of radius \(r\) and mass \(m\) collides with a plank of mass \(M\) kept on a smooth horizontal surface. Before impact, the centre of the ball has a velocity \(v_0\) and angular velocity \(\omega_0\), as shown in Figure.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nThe normal velocity is reversed with same magnitude and the ball stops rotating after the impact. Find the distance on the plank between first two impacts of the ball. The coefficient of friction between the ball and the plank is \(\mu\). Assume that plank is large enough.
questions.solution:
The forces during impact are shown in Figure.

DIAGRAM[2,200]

Let the horizontal velocities of the ball and the plank be \(v_1\) and \(v_2\) in opposite directions as shown in Figure, then by Law of Conservation of Linear Momentum in horizontal direction, we get \(mv_1 = Mv_2\) ...(1)
According to Impulse Momentum Theorem,
\(	ext{Linear Impulse on the ball in vertical direction} = 	ext{Change in Linear Momentum in vertical direction}\)
\(\Rightarrow J = \displaystyle\int Ndt = 2mv_0\) ...(2)
\(	ext{Linear Impulse on the ball in horizontal direction} = 	ext{Change in Linear Momentum in horizontal direction}\)
\(\Rightarrow \mu J = mv_1\) ...(3)
According to Angular Impulse Angular Momentum Theorem, we have
\(	ext{Angular Impulse on the ball about Centre of Mass} = 	ext{Change in Angular Momentum about Centre of Mass}\)
\(\Rightarrow (\mu J)r = I\omega_0 = \left(\dfrac{2}{5}mr^2ight)\omega_0\) ...(4)
Solving equations (1), (2), (3) and (4), we get \(v_1 = \dfrac{2}{5}r\omega_0\) and \(v_2 = \dfrac{m}{M}\left(\dfrac{2}{5}r\omega_0ight)\)
Now, actual path of the ball is a projectile whose time of flight will be \(T = \dfrac{2v_y}{g} = \dfrac{2v_0}{g}\)
Relative velocity of ball with respect to plank in horizontal direction is \(v_r = v_1+v_2 = \left(\dfrac{M+m}{M}ight)v_1 = \dfrac{2}{5}\left(\dfrac{M+m}{M}ight)r\omega_0\)
Therefore, the required distance is \(s = v_rT = \dfrac{4}{5}\left(\dfrac{M+m}{M}ight)\dfrac{v_0 r\omega_0}{g}\)
questions.hint: Consider the impulse-momentum theorem in both horizontal and vertical directions. The vertical impulse reverses the normal velocity.  The horizontal impulse, due to friction, changes the horizontal momentum of both the ball and the plank. The angular impulse stops the rotation of the ball. The actual path of the ball is projectile motion relative to the plank.
methodOfSolving: Apply the impulse-momentum theorem in the vertical direction: \(J = 2mv_0\).
Apply the impulse-momentum theorem in the horizontal direction: \(\mu J = mv_1\), where \(v_1\) is the horizontal velocity of the ball after impact.
Apply the angular impulse-angular momentum theorem: \((\mu J)r = I\omega_0\).
Apply conservation of linear momentum in the horizontal direction: \(mv_1 = Mv_2\).
Solve for \(v_1\) and \(v_2\).
The time of flight of the ball is \(T = \dfrac{2v_0}{g}\).
The relative horizontal velocity is \(v_r = v_1 + v_2\).
The distance between impacts is \(s = v_r T\).

questions.title: Mass for Spool Equilibrium on Inclined Plane
questions.questionText: A spool of mass \(M\) and radius \(2R\) lies on an inclined plane as shown in figure. A light thread is wound around the connecting tube of the spool and its free end carries a weight of mass \(m\). \nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nFind the value of \(m\) so that system is in equilibrium.
questions.solution:
Equilibrium of \(m\) gives
\(T = mg\) \(\quad \{T = 	ext{Tension in string}\}\)
Net torque about point of contact of spool should be zero. Hence,
\((2R)(Mg\sin\alpha) = TR\)
\(\Rightarrow 2Mg\sin\alpha = mg\)
\(\Rightarrow m = 2M\sin\alpha\)
questions.hint: For equilibrium, the net torque on the spool about any point must be zero.  Consider the forces acting on the spool: its weight, tension in the thread, and the normal reaction from the inclined plane.  Choose the point of contact of the spool with the inclined plane as the pivot point to eliminate normal reaction from torque calculations, as normal reaction is passing through this point.
methodOfSolving: Write the equilibrium condition for the hanging mass: \(T = mg\).
Choose the point of contact of the spool with the plane as the pivot.
Write the torque balance equation for the spool: \((2R)(Mg\sin\alpha) = TR\).
Solve for \(m\).

questions.title: Young's Modulus Determination with Uncertainties
questions.questionText: A student performs an experiment to determine the Young's modulus of a wire, exactly 2 m long, by Searle's method. In a particular reading, the student measures the extension in the length of the wire to be 0.8 mm with an uncertainty of 0.05 mm at a load of exactly 1.0 kg. The student also measures the diameter of the wire to be 0.4 mm with an uncertainty of 0.01 mm. Take \(g = 9.8 \,\text{m/s}^2\) (exact). Find the Young's modulus obtained from the reading.
questions.solution:
Young's modulus \(Y\) is given by:
\(Y = \dfrac{FL}{A\Delta L}\), where
\(F = \) Force \(= mg = 1.0 	imes 9.8 = 9.8 \,	ext{N}\)
\(L = \) Length \(= 2 \,	ext{m}\)
\(A = \) Cross-sectional area \(= \pi \left(\dfrac{d}{2}ight)^2 = \pi \left(\dfrac{0.4 	imes 10^{-3}}{2}ight)^2 = 1.26 	imes 10^{-7} \,	ext{m}^2\)
\(\Delta L = \) Extension \(= 0.8 	imes 10^{-3} \,	ext{m}\)
\(Y = \dfrac{(9.8)(2)}{(1.26 	imes 10^{-7})(0.8 	imes 10^{-3})} = 1.95 	imes 10^{11} \,	ext{N m}^{-2} \approx 2.0 	imes 10^{11} \,	ext{N m}^{-2}\)
\(\dfrac{\Delta Y}{Y} = \dfrac{\Delta L}{L} + \dfrac{\Delta \Delta L}{\Delta L} + 2\dfrac{\Delta d}{d} = \dfrac{0.05}{0.8} + 2\dfrac{0.01}{0.4} = 0.0625+0.05 = 0.1125\)
\(\Delta Y = Y 	imes \dfrac{\Delta Y}{Y} = 2 	imes 10^{11} 	imes 0.1125 = 0.225 	imes 10^{11} \approx 0.2 	imes 10^{11}\)
Therefore, \(Y = (2.0 \pm 0.2) 	imes 10^{11} \,	ext{Nm}^{-2}\).
questions.hint: Use the formula for Young's modulus: \(Y = \dfrac{FL}{A\Delta L}\), where \(F\) is the force, \(L\) is the length, \(A\) is the cross-sectional area, and \(\Delta L\) is the extension. Calculate the uncertainty in \(Y\) using the given uncertainties in \(\Delta L\) and \(d\).
methodOfSolving: Calculate the cross-sectional area \(A = \pi(\dfrac{d}{2})^2\).
Calculate Young's Modulus: \(Y = \dfrac{FL}{A\Delta L}\).
Calculate the uncertainty in \(Y\) using \(\dfrac{\Delta Y}{Y} = \dfrac{\Delta L}{L} + \dfrac{\Delta\Delta L}{\Delta L} + 2\dfrac{\Delta d}{d}\).

questions.title: Time Interval Between Two Projectiles Passing Through a Common Point
questions.questionText: Two particles are projected from a point at the same instant with velocities whose horizontal and vertical components are \(u_1\), \(v_1\) and \(u_2\), \(v_2\) respectively. Find the interval between their passing through the other common point of their path.
questions.solution:
If \(t_1\) and \(t_2\) are time of crossing point \(P\) then

DIAGRAM[1,200]

\(x = u_1t_1 = u_1t_2\)
\(y = v_1t_1 - \dfrac{1}{2}gt_1^2 = v_2t_2 - \dfrac{1}{2}gt_2^2\)
\(v_1t_1 - \dfrac{1}{2}gt_1^2 = v_2\left(\dfrac{u_1t_1}{u_2}ight) - \dfrac{1}{2}g\left(\dfrac{u_1t_1}{u_2}ight)^2\)
\(\dfrac{1}{2}gt_1^2\left(\dfrac{u_1^2}{u_2^2}-1ight) + t_1\left(v_1 - v_2\dfrac{u_1}{u_2}ight) = 0\)
\(t_1 = \dfrac{2(v_2u_1 - v_1u_2)}{g(u_1^2-u_2^2)}u_2^2\)
\(t_2 = \dfrac{u_1t_1}{u_2} = \dfrac{2(v_2u_1-v_1u_2)u_1}{g(u_1^2-u_2^2)}\)
and
\(\Delta t = t_2 - t_1 = t_1\left(\dfrac{u_1}{u_2} - 1ight) = \dfrac{2(v_2u_1 - v_1u_2)}{g(u_1+u_2)}\)
questions.hint: The two particles will pass through a common point if their x and y coordinates are the same at some instants of time.  Use the equations of motion for projectile motion.
methodOfSolving: Write the equations for the x and y coordinates of the projectiles as functions of time: \(x = u_i t_i\) and \(y = v_i t_i - \dfrac{1}{2}gt_i^2\), where \(i=1, 2\).
Set \(x_1 = x_2\) and \(y_1 = y_2\) to find the times \(t_1\) and \(t_2\) when each particle passes through the common point.
The time interval is \(\Delta t = |t_2 - t_1|\).

questions.title: Minimum Friction for Block on Accelerating Inclined Plane
questions.questionText: An inclined plane \(ABCD\) is shown in the figure. It is inclined at an angle of \(45^\circ\) from horizontal. A block is placed on the inclined plane. The plane is accelerating along \(x\)-axis with an acceleration, \(a = 5 \,\text{m/s}^2\). Find the minimum value of coefficient of friction between the block and the plane required, so that the block does not slip on the plane. \((g = 10 \,\text{m/s}^2)\)\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
Let the mass of the block be \(m\).  With respect to the inclined plane, pseudo force acts on block in opposite direction of motion of inclined plane i.e. towards left.
DIAGRAM[2,200]
In equilibrium,
\(\mu N = ma\cos	heta + mg\sin	heta\) ...(i)
\(N = ma\sin	heta + mg\cos	heta\) ...(ii)
Dividing Eq. (i) by Eq. (ii), we get
\(\mu = \dfrac{a\cos	heta + g\sin	heta}{a\sin	heta + g\cos	heta} = \dfrac{a+g}{a+g} \quad ( ecause 	heta=45^\circ)\)
\(\mu = \dfrac{5 + 10}{5\sqrt{2} + \dfrac{10}{\sqrt{2}}} 	imes \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{2}} = 1\)
questions.hint: Consider the forces acting on the block in the frame of reference of the accelerating inclined plane.  These include the weight, normal reaction, friction force, and pseudo force due to the acceleration of the plane. For no slipping, the net force along the incline must be zero.
methodOfSolving: Draw a free body diagram of the block in the frame of reference of the inclined plane, showing all forces including the pseudo force \(ma\) acting horizontally towards the left.
Resolve forces along and perpendicular to the incline.

Apply the condition for no slipping:  The net force along the incline is zero, so the friction force must balance the component of the weight down the incline and pseudo force component along the incline.
The normal reaction force balances the component of the weight perpendicular to the incline and the component of pseudo force perpendicular to the incline. Friction force is \(\mu N\).
Divide the two equations to eliminate \(N\) and solve for \(\mu\).

questions.title: Normal Reaction and Frictional Force on a Rotating Sleeve
questions.questionText: A rough L-shaped rod is located in a horizontal plane and a sleeve of mass \(m\) is inserted in the rod. The rod is rotated with a constant angular velocity \(\omega\) in the horizontal plane. The lengths \(l_1\) and \(l_2\) are shown in figure.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nFind the normal reaction and frictional force acting on the sleeve when it starts slipping. (\(\mu\) : coefficient of friction between rod and sleeve)
questions.solution: DIAGRAM\n\(N = m\omega^2 l_1\)\nFrictional force \(f = \mu N\)
questions.hint: The normal reaction provides the centripetal force for the circular motion of the sleeve. Slipping occurs when the centripetal force exceeds the maximum static friction force.
methodOfSolving: The normal reaction \(N\) provides the centripetal force: \(N = m\omega^2 r\), where \(r = l_1\).
The frictional force \(f\) opposes the impending motion and is given by \(f = \mu N\).

questions.title: Length of String Unwound from a Cylinder
questions.questionText: A string is wrapped around a cylinder of mass \(M\) and radius \(R\). The string is pulled vertically upward to prevent the centre of mass from falling as the cylinder unwinds the string. Find the length of the string unwound when the cylinder has reached a speed \(\omega\).
questions.solution:
As the centre of mass of cylinder is at rest,

DIAGRAM[1,150]

Therefore
\(T = mg\) ...(1)
Also,
\(T 	imes R = \dfrac{mR^2}{2}a\)
\(\Rightarrow a = \dfrac{2g}{R}\)
therefore
\(\omega^2 = 0 + 2a	heta\)
\(\Rightarrow 	heta = \dfrac{\omega^2R}{2 	imes 2g} = \dfrac{\omega^2 R}{4g}\)
Length of string unwound is \(l = \dfrac{\omega^2 R^2}{4g}\)
questions.hint: Since the center of mass of the cylinder is at rest, the tension in the string must balance the weight of the cylinder. The torque due to the tension causes angular acceleration.  The length of the string unwound is related to the angle rotated by the cylinder.
methodOfSolving: Write the force balance equation for the cylinder: \(T = Mg\).
Write the torque equation about the center of the cylinder: \(TR = I\alpha\), where \(I = \dfrac{1}{2}MR^2\) and \(\alpha\) is the angular acceleration.
Solve for the angular acceleration \(\alpha\).
Use the equation of rotational motion \(\omega^2 = \omega_0^2 + 2\alpha\theta\) to find the angle \(\theta\) rotated by the cylinder.
The length of the string unwound is \(l = R\theta\).

questions.title: Total Angular Momentum of Rolling Cylinder
questions.questionText: A solid cylinder of mass \(M\) and radius \(R\) is rolling without slipping on a horizontal surface. The velocity of its centre of mass is equal to \(v\). Find the total angular momentum of the cylinder about point \(P\) on the cylinder at distance \(\dfrac{R}{2}\) from centre.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution: \(I_p = I_{CM} + M\left(\dfrac{R}{2}\right)^2 = \dfrac{3}{4}MR^2\)\nangular momentum\n\(L = I_p\omega = \dfrac{3}{4}MR^2\left(\dfrac{v}{R}\right)\)
questions.hint: Use the parallel axis theorem to find the moment of inertia about point P.  For rolling without slipping, the angular velocity is related to the linear velocity of the center of mass and radius.
methodOfSolving: Find the moment of inertia \(I_p\) about point P using the parallel axis theorem: \(I_p = I_{CM} + Md^2\), where \(I_{CM} = \dfrac{1}{2}MR^2\) is the moment of inertia about the center of mass and \(d = \dfrac{R}{2}\) is the distance between P and center of mass.
For rolling without slipping, the angular velocity is \(\omega = \dfrac{v}{R}\).
Calculate the angular momentum about P using \(L = I_p \omega\).

questions.title: Displacement in the Last 2 Seconds of Motion
questions.questionText: A body moves in a straight line with a velocity whose square decreases linearly with the displacement between two points \(A\) and \(B\), which are 300 m apart as shown.\nDIAGRAM[1,200] \nFind the displacement \(\Delta S\) of the body during the last 2 s before arrival at \(B\).
questions.solution:
Slope of curve \(\dfrac{d(V^2)}{ds} = 2a\Rightarrow a = \dfrac{4}{3}\)
Velocity at \(B = \sqrt{800} \,	ext{m/s} = 28.28 \,	ext{m/s}\)
Velocity 2 sec. earlier \(= 30.95 \,	ext{m/s}\) (using \(v = u + at\))
\(\Rightarrow s = \left(\dfrac{u+v}{2}ight)t = 59.3 \,	ext{m}\)
questions.hint: The slope of the \(v^2\) vs. \(s\) graph gives the acceleration. Find the velocity at B and use the equations of motion to determine the velocity 2 seconds earlier.  The displacement in the last 2 seconds can then be calculated using the average velocity.
methodOfSolving: Determine the acceleration \(a\) from the slope of the given graph: \(\dfrac{d(v^2)}{ds} = 2a\).
Find the velocity at point B using the graph.
Calculate the velocity 2 seconds before reaching B using \(v = u + at\), where \(v\) is velocity at B, and \(t=2s\).
Calculate the displacement during the last 2 seconds using the average velocity: \(s = \dfrac{u+v}{2}t\).

questions.title: Coefficient of Restitution for Ball Rebounding from Hemisphere
questions.questionText: A ball is thrown from point \(A\) making an angle \(60^\circ\) with line \(OAS\) as shown in the figure, where \(OA = \dfrac{R}{\sqrt{3}}\) (O is the centre of spherical surface of \(PQS\)).\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nIf after striking the hemi-spherical surface, the ball rebounds in direction parallel to \(OA\), find the coefficient of restitution between the ball and the surface. (Neglect the effect of gravity any type of frictional force)
questions.solution:
DIAGRAM[2,200]
In \(	riangle OAP\), using sin rule
\(\dfrac{\dfrac{R}{\sqrt{3}}}{\sin	heta} = \dfrac{R}{\sin 120^\circ}\)
\(\Rightarrow \sin	heta = \dfrac{\sin 120^\circ}{\sqrt{3}} = \dfrac{1}{2}\)
\(\Rightarrow 	heta = 30^\circ\)
So \(\alpha = 30^\circ\)
Component of velocity of the ball before collision along the normal = \(v_0\sin	heta = \dfrac{1}{2}v_0\). Since after collision it becomes \(ev_0\sin	heta\), and since the ball rebounds in a direction parallel to OA, we have, \(ev_0\sin	heta = v_0 \cos 60^\circ\)
\(\Rightarrow e\dfrac{v_0}{2} = \dfrac{v_0}{2}\)
\(\Rightarrow e=1\)
questions.hint: Use the sine rule in triangle OAP to find the angle of incidence. For the ball to rebound parallel to OA, the horizontal velocity should be reversed, and related to the coefficient of restitution.
methodOfSolving: Apply the sine rule to triangle OAP: \(\dfrac{OA}{\sin\theta} = \dfrac{OP}{\sin(\angle OAP)}\). Solve for \(\theta\), which gives the angle between the incident velocity and the normal to the surface.
Determine the angle \(\alpha\) between the incident velocity and the tangent, \(\alpha=\theta\). The angle \(\theta\) is also the angle between the normal and OA.

The component of velocity along the normal is reversed and multiplied by the coefficient of restitution \(e\) after collision. So, after collision, the component of the velocity along the normal is \(ev_0 \sin\theta\), hence the component of velocity along \(OA\) is \(ev_0 \sin\theta\).
Since the rebound direction is parallel to OA, the horizontal component of the velocity is reversed. So,  \(ev_0\sin\theta = v_0 \cos 60^\circ\).
Solve for \(e\).

questions.title: Tension in a Thread Holding a Chain on a Sphere
questions.questionText: A chain of mass per unit length \(\lambda\) and length 1.5 m rests on a fixed smooth sphere of radius \(R = \dfrac{2}{\pi} \,\text{m}\) such that \(A\) end of chain is at the top of sphere while the other end is hanging freely. Chain is held stationary by a horizontal thread \(PA\). Find the tension in the thread.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
Let us take a small element of the chain as shown in figure.
DIAGRAM[2,200]
The driving force due to the gravitation on this element is \(dF = dmg\cos	heta\).
Sum of driving forces an all the elements between \(0\) to \(	heta = \pi/2\)
\(F = \displaystyle\int dmg\cos	heta\)
\(F = \displaystyle\int_0^{\pi/2} (\lambda Rd	heta)g\cos	heta = \lambda Rg \displaystyle\int_0^{\pi/2} \cos	heta d	heta\)
\(F = \lambda Rg[\sin	heta]_0^{\pi/2} = \lambda Rg\)
Therefore \(F = \lambda g \dfrac{2}{\pi}\)
Also, the driving force on the hanging part of the chain.
\(F' = \lambda(l - \dfrac{R\pi}{2})g\)
\(\Rightarrow F' = \lambda(\dfrac{3}{2} - 1) = \dfrac{\lambda g}{2}\)
therefore net driving force
\(=F+F' = \lambda g\left(\dfrac{1}{2} + \dfrac{2}{\pi}ight)\)
questions.hint: Consider a small element of the chain on the sphere and find the component of its weight along the tangent. Integrate this force over the portion of the chain on the sphere.  Also consider the weight of the hanging portion of the chain.  The horizontal thread must balance the net tangential force.
methodOfSolving: Consider a small chain element of length \(Rd\theta\) on the sphere at an angle θ from the vertical. Its mass is \(dm = \lambda Rd\theta\).
The tangential component of the weight of this element is \(dmg\cos\theta\).
Integrate this force from 0 to π/2 to get the force \(F\) due to the chain on the sphere.
The weight of the hanging part of the chain is \(F' = \lambda (l - \dfrac{\pi R}{2})g\).
The tension in the thread is the sum of these two forces: \(T = F + F'\).

questions.title: Angular Speed of Disc When String Becomes Taut
questions.questionText: Figure shows a disc of mass \(M\) and radius \(R\) hinged at the centre. A small ball of mass \(\dfrac{M}{2}\) is attached to point \(P\) with a thread of length \(2R\) and held at rest at position shown. Now, the ball is released to fall under gravity. Find with what angular speed the disc starts turning when the string becomes taut.\nDIAGRAM[1,140]
questions.solution:
DIAGRAM[2,200]
Using conservation of angular momentum about pt. \(O,\)
\(\dfrac{M}{2}\sqrt{2gR} 	imes R = \dfrac{MR^2}{2}\omega + \dfrac{M}{2}(R\omega)R\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{1}{2}\sqrt{2gR} = R\omega\)
\(\Rightarrow \omega = \sqrt{\dfrac{g}{2R}}\)
questions.hint: Consider the conservation of angular momentum about the hinge point O. The ball falls under gravity, gaining kinetic energy which is then transferred to the disc when the string becomes taut. Also, angular momentum of the system must be conserved, so angular momentum of ball about hinge equals the angular momentum of disc + ball system.
methodOfSolving: The ball falls a vertical distance of \(2R\) before the string becomes taut. Its velocity is given by \(v = \sqrt{2gh} = \sqrt{4gR}\).
