Apply conservation of angular momentum about the hinge point O. The initial angular momentum is due to the ball: \(\dfrac{M}{2}vR\). The final angular momentum is due to the rotating disc and the ball: \(I_{disc}\omega + \dfrac{M}{2}(\omega R)R\).
Use \(I_{disc} = \dfrac{1}{2}MR^2\).
Solve for \(\omega\).

questions.title: Frictional Force on a Ring Connected to a Disc
questions.questionText: In the given situation disc and ring are connected with a string as shown in the figure. Both are placed on the rough surface with coefficient of friction \(\mu\). A force \(F\) is applied on the centre of disc horizontally. Find the frictional force acting on the ring.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution: If a ring is dragged by a horizontal force at its top, then no friction force will act whatever be the force.
questions.hint: Consider the tension in the string and the friction force acting on the ring. For the ring to be in equilibrium, these forces must balance.
methodOfSolving: The tension \(T\) in the string pulls the ring to the right.

Since there is no other horizontal force on the ring except tension and frictional force, the frictional force must act to the left to balance the tension. This requires a torque on the ring about the point of contact with the ground. Since the only forces are vertical normal force and \(mg\), tension \(T\) and friction \(f\), the tension passes through the center and cannot produce any torque.

questions.title: Frequency of Simple Harmonic Motion of Two Spheres
questions.questionText: Two spheres \(A\) and \(B\) of the same mass \(m\) and the same radius are placed on a rough horizontal surface. \(A\) is a uniform hollow sphere and \(B\) is uniform solid sphere. \(A\) and \(B\) can roll without sliding on the floor. They are also tied centrally to a light spring of spring constant \(k\) as shown in figure.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]\nA and B are released when the extension in the spring is \(x_0\). Find the frequency of simple harmonic motion of the spheres.
questions.solution:
Let \(x_1\) and \(x_2\) be the displacement from equilibrium position, now for hollow sphere, applying
\(	au_A = I_A a\)
\(k(x_1+x_2)r = \dfrac{5}{3}mr^2 \dfrac{a}{r}\) ...(i)
By angular momentum conservation (about A) of the system,DIAGRAM[2,200]
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{5}{3} mv_1 r = \dfrac{7}{5} mv_2 r\) ...(ii)
\(\Rightarrow 25\,x_1 = 21\,x_2\) ...(iii)
Using (i) and (iii) we get,
\(k\left[x_1 + \dfrac{25}{21}x_1ight] = \dfrac{5}{3}ma_1\)
\(\Rightarrow a_1 = \dfrac{46k}{35m}x_1\)
\(\Rightarrow f = \dfrac{1}{2\pi}\sqrt{\dfrac{46k}{35m}}\)
questions.hint: Consider the torque on each sphere due to the spring force. Use conservation of angular momentum and the relationship between linear and angular quantities for rolling without slipping.
methodOfSolving: Let \(x_1\) and \(x_2\) be the displacements of the hollow and solid spheres from their equilibrium positions, respectively.  The extension/compression in the spring is \(x_1 + x_2\).

Consider torques about point of contact for A. Relate the torque on sphere A to its angular acceleration \(\alpha_1 = \dfrac{a_1}{r}\): \(k(x_1+x_2)r = I_A \alpha_1\), where \(I_A = \dfrac{5}{3}mr^2\) for hollow sphere.

Apply conservation of angular momentum about the center of mass of sphere \(A\): \(I_A\omega_1 = I_B\omega_2\), where \(I_B = \dfrac{7}{5}mr^2\) for the solid sphere. Convert angular quantities \(\omega_i\) to linear quantities: \(v_i = r\omega_i\), where \(i = 1, 2\).
Since there is no slipping, \(v_1 = \dot{x_1}\), \(v_2 = \dot{x_2}\), so integrate both sides with time to get \(x_1\) and \(x_2\) relation. Substitute this to find \(a_1\) from equation (i).
Use \(a = -\omega^2 x\) to find frequency \(f = \dfrac{\omega}{2\pi}\).

questions.title: Motion of Trolley and Ball After Collision
questions.questionText:
A ball of mass \(m = 1 \,	ext{kg}\) is hung vertically by a thread of length \(l = 1.50 \,	ext{m}\). The upper end of the thread is attached to the ceiling of a trolley of mass \(M = 4 \,	ext{kg}\). Initially, the trolley is stationary and is free to move along horizontal rails without friction. A shell of mass \(m = 1 \,	ext{kg}\), moving horizontally with velocity \(v_0 = 6 \,	ext{ms}^{-1}\), collides with the ball and gets stuck with it. As a result, the thread starts to deflect towards the right. \((g = 10 \,	ext{ms}^{-2})\)
DIAGRAM[1,180]
Find:
(a) The maximum deflection of the thread with the vertical.
(b) The velocity of the trolley at the instant of maximum inclination of the thread.
questions.solution:
When the shell strikes the ball and gets stuck with it, the combined body of mass \(2m\) starts to move to the right. Let the velocity of the combined body (just after the collision) be \(v_1\).
By conservation of momentum, \((m+m)v_1 = mv_0\), or
\(v_1 = \dfrac{mv_0}{2m} = \dfrac{v_0}{2} = \dfrac{6}{2} = 3 \,	ext{ms}^{-1}\).
As soon as the combined body starts to move rightwards, the thread becomes inclined to the vertical. The horizontal component of its tension retards the combined body while the trolley accelerates rightwards due to the same component of tension.
The inclination of the thread with the vertical continues to increase till the velocities of both (combined body and trolley) become identical, or the combined body comes to rest relative to the trolley. Let the velocity at that instant of maximum inclination of the thread be \(v\). According to the law of conservation of momentum,
\((2m+M)v = 2mv_1\), so \(v = \dfrac{2mv_1}{2m+M} = \dfrac{2(1)(3)}{2(1)+4} = 1 \,	ext{ms}^{-1}\).
During the collision of the ball and shell, a part of the energy is lost. But after that, there is no loss of energy. Hence, after the collision, the kinetic energy lost is used up in increasing the gravitational potential energy of the combined body.
If the maximum inclination of the thread with the vertical is \(	heta\), then according to the law of conservation of energy,
\(\dfrac{1}{2}(2m)v_1^2 - \dfrac{1}{2}(2m+M)v^2 = 2mg(l-l\cos	heta)\).
\(\dfrac{1}{2}(2)(1)(3^2) - \dfrac{1}{2}(2+4)(1^2) = 2(1)(10)(1.5-1.5\cos	heta)\).
\(9 - 3 = 30(1-\cos	heta)\).
\(\Rightarrow \cos	heta = 0.8\), or \(	heta = 37^\circ\).
questions.hint: Apply conservation of momentum to find the velocity of the combined mass after the collision. Apply conservation of momentum again when the trolley and the combined mass have the same velocity. Use conservation of energy to find the maximum angle of deflection.
methodOfSolving: Apply conservation of momentum to the collision between the shell and the ball: \((m+m)v_1 = mv_0\).
Apply conservation of momentum to the system of the combined mass and the trolley when they have the same velocity \(v\): \((2m+M)v = 2mv_1\).
Apply conservation of energy.  The loss in kinetic energy is equal to the gain in potential energy: \(\dfrac{1}{2}(2m)v_1^2 - \dfrac{1}{2}(2m+M)v^2 = 2mg(l-l\cos\theta)\).  Solve for \(\theta\).

questions.title: Velocity and Angular Velocity After Collision
questions.questionText:
A uniform rod of mass \(8m\) lies on a smooth horizontal table. Two point masses \(m\) and \(2m\) moving in the same horizontal plane with speeds \(2v\) and \(v\) respectively, strike the bar as shown in the figure and stick to the bar after the collision. \(C\) denotes the center of mass of the rod, and the length of the rod is \(6a\), where \(a = 1 \,	ext{m}\). \((v = 10 \,	ext{m/s})\)
DIAGRAM[1,300]
(a) What is the velocity of the center of mass just after the collision?
(b) What is the angular velocity of the system just after the collision?
questions.solution:
Both masses, \(2m\) and \(m\), after striking the bar, give equal momentum each \(2mv\) to the bar in opposite directions. Hence, after the collision, the bar has no translational motion, i.e., the linear velocity of the center of mass of the bar is zero. \(v_c = 0\).
When both masses stick to the bar, the whole system rotates about the center of mass \(C\). As there is no external torque acting on the system, the angular momentum is conserved.
Before collision (bar is stationary), there will be only the angular momentum of \(2m\) and \(m\) about \(C\). Hence the initial angular momentum (see Fig.) is \(J_i = 2mva + m(2v)2a = 6mva\) (in an anticlockwise direction).
After collision, the bar and both the masses (\(2m\) and \(m\)) rotate with angular velocity \(\omega\) about the center of mass \(C\). The moment of inertia of the bar (mass \(8m\) and length \(6a\)) about C is \(\dfrac{M l^2}{12} = \dfrac{8m(6a)^2}{12} = 24ma^2\), and the moments of inertia of \(2m\) and \(m\) about \(C\) are \(2ma^2\) and \(4ma^2\), respectively. Hence, after collision, the angular momentum of the system is \(J_f = (24ma^2 + 2ma^2 + 4ma^2)\omega = 30ma^2\omega\).
\(J_f = J_i\) (conservation of angular momentum)
\(\Rightarrow \omega = \dfrac{6mav}{30ma^2} = \dfrac{v}{5a}\)
Given \(v=10\,	ext{m/s}\) and \(a=1\,	ext{m}\), we have \(\omega = \dfrac{10}{5(1)} = 2 \,	ext{rad/s}\).
questions.hint: The net linear momentum imparted to the rod is zero, so the velocity of the center of mass remains zero. Angular momentum is conserved about the center of mass C.  Calculate the initial angular momentum and the final moment of inertia of the system.
methodOfSolving: Calculate the total linear momentum imparted to the rod. Since it's zero, the velocity of the center of mass remains zero.
Calculate the initial angular momentum \(J_i\) about C: \(J_i = (2m)va + m(2v)(2a) = 6mva\).
Calculate the final moment of inertia \(J_f\) of the system about C: \(I_{rod} + I_{2m} + I_m = \dfrac{8m(6a)^2}{12} + 2ma^2 + m(2a)^2 = 30ma^2\).
Apply conservation of angular momentum: \(J_i = J_f\), which gives \(6mva = 30ma^2 \omega\).
Solve for \(\omega\).

questions.title: Maximum Separation Between Two Particles
questions.questionText: Two particles A and B start from the same point and move along a straight line. The velocity-time graph for both of them has been shown in the figure. Find the maximum separation between the particles in the interval \(0 < t < 5\) sec.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution: The velocity of B becomes lesser than the velocity of A after \(t=4\) s, and hence the distance between the particles starts to decrease. The separation is maximum at \(t=4\) s.  Maximum separation \(= x_A(\text{at } t=4) - x_B(\text{at } t=4)\), which is difference in area under the curves.\n\(\Rightarrow \text{Maximum Separation} = \text{Area under A} - \text{Area under B} \)\n\( = \dfrac{1}{2} \times 4 \times 10 - \dfrac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 10 = 10 \,\text{m}\).
questions.hint: The separation between the particles is maximum when their relative velocity becomes zero. Find the time at which the velocities of A and B are equal and their relative velocity is zero. Then, the area under v-t curves upto the moment when separation is maximum gives displacements, and hence their difference gives the maximum separation.
methodOfSolving: Find the time at which the velocities of A and B are equal. This is the time when their relative velocity is zero, and the separation is maximum.
Calculate the displacement of A at this time by finding the area under the velocity-time graph for A.
Calculate the displacement of B at this time by finding the area under the velocity-time graph for B.
The maximum separation is the difference between the displacements of A and B.

questions.title: Fastest Bead to Reach Point B
questions.questionText: Two frictionless ropes connect points A & B in a vertical plane. Bead 1 is allowed to slide along the straight rope AB and bead 2 slides along the curved rope ACB. Which bead will reach B in less time?\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
Let \(t_1\) be the time taken by bead 1 to reach B. Since the rope is frictionless,
DIAGRAM[2,300]
\(l = \dfrac{1}{2}(g\cos\alpha)t_1^2\)
\(\Rightarrow t_1 = \sqrt{\dfrac{2l}{g\cos\alpha}}\)
For bead 2, we have \(\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 = mgy\) \((y=	ext{vertical displacement})\)
\(v = \sqrt{2gy}\)
\(\dfrac{ds}{dt} = \sqrt{2gy}\)
\(\Rightarrow \displaystyle\int \dfrac{ds}{\sqrt{2gy}} = \displaystyle\int dt\)
Consider any elemental length \(ds\) along ACB. Let the angle subtended by \(ds\) at the center be \(d\phi\). Then \(ds = rd\phi\), where \(r\) is radius of curvature, and vertical distance \(y\) is given by \(y = r(1-\cos\phi)\).
So, time \(t_2 = \sqrt{\dfrac{2r}{g}}\phi\)
Since \(l = r\phi \cos\alpha\Rightarrow \phi = \dfrac{l}{r\cos\alpha}\)
\(\Rightarrow t_2 = \sqrt{\dfrac{2r}{g}} \dfrac{l}{r\cos\alpha} = \sqrt{\dfrac{2l}{g\cos\alpha}} 	imes \dfrac{l}{\sqrt{rl\cos\alpha}}\)
So, \(t_2\) is more than \(t_1\). Hence bead 1 reaches B in less time.
questions.hint: For bead 1, use the equations of motion for constant acceleration along an inclined plane. For bead 2, use conservation of energy to relate velocity and vertical displacement, and integrate to find the time taken.
methodOfSolving: For bead 1, use \(l = \dfrac{1}{2}(g\cos\alpha)t_1^2\), where \(l\) is the length of the string AB and \(\alpha\) is the angle AB makes with the horizontal.  Solve for \(t_1\).
For bead 2, use conservation of energy: \(\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2 = mgy\), where \(y\) is the vertical displacement.  This gives \(v = \sqrt{2gy}\).
Relate the elemental length \(ds\) along the curve to the radius of curvature \(r\) and angle \(d\phi\): \(ds = rd\phi\).  The vertical distance is \(y = r(1-\cos\phi)\).
Use \(\dfrac{ds}{dt} = v\) and integrate to find the time \(t_2\) for bead 2.
Compare \(t_1\) and \(t_2\).

questions.title: Velocity and Velocity Ratio for a Pulled Block
questions.questionText:
Two persons are pulling a heavy block with the help of horizontal inextensible strings. At the instant shown, the velocities of the two persons are \(v_1\) and \(v_2\), directed along the respective strings, with the strings making an angle of \(60^\circ\) between them. 
DIAGRAM[1,150]
(a) Find the speed of the block at the instant shown.
(b) For what ratio of \(v_1\) and \(v_2\) will the instantaneous velocity of the block be along the direction of \(v_1\)?
questions.solution:
DIAGRAM[2,250]
(a) For a string to be taut, the objects at the two ends must have the same velocity component along the length of the string.
\(v\cos	heta = v_1\) ...(1)
\(v\cos(60-	heta) = v_2\) ...(2)
From (2), \(v\left(\cos 60^\circ\cos	heta + \sin 60^\circ\sin	hetaight) = v_2\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{v}{2} + v\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}	an	heta = v_2 \quad \{  ecause 	an	heta = \dfrac{\sin	heta}{\cos	heta} \}\)
\(\dfrac{v}{2} + \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\dfrac{vv_1}{v} = \dfrac{v}{2} + \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}v_1 = v_2\)
\(\Rightarrow v = \sqrt{4v_2^2 - 4v_2v_1\sqrt{3}+3v_1^2} = \sqrt{v_1^2 + v_2^2 + \sqrt{3}v_1v_2}\)
\((b) For \(	heta = 0^\circ\), from equation (1) we have \(v=v_1\). Putting into the expression for \(v\), we get
\(3v_1^2 = 4v_2^2 + v_1^2 + 2\sqrt{3}v_1v_2\Rightarrow v_1^2 - \sqrt{3}v_1v_2 - 2v_2^2 = 0\)
\(v_1 = \dfrac{v_2(\sqrt{3} \pm \sqrt{3+8})}{2}\Rightarrow v_1 = \dfrac{\sqrt{3} \pm \sqrt{11}}{2}v_2\)
Since velocities cannot be negative, we have
\(\Rightarrow v_1=2v_2\)
questions.hint: The velocity components of the block and each person must be equal along the direction of the respective strings. Use vector addition to find the velocity of the block.  For the velocity of the block to be along \(v_1\), the angle θ must be zero.
methodOfSolving: For each string, equate the component of the block's velocity \(v\) along the string to the person's velocity. This gives two equations: \(v\cos\theta = v_1\) and \(v\cos(60-\theta) = v_2\).
Eliminate \(\theta\) from these equations to find \(v\) in terms of \(v_1\) and \(v_2\).
For \(v\) to be along \(v_1\), the angle θ must be zero.  Substitute \(\theta = 0\) into the equations and solve for the ratio \(\dfrac{v_1}{v_2}\).

questions.title: Equilibrium and Acceleration in a System with Rod, Ring, and Sphere
questions.questionText:
A smooth rod is fixed at an angle \(\alpha\) to the horizontal. A small ring of mass \(m\) can slide along the rod. A thread carrying a small sphere of mass \(M\) is attached to the ring. To keep the system in equilibrium, another thread is attached to the ring which carries a load of mass \(m_0\) at its end (see figure). The thread runs parallel to the rod between the ring and the pulley. All threads and pulley are massless.
DIAGRAM[1,300]
(a) Find \(m_0\) so that the system is in equilibrium.
(b) Find the acceleration of the sphere \(M\) immediately after the thread supporting \(m_0\) is cut.
questions.solution:
(a)DIAGRAM[2,300]
\(T_1 = Mg\) and \(T_2 = m_0g\)
For ring:
\(T_2 + mg\sin\alpha = T_1\sin\alpha\)
\(\Rightarrow m_0g + mg\sin\alpha = Mg\sin\alpha\)
\(\Rightarrow m_0 = (M-m)\sin\alpha\)
(b)DIAGRAM[3,300]
\(a_1 \sin\alpha = a_2\) ...(1)
For ring:
\(T + mg\sin\alpha = ma_1\) ...(2)
For sphere:
\(Mg - T = Ma_2\) ...(3)
Substituting \(a_1\) from equation (1) into equation (2) we get
\(T+mg\sin\alpha = m\dfrac{a_2}{\sin\alpha}\) ...(4)
From equations (3) and (4),
\(Mg - \left[m\dfrac{a_2}{\sin\alpha} - mg\sin\alphaight] = Ma_2\)
\(\Rightarrow a_2 = \dfrac{Mg + mg\sin^2\alpha}{M+\dfrac{m}{\sin\alpha}}\sin\alpha\)
questions.hint: (a) Consider the forces acting on the ring and the sphere.  For equilibrium, the net force on each must be zero.  The tension in the thread supporting \(m_0\) must balance the horizontal component of the tension in the other thread.\n(b) When the thread supporting \(m_0\) is cut, the ring and the sphere will accelerate. The component of the ring's acceleration perpendicular to the rod must equal the sphere's acceleration. Use Newton's second law for both the ring and sphere. As ring cannot move perpendicular to the rod.
methodOfSolving: (a) Draw free body diagrams for the ring and sphere. Write equations for equilibrium: \(T_1 = Mg\), \(T_2 = m_0g\), and \(T_2 + mg\sin\alpha = T_1\sin\alpha\). Solve for \(m_0\).

(b) Let \(a_1\) and \(a_2\) be the accelerations of the ring and the sphere respectively. Since ring cannot move perpendicular to the rod, \(a_1\sin\alpha = a_2\). Apply Newton's second law to the ring and sphere to get two more equations. Solve these equations for \(a_2\).

questions.title: Friction Coefficient for Dust on Rotating Hemisphere
questions.questionText: A metallic hemisphere is having dust on its surface. The sphere is rotated about a vertical axis passing through its centre at an angular speed \(\omega\). Now the dust is visible only on the top \(\eta\)% area of the curved hemispherical surface. The radius of the hemisphere is \(R\). Find the coefficient of friction between the dust particle and the hemisphere. \((g = \text{acceleration due to gravity})\)\nDIAGRAM[1,250]
questions.solution:
DIAGRAM[2,250]
The solid angle subtended by the spherical cap at the center of the hemisphere is \(\Omega = 2\pi(1-\cos	heta)\).
Surface area of the cap \(s = \Omega R^2 = 2\pi R^2(1-\cos	heta)\).
If \(s = \eta(2\pi R^2)\), then
\(2\pi R^2 (1-\cos	heta) = \eta (2\pi R^2)\)
\(\Rightarrow \cos	heta = 1-\eta\)
A dust particle at an angle \(	heta\) is in limiting equilibrium in the reference frame of the hemisphere. 
DIAGRAM[3,250]
Thus,
\(N = mg\cos	heta - m\omega^2R\sin^2	heta\)
And \(\mu N = mg\sin	heta + m\omega^2 R\sin	heta\cos	heta\)
\(\Rightarrow \mu = \dfrac{g\sin	heta + \omega^2 R \sin	heta\cos	heta}{g\cos	heta - \omega^2 R\sin^2	heta}\)
\(\mu = \dfrac{g	an	heta + \omega^2 R\sin	heta}{g - \omega^2 R 	an	heta \sin	heta}\)
questions.hint: The dust particles at the edge of the visible region are in limiting equilibrium. The forces acting on a dust particle are its weight, the normal reaction, and the friction force.  The centripetal force is provided by components of these.
methodOfSolving: Relate the visible area to the angle \(\theta\) subtended by the spherical cap: \(\eta(2\pi R^2) = 2\pi R^2(1-\cos\theta)\).  Solve for \(\cos\theta\).
Draw a free body diagram of a dust particle at the edge of the cap.
Write the equations of equilibrium: \(N = mg\cos\theta - m\omega^2R\sin^2\theta\) (normal to surface)\n                 and \(\mu N = mg\sin\theta + m\omega^2 R\sin\theta\cos\theta\) (along tangent).
Solve for \(\mu\).

questions.title: Acceleration of Chain on Smooth Hill
questions.questionText: A chain with uniform mass per unit length lies in a vertical plane along the slope of a smooth hill. The two ends of the chain are at the same height. If the chain is released from this position, find its acceleration.\nDIAGRAM[1,350]
questions.solution:
Let's calculate the net force of gravity along the slope on the part AB of the chain.
DIAGRAM[2,350]
Consider the small segment of the chain between \(x\) and \(x+dx\).
Gravitational force along the slope is \(\lambda dx g\sin	heta\) \((\lambda = 	ext{mass per unit length})\).
Net gravity force along the slope on part AB is
\(\displaystyle\int_0^l \lambda g\sin	heta dx = \lambda g \displaystyle\int_0^l dy = \lambda gH\)
Thus, the force does not depend on the profile of the hill. It only depends on the height of B from A.
For portion BC also the force will be same. Hence, net force on the chain is zero.
Acceleration of the chain is zero.
questions.hint: Consider the forces acting on the chain due to gravity. Since the hill is smooth, there is no friction. The net force on the chain determines its acceleration. Consider the net force on elements of the chain in portions AB and BC, where AB and BC represent the vertical distances between point A and B, and B and C respectively.  Let H be the height difference between the two ends of the chain, where H = 0 for this case.
methodOfSolving: Consider a small segment of the chain of length \(dx\) at a height \(y\) on the slope AB.  Its mass is \(\lambda dx\). The component of its weight along the slope is \(\lambda g \sin\theta dx\), where \(\sin\theta = dy/dx\).

Integrate this force over the length of the chain segment AB (from 0 to l) to find the net force \(F_{AB}\): \(\displaystyle\int_0^l \lambda g \sin\theta dx = \lambda g \displaystyle\int_0^H dy = \lambda gH\).
Similarly, calculate the net force \(F_{BC}\) along the slope BC. Since the height difference between ends is the same, \(F_{BC} = -\lambda gH\).
The net force on the entire chain is \(F_{net} = F_{AB} + F_{BC} = 0\). Since the net force is zero, the acceleration is zero.

questions.title: Exit Time and Speed of Block from Semicircular Ring
questions.questionText:
A semicircular ring of radius \(R\) is fixed on a smooth horizontal table. A small block is projected with speed \(u\) so as to enter the ring at end A. The initial velocity of the block is along the tangent to the ring at A, and it moves on the table remaining in contact with the inner wall of the ring. The coefficient of friction between the block and the ring is \(\mu\). 
DIAGRAM[1,100]
(a) Find the time after which the block will exit the ring at B.
(b) With what speed will the block leave the ring at B?
questions.solution:
Let the speed be \(v\) after time \(t\) when the block has moved through a distance \(s\). Normal reaction of the ring is \(N = \dfrac{mv^2}{R}\).
\(m\dfrac{dv}{dt} = -\mu N \Rightarrow \dfrac{dv}{dt} = \dfrac{\mu v^2}{R}\)
\(\displaystyle\int_u^v \dfrac{dv}{v^2} = \displaystyle\int_0^t -\dfrac{\mu}{R}dt \Rightarrow \dfrac{1}{v} - \dfrac{1}{u} = \dfrac{\mu t}{R}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{1}{v} = \dfrac{1}{u} + \dfrac{\mu t}{R}\)  ...(1)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{ds}{dt} = \dfrac{1}{\dfrac{1}{u}+\dfrac{\mu t}{R}} = \dfrac{u}{1+\dfrac{\mu ut}{R}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \displaystyle\int_0^\pi \dfrac{\mu}{R} ds = \displaystyle\int_0^t \dfrac{\dfrac{\mu u}{R}dt}{1+\dfrac{\mu ut}{R}} \Rightarrow \dfrac{\mu}{R}s = [\ln(1+\dfrac{\mu ut}{R})]_0^t\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{\mu}{R}(\pi R) = \ln(1+\dfrac{\mu ut}{R})\)
\(\Rightarrow 1 + \dfrac{\mu u t}{R} = e^{\pi\mu}\)
\(\Rightarrow t = \dfrac{R}{\mu u}(e^{\pi\mu} - 1)\)   ...(2)
Put value of \(t\) from equation (2) into equation (1)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{1}{v} = \dfrac{1}{u} + \dfrac{\mu}{R}\dfrac{R}{\mu u}(e^{\pi\mu}-1) = \dfrac{e^{\pi \mu}}{u}\)
\(\Rightarrow v = ue^{-\pi\mu}\)
questions.hint: The normal reaction provides the centripetal force.  Friction opposes the motion and causes tangential deceleration.  Integrate the tangential acceleration to find the velocity and then integrate velocity to find the distance traveled and time.
methodOfSolving: The normal reaction is \(N = \dfrac{mv^2}{R}\).  The frictional force is \(f = \mu N\), and the tangential acceleration is \(a_t = -\dfrac{f}{m} = -\dfrac{\mu v^2}{R}\).
Integrate \(\dfrac{dv}{dt} = -\dfrac{\mu v^2}{R}\) to relate \(v\) and \(t\).
Integrate \(\dfrac{ds}{dt} = v\) with the limits \(s=0\) to \(s=\pi R\) and \(t=0\) to \(t\) to find the time \(t\) taken to travel a distance \(\pi R\) (semicircle).
Substitute this value of \(t\) back into the equation relating \(v\) and \(t\) to find the final velocity \(v\).

questions.title: Minimum Work to Pull Particle to Pulley
questions.questionText: A uniform rope of linear mass density \(\lambda \,\text{kg/m}\) passes over a smooth pulley of negligible dimension. At one end B of the rope there is a small particle having mass one-fiftieth of the rope. Initially the system is held at rest with length \(L\) of the rope on one side and length \(\dfrac{L}{4}\) on the other side of the pulley (see fig.). The external agent begins to pull the end A downward. Find the minimum work that the agent must perform so that the small particle will definitely reach the pulley.\nDIAGRAM[1,350]
questions.solution:
Total mass of the system \(= L\lambda + \dfrac{L\lambda}{4} + \dfrac{L\lambda}{50} = \dfrac{5L\lambda}{4} + \dfrac{L\lambda}{50} = \dfrac{125+1}{50}\dfrac{L\lambda}{2} = \dfrac{126L\lambda}{100} = \dfrac{63L\lambda}{50}\).
The external agent must ensure that more than half the mass of the system gets to the right of the pulley. After that, he can leave the system and the particle will accelerate to the pulley.
Take PE to be zero at the horizontal level of the center of the pulley.
Minimum work needed = Increase in gravitational PE of the system between the two positions shown in the figure below.
DIAGRAM[2,400]
Mass on both sides equal.
\(W_{min} = \left[\dfrac{\lambda L}{2} 	imes \dfrac{L}{4}g - \dfrac{\lambda 3L}{4} 	imes \dfrac{3L}{8}g - \dfrac{\lambda L}{4 	imes 2}gight] - \left[-\dfrac{\lambda L}{2} 	imes \dfrac{L}{2}g - \dfrac{\lambda L}{4} 	imes \dfrac{L}{8}g - \dfrac{\lambda L}{4}gight] = \dfrac{\lambda L g}{4} \left[\dfrac{L}{2} - \dfrac{9L}{8} - \dfrac{L}{8} + L + \dfrac{L}{8} + Light] = \dfrac{7\lambda L^2 g}{32}\).
DIAGRAM[3,100]
questions.hint: The minimum work done is equal to the change in potential energy of the system when the mass on both sides of the pulley is equal.  Consider the two configurations: initial and when mass on both sides of the pulley are equal.
methodOfSolving: Calculate the total mass of the system: rope mass + particle mass.
The external agent needs to pull the rope until more than half the system's mass is on the right side of the pulley.
Calculate the change in potential energy between the initial state and the state where the masses on both sides are equal.  This is the minimum work required.

questions.title: Angle of Velocity After Elastic Collision
questions.questionText: A mass \(m\) moving with speed \(u\) in \(x\) direction collides elastically with a stationary mass \(2m\). After the collision, it was found that both masses have equal \(x\) components of velocity. What angle does the velocity of mass \(2m\) make with the \(x\) axis?
questions.solution:
In the lab frame, the \(x\) component of velocity of the two particles is \(v_x = \dfrac{u}{3}\).
DIAGRAM[1,100]
In CoM frame, before collision, the situation appears as shown below.
DIAGRAM[2,200]
\(2v_x = u \Rightarrow v = \dfrac{u}{3}\)
Because \(x\) component of velocity of \(2m\)
\(= \dfrac{mu}{m+2m} = \dfrac{u}{3}\)
Since CoM is moving along \(x\), the velocity components in \(y\) direction are same in lab frame as well as CoM frame.
After collision, particles travel along y in CoM frame. Kinetic energy is conserved in CoM frame also.
DIAGRAM[3,100]

\(\dfrac{1}{2}mv_1^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}(2m)v_2^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}m\left(\dfrac{2u}{3}ight)^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}2m\left(\dfrac{u}{3}ight)^2 = \dfrac{2}{3}mu^2\)
\(\dfrac{2}{3}v_1'^2 + \dfrac{1}{3}(v_2')^2 = \dfrac{2}{3}u^2\Rightarrow v_1' = -u \Rightarrow v_2' = u\)
In lab frame the situation will appear as shown below.DIAGRAM[4,200]
\(	heta = 45^\circ\)
questions.hint: Consider the center of mass (CoM) frame. In this frame, the velocities of the two masses are along the y-axis after the collision. Apply conservation of momentum and kinetic energy in the CoM frame.
methodOfSolving: Determine the velocity of the center of mass.
In the CoM frame, the initial \(x\)-component of velocity of mass \(m\) is \(2u/3\) and that of \(2m\) is \(-u/3\).
Since the final \(x\)-components are equal in the lab frame, they are also equal in the CoM frame, and are given by \(u/3\) since \(v_{cm} = u/3\).
Apply conservation of momentum and kinetic energy in the CoM frame to find the y-components of the final velocities.
Convert back to the lab frame to find the final velocities and the angle the velocity of \(2m\) makes with the x-axis.

questions.title: Maximum Angle of Deflection in Elastic Collision
questions.questionText: A ball of mass \(M\) collides elastically with another stationary ball of mass \(m\). If \(M > m\), find the maximum angle of deflection of \(M\).
questions.solution:
Let's analyze this collision in the center of mass (CoM) frame.  Let \(u\) be the initial velocity of mass \(M\). In the CoM frame, before the collision:
\(v_{M,cm} = \dfrac{m}{M+m}u\)
\(v_{m,cm} = -\dfrac{M}{M+m}u\)

DIAGRAM[1: Before collision in CoM frame]

After the collision, in the CoM frame, the speeds remain the same, but the directions can change.  The maximum deflection of \(M\) occurs when the collision is glancing in the CoM frame.  Let \(v_M'\) and \(v_m'\) be the velocities of \(M\) and \(m\) after the collision in the CoM frame, respectively.  Let \(\delta\) be the angle of deflection of \(M\) in the lab frame.  The CoM velocity is given by:
\(v_{cm} = \dfrac{Mu + m(0)}{M+m} = \dfrac{Mu}{M+m}\)
The initial velocity of \(M\) in the CoM frame is \(v_{M,cm} = \dfrac{m}{M+m}u\). Since the collision is elastic, the magnitudes of velocities in COM frame remain unchanged.  The velocity of \(M\) in the CoM frame after collision is also \(v_{M,cm} = \dfrac{m}{M+m}u\).

DIAGRAM[2: After collision in CoM frame, showing maximum deflection]

For the maximum angle of deflection \(\delta_{max}\), the final velocity of M makes an angle \(\delta_{max}\) such that
\(v_{cm}\sin\delta_{max} = v_{M,cm}\)
\(\Rightarrow \sin\delta_{max} = \dfrac{v_{M,cm}}{v_{cm}} = \dfrac{\dfrac{m}{M+m}u}{\dfrac{M}{M+m}u} = \dfrac{m}{M}\)
\(\delta_{max} = \sin^{-1}\left(\dfrac{m}{M}ight)\)
questions.hint: Analyze the collision in the center of mass (CoM) frame. The maximum angle of deflection occurs when the collision is a glancing one in the CoM frame.  Remember that in an elastic collision, kinetic energy is conserved, and in the CoM frame, the velocities of the particles are reversed after collision.
methodOfSolving: Determine the velocity of the center of mass (CoM).
Calculate the initial velocity of mass \(M\) in the CoM frame.
For maximum deflection, the collision is glancing in the CoM frame. Relate the angle of deflection \(\delta_{max}\) to the CoM velocity and the initial CoM velocity of \(M\).
Solve for \(\delta_{max}\).

questions.title: Angle of Inclination for Hemisphere on Verge of Sliding
questions.questionText: A uniform hemisphere placed on an incline is on the verge of sliding. The coefficient of friction between the hemisphere and the incline is \(\mu\). Find the angle \(\phi\) that the circular base of the hemisphere makes with the horizontal.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
Let \(	heta\) be the angle of incline.
DIAGRAM[2,250]
\(C ightarrow\) Center of circular base; \(G ightarrow\) Center of mass.  \(CG = \dfrac{3R}{8}\). \(A ightarrow\) Contact point.
CA is \(\perp\) to the incline.
The normal contract force (along AC), weight (along GA) and friction all pass through point A.
\(	an	heta = \mu\)
In \(	riangle ACG\):
\(\dfrac{CG}{CA} = \dfrac{\dfrac{3R}{8}}{R\sin\phi} = \dfrac{3}{8\sin\phi}\)
Also, \(\dfrac{CG}{CA} = \dfrac{\sin(\pi-\phi)}{\sin	heta} = \dfrac{\sin\phi}{\sin	heta}\)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{\sin\phi}{\sin	heta} = \dfrac{3}{8\sin\phi}\Rightarrow \sin^2\phi = \dfrac{3}{8}\sin	heta\)
Since, \(	an	heta = \mu\), we have \(\sin	heta = \dfrac{\mu}{\sqrt{1+\mu^2}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \sin^2\phi = \dfrac{3\mu}{8\sqrt{1+\mu^2}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \phi = \sin^{-1}\sqrt{\dfrac{3\mu}{8\sqrt{1+\mu^2}}}\)
questions.hint: Since the hemisphere is on the verge of sliding, the friction force is equal to \(\mu\) times the normal reaction.  The forces acting on the hemisphere are its weight, the normal reaction, and the friction force.  These forces must pass through the point of contact A. Consider the triangle formed by the center of mass G, the center of the circular base C, and the contact point A. The center of gravity of a solid hemisphere of radius R is at a distance 3R/8 from its geometrical center C.
methodOfSolving: The angle of inclination of the plane is given by \(\tan\theta = \mu\), which implies \(\sin\theta = \dfrac{\mu}{\sqrt{1+\mu^2}}\).
The center of gravity G is at a distance \(\dfrac{3R}{8}\) from the center C.
In triangle ACG, the ratio \(CG/CA = \dfrac{3R/8}{R\sin\phi} = \dfrac{\sin(\pi - \phi)}{\sin\theta}\).
Simplify the equation and solve for \(\phi\).

questions.title: Kinetic Energy of Rolling Ball with Non-Rotating Point
questions.questionText: Consider an idealized case of rolling of a solid ball in which the point \(P\) does not rotate in a vertical plane. But it rotates on a circular path \(PQRSTP\) when observed from the centre of the ball. The radius of a circular path \(PQRSTP\) is half the radius of the ball. The ball rolls without sliding with its centre moving with speed \(v_0\) in a direction perpendicular to the plane of the figure. Calculate the kinetic energy of the rolling ball. The mass of the ball and its radius are \(M\) and \(R\) respectively.\nDIAGRAM[1,250]
questions.solution:
\(\omega = \) angular speed
\(\dfrac{\omega R}{2} = v_0\) for pure rolling condition.
\(	ext{KE} = \dfrac{1}{2}Mv_0^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}I\omega^2\)
\(= \dfrac{1}{2}Mv_0^2 + \dfrac{1}{2}\left(\dfrac{2}{5}MR^2ight)\omega^2 = \dfrac{1}{2}Mv_0^2 + \dfrac{1}{5}M(R\omega)^2\)
\(= \dfrac{1}{2}Mv_0^2 + \dfrac{1}{5}M(2v_0)^2 = \dfrac{13}{10}Mv_0^2\)
questions.hint: The kinetic energy of the rolling ball is the sum of its translational kinetic energy and rotational kinetic energy. For pure rolling, the angular velocity is related to the linear velocity of the center of mass and radius.  Since radius of circular path of point P is R/2, \(v_0 = \omega R/2\).
methodOfSolving: The translational kinetic energy is \(\dfrac{1}{2}Mv_0^2\).
The rotational kinetic energy is \(\dfrac{1}{2}I\omega^2\), where \(I = \dfrac{2}{5}MR^2\) for a solid sphere.

For pure rolling, the velocity of the center of mass is related to the angular velocity by \(v_0 = \dfrac{\omega R}{2}\), as point P traces a circle of radius \(\dfrac{R}{2}\) with \(v_0\) as velocity.
Substitute \(\omega\) in terms of \(v_0\) and add the translational and rotational kinetic energies to find the total kinetic energy.

questions.title: Acceleration of Ring Wrapped with Rope
questions.questionText: A uniform rope tightly wraps around a uniform thin ring of mass \(M\) and radius \(R\). The mass of the segment of the rope around the ring (i.e., mass of the length \(2\pi R\) of the rope) is also \(M\). The ends of the rope are fixed one above the other and it is taut. The ring is let go. Find its acceleration. Assume no slipping and the thickness of the rope to be negligible.\nDIAGRAM[1,100]
questions.solution:
At any given instant the ring and the rope around it is moving. Rest of the rope is not moving at any given instant. The motion is identical to that of a wheel rolling without sliding.
Taking torque about A:
DIAGRAM[2,200]
\(I_A\alpha = 	au_A\)
\(2(2M)R^2 \alpha = 2MgR\)
\(\Rightarrow \alpha = \dfrac{g}{2R}\)
Acceleration of the centre will be \(a = R\alpha = \dfrac{g}{2}\).
questions.hint: The motion of the ring is analogous to rolling without slipping. Consider the torque about the point of contact of the ring with the rope. The total mass rotating includes the mass of the ring and the mass of the rope segment in contact with it. Then find linear acceleration using \(a=R\alpha\).
methodOfSolving: The motion is equivalent to rolling without slipping.
The instantaneous point of contact of the ring with the rope is the instantaneous axis of rotation.
The total mass involved in rotation is \(2M\) (mass of ring \(M\) + mass of rope segment \(M\)).  The moment of inertia about the point of contact A is \(I_A = 2MR^2\) (using parallel axis theorem).
The torque about A is \(\tau_A = MgR\).
Use the torque equation \(I_A\alpha = \tau_A\) to find the angular acceleration \(\alpha\).
The linear acceleration of the center of the ring is \(a = R\alpha\).

questions.title: Velocity of Center of Square Plate After Vertex is Fixed
questions.questionText: A uniform square plate ABCD has mass \(M\) and side length \(a\). It is sliding on a horizontal smooth surface with a velocity of \(\vec{v} = v_0(4\hat{i}+2\hat{j})\). There is no rotation. Vertex A of the plate is suddenly fixed by a nail. Calculate the velocity of the center of the plate immediately after this.\nDIAGRAM[1,200]
questions.solution:
We can apply conservation of angular momentum about a point on the surface just below A.
DIAGRAM[2,400]
Initial angular momentum about point A:
\(L_{iA} = M(4v_0)\dfrac{a}{2} - M(2v_0)\dfrac{a}{2} = Mv_0a\) (Clockwise)
Final angular momentum about point A:
\(L_{fA} = I_A \omega = \dfrac{2}{3}Ma^2\omega\) (Clockwise)
\(\Rightarrow \dfrac{2}{3}Ma^2 \omega = Mv_0a \Rightarrow \omega = \dfrac{3v_0}{2a}\)
DIAGRAM[3,150]
Velocity of centre will be:
\(v_c = \dfrac{a}{\sqrt{2}}\omega = \dfrac{a}{\sqrt{2}}\dfrac{3v_0}{2a} = \dfrac{3v_0}{2\sqrt{2}}\), in the direction perpendicular to AC.
\(\Rightarrow \vec{v}_c = \dfrac{3v_0}{2\sqrt{2}}\left[\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\hat{i} - \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\hat{j}ight] = \dfrac{3v_0}{4}(\hat{i}-\hat{j})\)
questions.hint: Since the nail exerts an impulse at point A, the angular momentum about A is conserved. Calculate the angular momentum about A just before and just after the nail is fixed. The velocity of the center of mass is related to the angular velocity about A.
methodOfSolving: Apply conservation of angular momentum about the point A.  Before fixing the nail, the plate has linear momentum but no angular momentum.
Calculate the initial angular momentum \(L_{iA}\) about A using the given velocity: \(L_{iA} = Mv_x (a/2) - Mv_y (a/2) = Mv_0a\).

After A is fixed, the plate rotates about A with angular velocity \(\omega\). Calculate the moment of inertia \(I_A\) of the plate about A (perpendicular axis theorem to calculate moment of inertia about centre of mass), and hence the final angular momentum \(L_{fA} = I_A \omega\).
Apply conservation of angular momentum: \(L_{iA} = L_{fA}\). Solve for \(\omega\).
The velocity of the center of mass after A is fixed is \(v_c = r\omega\), where \(r = \dfrac{a}{\sqrt{2}}\) is the distance from A to the center of mass. The direction is perpendicular to AC.
